<Author>Shellyboo70
<Content>Absolutely Marvelous!!!!!!!!! We stayed at the InterContinental over the Christmas holiday, for 5 nights. What a beautiful resort. We never used the Casino, since we're not gamblers. The pool was gorgeous and really enjoyed the evening swimming. The staff was extremely helpful, and kept the hotel in top shape. We got our room through Hotwire, and we were very pleased about the property. We coudn't have asked for more!!! We did not use any of the hotels restaurants for dining, since we really wanted to experience the local flavor. There is a great restaurant, Mi Casita across the street, that was tasty and well priced. We rented a jeep and parked across the street for about 16 bucks per night, and had access to a parking area 24 hours a day, the lot is safe, and is alway attended by InterContinental staff. We will defiinitey stay at this location again and again. I wish I were there right now!  
<Date>Jan 6, 2009

<Author>glory4
<Content>Great hotel and location My husband and I stayed here with our 4 year old son in January. The hotel is in a great location, within walking distance of lots of stores, other hotels and restaurants. The hotel was covered in amazing Christmas decorations and still smelled of pine. Their sushi restaurant was amazing and our son loved their fish tank as well. Our room was on the 15th floor and was very spacious with a pull out sofa. Our only complaint with the room was that we had a room facing the road and there was lots of road noise and sirens all night. I would upgrade to an ocean front room in the future. The front desk staff and bellmen were all wonderfully attentive and considerate. The beach is great, as is the large pool. Overall we had a great stay and would love to return in the future.

<Author>happycruiser11
<Content>Fire alarms in the middle of the nights, raw sewage, 22% tax I've stayed many places in San Juan but wanted to try this hotel because it is top rated. (Marriott, esj, and Embassy suites are all wonderful)I booked my husband and I here for the first 4 nights of our honeymoon before we caught a princess cruise to eastern Caribbean. First glance, I loved it, it was gorgeous, friendly staff and nice restaurants. It stopped there: beware of an extra 22% hotel tax they tack onto your bill on that credit card for incidentals I have never had to pay this at any of the other hotels. I pre-paid everything this vacation with priceline, so I was perturbed at this. Beyond that minor aggravation, a fire alarm went off two nights in a row at 1:40 and 3 am. I can understand one night having an accident in the kitchen, but two? Beyond that, the manager of the hotel had no idea that the first night it had gone off, he said, oh, it must have been a floor alarm that someone on your floor tripped. But that he had no information on it and oh well. Im a very light sleeper and being woken from dead sleep to a very loud siren and loud booming voice saying a fire has been detected in the building was not my idea of a nice honeymoon. Ok, beyond these two obstacles, we decided to book an excursion on the island. The concierge was very helpful and we decided to take one (mind you very expensive one) that took us to El Yunque, Luquillo beach, and Bioluminescent bay. I had heard great things about the first and last, but never luquillo. I asked the concierge and he said OH its wonderful, best beach on the island, so we went ahead. The rainforest was nice, but when the van dropped us off at the beach and told us they'd be back in 3 hours, we were a little freaked out. We couldn't see the beach from the parking lot so before the van drove away, the guide told us he'd pick us up at the food shacks a half mile down the road at 6pm. Passing them on the way in, it looked like the worst part of the barrio, so we decided we better stay on the beach as long as possible. The van drove away and we walked towards the beach. As soon as we got 10 steps further (of course the van was long gone by then) we saw homeless people sleeping on the beach which was littered with trash and bugs. A few people were swimming but the water looked a little of a weird color--Im from new jersey and even our beaches didn't look that gross. So of course with every disaster of a honeymoon, the clouds darkened for a storm so we were forced to walk to the barrio food shacks. On the way we noticed a nice large river of raw sewage (yes it was for sure as it smelled like it as well) that flowed right into the beach. (we're talking raw sewage into a beach 0.25 miles from the center of the beach) So in the barrio, we were like sitting ducks, we might as well had a target on us, so we spent the 2.5 hours left in the corner of one of the shacks playing pool and trying to generously tip the people at that food stand in hopes we wouldn't be shot or mugged. Finally we got picked up and were brought to Bioluminescent bay in Fajardo. It was nice, but since it was still storming it was a bit short and they didn't let us swim in the water, just kayaked 40 mins round trip to shake our hands in the water and return to the shore. Afterwards, talking to other people on the island, they said the best place to see Biobay is in Vieques (an island off the eastern coast). I give this background because the concierge at the hotel is the one that put us on this. We asked a few cab drivers that they get for you at the hotel and they all say Luquillo is their favorite beach, but any taxi driver not around that hotel will tell you culebra or some others on the western side or southern part of the island.....suspicious, to us it seemed they were all in coohoots. OK so when we went to check out, we asked the manager about this, and he told us, look it up online, its a wonderful beach! I said I dont care what it said online, we've been there and seen the area, seen the sewage and contamination, and its crazy they keep sending people there. He didn't seem to care, so great if he likes swimming in raw sewage (which is where I'd like to dunk him now), I just advise the rest of you dont. :) So to not ruin your vacation or honeymoon, this is a beautiful hotel, but I'd advise stay in The Embassy Suites (free hot breakfast and free happy 2 hours) or El San Juan and with either you can walk to Ruth's Chris steakhouse or any Intercontinental amenities.  
<Date>Nov 18, 2008

<Author>Rwinks685
<Content>My Favorite Hotel This hotel is one of the best I have stayed at. I discovered this hotel during 9/11 (where I was forced to stay during the air space clousure) and fell in love iwth it. I have returned at least once a year since then.The service is great. I have never had a problem with staff. They are helpful and go out of their way to meet your needs.The beach is very nice and rivals any in the Carribean. It is clean and safe. I have never been bothered here by beggars, etc. The pool is really cool. Waterfalls, swim up bar, adult area, kid area. What more do you need? The only draw back is if you sleep in, you may not get a chair! My kids and wife love it too.The rooms are clean and very comfortable. Even though it is near the airport, you never hear the planes. Very quiet.If you are looking for a quality hotel in San Juan, this one is worth evey penny.

<Author>LifesATrip007
<Content>Fabulous We (my husband and I and another couple) stayed here one night after our cruise and we all absolutely loved this hotel. I was nervous because I was the one that made the reservations and you know how that can sometimes go! But from the moment we checked in to the moment we left we enjoyed our stay tremendously. When we arrived we were immediately greeted as we got out of the taxi and our bags were taken care of. Check-in was a breeze...although that could have something to do with the fact that there happened to be no one else in line when we arrived! We arrived early and our room wasn't ready which we didn't expect it to be. We were offered a hospitality room (which was one of the hotel rooms) to use to change/freshen up, etc. So we put our suits on and headed right out to the beach for the afternoon. The staff were all friendly. I was pleasantly surprised when we checked out the next morning that the gentleman behind the desk actually remembered my name and greeted me by name. The hotel room itself was great. I didn't find it small at all (could that be because we just came off of a week on a cruise ship???). There was a vanity right outside the bathroom which was perfect for hair and makeup and best of all - the lighting was good for doing your makeup! (Women can relate to this issue!).We didn't eat in the hotel so I can't comment on that. We did have breakfast in a small diner located in the strip mall across the street - food was good (typical breakfast stuff) and very reasonably priced. The hotel is about a 5 minute ride to the airport and I was surprised that the whole afternoon we spent on the beach (and the next morning) we never heard any planes go by.All in all I highly recommend this hotel and if we go back we'll definitely stay here again.  
<Date>Nov 8, 2008

<Author>didiette
<Content>Raving Reviews! Loved It! My boyfriend and I stayed at the Intercontinental during our 3 night trip to Puerto Rico Oct. 17th - 20th. We really enjoyed our stay here. It was a quick ride from the airport, costing us about $15 with our luggage, and when we got there, the bell guy who greeted us (Ramon) very warm and friendly. We checked in early and our room was not ready, but they held our bags and encouraged us to walk around and view the facility. The pool area was very nice, and just steps beyond that was the beach. The landscape of the pool area was awesome and the swim up bar was a definite plus. Since we were traveling in the off season, there weren't many people there and so it was easy to get service. All the staff members were extremely friendly, curteous, and professional. I have nothing but the best to say about them. David, the bartender, was the best! He gave us wonderful recommendations for food and was always available with a helping hand. The room was a bit small, but it was functional. The bed was comfortable and we had fresh towels everyday. The only bad thing was the bathtub took so long to drain -- by the end of the shower you'd be standing in 3 of water. The hotel lobby was nice and bright and I enjoyed their casino as well. We won the first night, but gave it all back plus some throughout our stay. I would definitely go back to the intercontinental and would recommend this hotel to anyone.  
<Date>Nov 4, 2008

<Author>foxyb03
<Content>Que Sabor! What Flavor! Que Sabor! What flavor! From the minute you enter the premises of the Intercontinental San Juan you are surrounded by lush landscaping, friendly bilingual staff, and native salsa music. I was not disappointed. The rates were equal to what you get. The grounds were kept clean. Staff and security were visible 24 hours a day. My husband and I stayed for a week and visited the spa daily. It was empty most days but is complimentary including bottled water, robes, fruit, and a nice dry/wet sauna. The gym overlooks the ocean and has very up to date equipment. I would advise all to eat majority of meals outside of the resort as breakfast alone cost us $45. There is a grocery store along with restaurants offering cheap authentic Puerto Rican cuisine within walking distance. The concierge can get you anywhere you want to go along with available cab service stationed outside the front door of hotel. I plan to go again soon!  
<Date>Nov 4, 2008

<Author>KfromME622
<Content>Very nice, but a bit dated We stayed at the Intercontinental for four nights, and had a great time. The hotel was clean and beautiful, although the room decor was a bit dated. The bed was super comfortable, and the pool and beach were clean and well maintained. The staff was very accomodating, but the best part was that they left you alone. I have been to resorts where the pool area staff hovered around you and asked if you needed anything every five minutes, but here they were visible and available, but left you alone for the most part. The beach was clean and not too crowded. The surf was a bit rough and there was a bit of an undertow, but it was fun. Just watch out for the stinging urchins! We did not eat at any of the hotel restaurants, but we did get room service and the food was just okay. We got the continental breakfast in the lobby each morning and took it down to the beach, which was great. The coffee in the lobby is so good! Overall, this was not a bad hotel, and I'd stay there again if I ever go back to San Juan. Just be sure to ask for a room overlooking the pool and ocean, since the view on the other side is not so great. Also, be aware that the hotel (and in fact all of the Isla Verde area hotels) are very close to the airport, so you will hear jets taking off and landing all day. If that will bother you, you may want to try Condado or one of the other parts of the island.  
<Date>Oct 25, 2008

<Author>epleiss
<Content>Awesome quick getaway!! My husband and I stayed at the Intercontinental for my birthday and it was just perfect. If you are looking for a relaxing atmosphere without the big crowds (low season), this is the place to go.The hotel has an elegant flair and they try to make it feel as luxurious as possible, don't expect Ritz Carlton level and you will not be dissapointed. The hotel: Same as everyone else says : nice people, slow front desk, helpful when needed and always opening doors. As far as the food at the hotel, we only ate there once and it was good but pricey, $48.00 for lunch that consisted of a burger, a sandwich and two drinks, ouch. Stay away from the drinks at the beach bar, we ended up ordering two $15 drinks that were not even that great or strong or big. Check with the waiter about the prices before you order because they don't list them on the menu.The rooms: Nice and clean, not imaculate but clean. The bed was soft and plushy, super comfortable. We also upgraded to ocean view and it really is worth the money. We were greeted with wine and strawberries for my B-day which is always nice.The beach: We read that the beach in Isla Verde is nothing compared to the not so touristy beaches that PR offers, so we didn't know what to expect. When we finally checked in, ( that took a really long time) we headed to the beach and it was beautiful. Blue, calm and just what we needed. There were maybe 8 other couples on the beach, so it felt very private. It was quiet, and so relaxing. The beach alone is worth the trip.We opted to rent a car, and I would say that if you are planning to do some exploring you have to rent a car. It is very easy to get everywhere and the freedom you get to leave when you want and go whenever and wherever you want to go is awesome. So, unless you are not moving from the hotel, rent a car, it is worth it and cheaper. I definetaly agree with the fact that organized tours are not worth your money. We explored so much, Luquillo beach, the rainforest, Old san juan, Pinones on Sunday when all the locals go (fun and very PR, if you want to sample local food, brace yourself and eat).The only tour I highly recommend is the Vieques Bioluminecent tour. East Island Excursions is the only company that can arrange a night trip and bring you back to Fajardo, which is a 20-30 minute drive from Isla Verde. I will do it again in a heart beat. To read more about it, go to puertoricodaytrips.com. Don't forget to schedule your tour according to the what phase the moon is in. The biobay is best experienced on cloudy, moonless nights. Food: Well, I guess this is the only down side of our trip. We are very adventurous when it comes to food and we were looking forward to trying the local fare. Unfortunately, most of it didn't agree with me, lots of fried and super fried foods. But that is just me. We ate at Mi Casita one night and it was good, we also tried Pamela's for my actual b-day dinner, and even though that was pricey, about $200.00 for two with drinks, it was so yummy.I am definetaly coming back with the kids, the hotel's pool is awesome and beach access steps away. I recommend everyone explore PR, it is really beautiful and so different than your usual Mexico vacation. I look forward to coming back soon.  
<Date>Oct 25, 2008

<Author>Travelscott
<Content>A great pre-cruise hotel We stayed at the Intercontinental for 2 nights before our Southern Caribbean cruise. We were met by a wonderful staff, always with a smile and a greeting. The entire staff were friendly and helpful. The hotel itself was beautiful, and our room was spectacular, very clean, with a comfy king size bed. The pool area was great, the pool itself was phenominal with a waterfall and a swim-up bar. The hotel is situated on the beach, which is a short walk from the pool. We had a great time and I highly recommend this hotel to anyone. The only downfall is the food prices at this hotel. However, there is ample food choices for the bargin hunter just across the street.

<Author>THEJ'S
<Content>What a fantabulous trip My husband and I spent our anniversary at the intercontinental, what a wonderful time we had. Upon arrival to the hotel we were greeted by some of the nicest hotel staff there is. Check-in was relatively smooth, although our room wasn't ready the bell man had already taken out luggage and placed it in safekeeping. Once we were able to get to our room I couldn't believe how beautiful the room was. We were able to get an ocean view and it was worth every penny it cost. We received complimentary wine and chocolate covered strawberries to celebrate our anniversary. The concierge was very helpful they gave direction for everything within the area. Every type of fast food eatery is within distance of the hotel for example..... Church's chicken, baskin robbins, Dominoes, Pizza Hut, Wendy's and more. Please also try the italian restaurant in the hotel wow how wonderful of a meal they offer. The wine distillery was a bus ride away so there was no need to rent a car. The buses are free from Aug 08-Dec 08 so ride on. We visited the rain forest which is an experience I recommend to every tourist. The pool area was wonderful as well. With regards to shopping you can shop for all the name brands Coach Tommy Hilfiger, Boss, Dooney  Burke, Burberry. This is a trip that I am really glad I took and had a great time without spending a bundle of money.

<Author>SalseroWes
<Content>Tips fom a 3rd-time Visitor Background: I'm 28yrs old, I have been to San Juan 3 times in the past 2 years - twice at the El San Juan when I was single (next door) and once at the Intercontinental with my girlfriend (this visit).The Hotel: My first impression was that the hotel was very nice. It is centrally located in relation to popular tourist attractions (Old San Juan and El Yunque Rainforest). It is right on a beatiful beach. The lobby is quite small and not much going on. If you are looking for action the El San Juan is right next door. Overall, the pool and the lobby is much nicer at the El San Juan but for a family, couples, a relaxing vacation or elderly people, the Intercontinental is a better choice as it is much quieter and well lit. The El San Juan is very trendy, dark and loud (think night club) - but if you are single and younger (under 35) the El San Juan is a better choice.The Room: I originally upgraded to a room with an ocean view but when I got to my room on the 7th floor I noticed that most of the view was obstructed by trees. I immediately called the front desk and they gladly changed rooms to the 14th floor...that view was SPECTACULAR!!! Moral of the story - make sure you call for a higher floor because ocean view is pretty much anything on the side of the hotel that faces the ocean...it doesn't necessarily mean that you can see the ocean LOL! My only complaint was that the walls were paper-thin and you can easily hear people in the next room and it can be hard to sleep at night if you have loud neighbors. I had to call security all 3 nights I was there - it's not the hotel's fault that these people were really loud but just keep in mind that the walls are thin.The Hotel Staff: The staff is extremely courteous (much more than at the El San Juan). There was always someone to open the doors to the hotel for you no matter what time you entered or exited the hotel (and they never asked or expected a tip). The concierge was very nice and helpful as well. My only complaint was that the service at the front desk was a bit slow. House keeping was very quiet when cleaning other rooms- they were like ninjas - you dind't even know they were there. I left my room for breakfast, put the sign on my door to get my room cleaned...came back 45min later and my entire room was clean.Rental Car / PARKING!!!! : This was the best part for me...right accross the street is a self-parking area...it costs $16 per day and you can go in and out AS MUCH AS YOU PLEASE! This is such an advantage if you are doing any sightseeing. DO NOT waste money on organized tours...all the signs in San Juan are in English and easy to follow. Rent a car and you will save yourself a TON on money (including a $15 cab trip each way to and from the airport). I reserved a car from the airport on priceline.com for $15/day tax inc.!!!! That's $93 for a 4-day, 3-night weekend for parking and the car - You can't beat that! Old San Juan and the Bacardi factory are 15min by car and the rainforest is 45min away. If you take an organized tour this will cost you at least a couple of hundred dollars per person...for something that can easily be done on your own! However, make sure you bring a GPS - it will really come in handy - if you don't have one, most rental car companies can offer you one at a marginal rate. RENT A CAR, RENT A CAR, RENT A CAR!!!!Where to eat: Right across from the hotel there are tons of restaurants (Burger King, Pizza Hut, Wendy's, Subway, KFC...). My suggestion would be Mi Casita it is fairly authentic and relatively inexpensive and the food is good...BUT BEWARE the service can be long. I have eaten at this restaurant 5 times, dinner usually takes at least 45min for you to get your food and breakfast is around 25-30min. However, the last day we were there, dinner came out in 15min and breakfast came out in 10min...so I would say it's hit or miss but prepare for the worst. Don't go when you are extremely hungry because chances are you will wait a while. Try their Signature Mofongo dishes (mashed plantain topped with a tomato based sauce and your choice of chicken/beef/shrimp.) Overall, the wait is worth it - both for the quality of the food and especially the price.  If you eat at any of the hotels, don't expect to get out of there for under $100 for 2 people (wine not included). Another option, is there is a grocery store within 5min walking distance from the hotel - you can't see it, so ask the concierge how to get to the Pueblo grocery store. There you can buy water, drinks, and even prepared food for dirt cheap prices. Also, there is a Walgreens 5min walking distance as well. Beach: The beach is very nice but can be crowded in peak seasons. It is a long beach - I'd say at least 5 miles. The sand is groomed every morning. The water can get rough if there is bad weather but generally, it is really good. The good thing about this hotel is that the beach chairs are free. Some other hotels charge $4/day for beach chairs!Things to do: If you like booze, the Bacardi Factory is nearby, you can go on a tour once you get there with your rental car =) Old San Juan is beautiful - make sure to bring a camera. There are a few old forts that can be visted that will give you a great view of the ocean and the city as well as a history of the island. Also, there is a path that you can walk on right by the ocean that takes you all along Old San Juan.El Yunque rainforest: This is a must! Take your rental car and drive to the rainforest; there are many well marked trails that are paved. You do not need a guide or to go on a tour. If you go by yourself - it's FREE!!!! All you have to do is print out a trail map from the internet first. On my first trip in 2005, I went on a tour that cost me $60...we walked for an hour and we were done. This time I did some research and did the La Mina trail and the Big Tree trail and that was amazing - nothing like what the tours take you on...breath-taking scenery and a gorgeous waterfall at the bottom. The rainforest opens at 7:30am; if you start hiking before 8:30am you will be fine otherwise expect crowds, especially at La Mina Falls. Both trails I took were about 40min of hiking...the La Mina trail is MUCH nicer than the Big Tree trail but it is also a bit harder to do. If you are in any decent shape, I suggest the La Mina trail down to the falls and the Big Tree trail back up. I hope this helps you out, I really love Puerto Rico and it is clear why it is called La Isla Del Encanto. I am set to go back in May and visit Culebra, home to Flamenco Beach - rated by Discovery Channel as one of the nicest beaches in the world. If you have a week in PR be sure to check this out - I am sure that you won't be sorry =)Wes  
<Date>Oct 15, 2008

<Author>PhoeSky
<Content>Breathe - Taking The hotel was steps from the beach. It is locate along the hotel strip 5 mins from the airport. A girlfriend and I stayed here for her birthday and she loved it. We were upgraded to an oceanview room without even asking for it. There are plenty restaurants within the hotel but we did not eat at any of them. There are restaurants along the strip and you have your american chains (Burger King, Church's, Wendy's, etc) I could have not asked for a better hotel. The grounds were well maintained, the staff was always helpful, and I love the huge swimming pool. What you are not told is that there is a hotel fee of $10 a day, but they hold a $100 a day on your credit card. I don't have one bad thing to say about this hotel.

<Author>sambamdoo
<Content>Mom, Hubby, Kids all loved it! We took my mom here for her 65th birthday knowing she loved PR. Well, it was a GREAT trip- except for the rain the last few days. We were there from Oct.9-13 and even though the hotel was full, it never felt that way. Everyone loved the resort, hubby-hard to please, mom-harder to please :-) and our 2 little girls- 5 and 6. Our 14 year old was a bit bored due to the fact that there weren't many teenagers for her to hang with. Wonder if they have a kids program during peak season? They did show family movies every day at 5:00 p.m. The pool was beautiful, the staff amazingly friendly, beach clean and lovely. I do prefer the Caribbean Sea to the Atlantic Ocean but Intercontinental can't do anything about that. LOL The casino was fun- as mentioned, free food and drinks while gambling. Old San Juan was great shopping and beautiful. Will definitely be back, but beware as hotels everywhere, the food and drink prices were high. Mix BK, Subway,Mi Casita with hotel food and have a WONDERFUL time. We did.

<Author>gatorbucboy
<Content>better than expected We went in the off season and paid less than $2000 for airfare and three nights at hotel for four of us.. We have a 3 and 5 year old who loved it. The pool is fantastic with waterfalls, swim up bars, and even a shallow platform for the kids to play on. The beach is steps away and there is an outdoor restaraunt so you never have to go in. There are some good places to eat at the hotel but we found that if you want authentic puerto rican food all you have to do is go across the street to Mia Casita, fantastic food and very inexpensive. We took the public bus to Old SanJuan and the fort. Took us an hour to get there. On the way back we took a taxi for $20 and it took 10 minutes, worth it! At night there is always music in the lobby and the casino is small but very adequate. Complimentary sandwiches and beverages at gaming areas. We will be going back and recommended it to all traveling types.  
<Date>Oct 9, 2008

<Author>MYPRITI
<Content>Loved it again. This was my 2nd stay at the Intercontinental San Juan. Once again, it was very clean and very nice. We reserved a suite, which has a separate living room, tv and fridge. There was another fridge and tv in the bedroom. The staff was nice and helpful. I liked the location. Isla Verde is a public beach, and very clean for a public beach. Great diner across the street, very convenient. Love the fact that it was literally 5 mins from the airport. Great for a quick get away. Just a very easy, convenient trip and the beach is beautiful. One silly thing that disappointed me was the fact that complimentary bottles of water were available at the towel desk during our last visit but not during this visit. The pool is nice but a bit small. The pool area is beautiful. Very lush, and nice landscaping - makes you feel like you are in your vey own oasis, which is how one should feel while on vacation.

<Author>lynachka
<Content>Nice Stay- Probably wouldnt return My husband and I stayed at the Intercontinental for 7 days, Sept. 17-23 for our anniversary. We didnt have to wait too long to check in and we upgraded to a ocean front room for $150 extra. Here is my honest review: When I saw our ocean front room I was shocked by how much they charge regular price for it. There were tons of ants in the bathroom. I had to call housekeeping a couple of times to spray the bathroom. There was mold everywhere. Rooms are dingy. Old carpets. Old furniture. I would never pay full price for this room. The actual hotel grounds were ok. Pool was clean. The Beach was AMAZING. The water was perfect and the sand clean, hardly any rocks. We really got to relax. I must also point out that we visited during Peak Hurricane Season so there were hardly any people staying at the hotel. Next to the pool, there must have been 10 people the entire week. If your'e going during high season, the pool area is pretty small and I can see it crowding really easily. The food at the hotel was BLAH. You're better off going across the street to Mi Casita for breakfast (will cost you $15.00 rather than $50.00 at the hotel). Dinners are VERY expensive. We spent an average of $140 every night just for dinner. Lunch runs about $45.00 for two people - and we dont eat a lot. So food is extremely pricey unless you want to eat fried fast food for the week. Wendy's Burger King, KFC, Taco Bell, Pizza Hut, all across the street. We ate mostly at the El San Juan Hotel. That hotel looked absolutely beautiful. Food was amazing at Koco, The Palm and Yamato. If I was to go back to San Juan, I would probably try staying at the El San Juan. It was way more modern than the Intercontinental. Overall, unless you are getting a GREAT deal at this hotel, I would recommend choosing another one. They really need to fully clean and maintain their rooms, not just their outside property.  
<Date>Sep 25, 2008

<Author>LauraTheExplorerNyc
<Content>The Intercontinental Rocks! We had a room overlooking the beach. Upon arrival, there was a piece of chocolate cake in our room because my birthday would occur during our stay. The first night we walked on the beach right off the hotel and watched a beautiful sunset. Every day we swam up to the bar IN THE POOL and had drinks (cappuccino colada!!!) and the best chicken quesadillas! One day I hung my bathing suit on the balcony to dry, and a gust of wind made it fall below to a rooftop ten floors below our room. My fiance (well, back then he was a mere boyfriend but we since got engaged!!!) went down to the concierge to ask for help, and minutes later a maintanance worker was sent to rescue my bathing suit and he promptly brought it to our room. Another time I left my watch near the pool to go for a swim, and one of the pool boys must have thought I left it there and took it to the lost and found. When we inquired about the watch, they were very helpful and the concierge even made me prove that the watch was mine before he handed it back to me.At the hotel's recommendation, we celebrated my birthday at Pamela's, a beautiful restaurant right on the beach. It was so romantic and delicious. We loved the Intercontinental and would recommend it to anyone who likes to swim up to their bar and hang their bathing suits to dry on the balcony. We'll be back!

<Author>t4me2
<Content>Wonderful Hotel I just returned from Puerto Rico where I stayed at the InterContinental Hotel  Resort; we were there from 09/10/08 to 09/15/08. The hotel and staff are wonderful. Upon our arrival from the airport (which is literally a 7 minute drive), Jose checked us in. We'd originally reserved and paid for a regular room. I asked Jose about upgrading and he offered us a suite on the 16th floor (top) for an excellent price. The suite was #1600 and was nicely laid out and very roomy. It included an average size bedroom that opened to very spacious living and dining rooms. The suite had 2 full baths (both could stand to be a little larger). They were both nicely decorate with marble. There was a small kitchen area off of the living room that had a small sink and a mini-refrigerator but no microwave which was a little disappointing (there's certainly enough counter and cabinet space for one). The suite had 3 balconies that provided a beautiful ocean view. The balconies are only large enough to stand but were realy nice to have. We didn't do much in terms of sight seeing. We went to Old San Juan one day to visit the Forts which was nice. We were given great advice about how to get there and what to do from Nestor at the concierge desk. He was very knowledge and took the time to explain everything. We ate at Ruth's Chris ( which is right in the hotel) one night which we love and do on a regular basis when we're home. It was good and although pricey it was comparable to what we normally pay. We made reservations for the Japanese restaurant but didn't go because we'd had a late lunch and were not hungry. We went to Mi Casita (which is right across the street) for breakfast a couple of days and for dinner one night. The breakfasts were good and cheap and the seafood paella was wonderful and inexpensive as well. There are a number of other places to eat accross the street (Burger King, Church's Chicken, Baskin Robbins, a taco place) and a supermarket that wasn't very well stocked but did have beer and water. We spent a great deal of time in the casino and on the beach. The casino at the InterContinental was OK; however, we preferred the one up the street at the El San Juan hotel. The beach was OK, nothing tropical or beautiful. It certainly doesn't compare to the beaches in other parts of the Caribbean; it's more like a city beach; nothing special or breathtaking. All-in-all, our trip to Puerto Rico was OK. It was nice to get away to a place that I'd never been before but it certainly didn't satisfy to desire to be on a beatuiful tropical island and beach.  
<Date>Sep 16, 2008

<Author>suzieboston
<Content>3 stars at best. We had problems, but management did come through for us. I stayed at the IC San Juan in early September. I love Puerto Rico (this was my 5th hotel stay in PR in a year and a half) and was thrilled to bring along a friend who hadn been before. We chose the IC because we found a really great deal online. I had been in a lobby a few times and it seemed nice. I wasn't scared away by a few negative reviews on Tripadvisor, but perhaps I should I have been.We encountered cleanliness issues in our room, and service issues in general. To give some specifics, we encountered a dirty carpet full of dust bunnies under the furniture, hair left in the shower, mold in the bathroom, half-hearted daily housekeeping, and a soiled bathrobe. Room service screwed up in several ways (waking me up before 7 am to verify my order which I placed the night before, then getting the order wrong anyway, and serving it cold). Waiters at the pool literally never came by, though we did see them, so we would eventually give up and get our own food and drinks. It was frustrating, but Irene, the club manager, did set things right for us, comping the room service and adding a few other nice touches. So, while we encountered annoyances, all forgiven. She was extremely professional. Like most nearby resorts, they nickel and dime you; prepare to pay for everything. The best bet is to stock up on water, sunscreen, and snacks at the Walgreens right down the street. The gift shop has cheaper water than the bottles in the room if you need it. (FYI, there's no complimentary water in the gym except the old-fashioned communal water fountain; they will sell you a Gatorade for $3.)On the plus side, the hotel has a nice location on the beach, a good pool, a swim-up bar with great bartenders, and a decent gym. The waiter on the beach (not poolside) did come around often enough. The gentleman who sets up chairs and umbrellas on the beach, Jose, was very friendly.Because management took the time to hear my concerns and fix the problems, I can give this place a less than three stars, though it's really more like a 2.5 out of 5. I wish I didn have to take time out of my stay to complain, which I don like to do. I think part of the problem may have been that it was a generally slow season but a busier holiday weekend, thus they may have had more people than the staff could handle. I also feel like the IC is an upscale chain, but this particular IC is not like other Intercontinentals. This IC thinks it a 4-star hotel but operates more like a 3-star. A better choice in the same price range is the Courtyard Marriot Isla Verde, which is not as fancy a hotel (no high end steakhouse, no opulent lobby) but absolutely excels in its class and has great service and better food. As for Ruth's Chris, I have now eaten there twice and am not impressed at all. You can get less awkward service and similar quality cooking at the Outback, but if you want to splurge, go the BLT Steak . I've probably eaten there at least 10 times and each time it's perfect.  
<Date>Sep 14, 2008

<Author>miamiskyboy
<Content>Beautifull Property - Terrible Service This resort leaves a lot to be desired. The place is very, very old. The lobby and public areas have been somewhat re-done. But not to the standards of Intercontinental property's in the US. Check in was a breeze, courteous, and very efficient. Except that I was charged an additional resort tax and fees that where never mentioned when I booked my reservation. A resort fee at a resort that charges a fortune for water in your room, charges for everything. So not sure what the resort fee is for.My room was dated, worn, and torn. The furniture was very old rattan and wood. The french door with mirrors for the bathroom was very 1980. The A/C was loud and did not cool to well. Carpets where frayed, stained and torn. Not the room that you would expect at an Intercontinental Hotel. It was actually a Jr. Suite with a separate bedroom and living room. Old style box televisions and no mini-bar, no robes, no upgraded amenities. I faces the lagoon. My friend had a room facing the ocean (#820). Those rooms have plasma TV;s and upgraded furniture and bedding. But the rooms (mine was #821) with odd numbers that face the lagoon are old school. Make sure u make it clear ar check in that you want one of the newer rooms.Turndown service is a joke. Its not included automatically. You have to request it. All the do is come in and close curtains. That's it. No chocolate, no refreshing of room. no extra towels. Nothing. Why even offer turndown service if they are not going to do it the right way ?Pool area is absolutely amazing. What a nice pool and bar area. I really enjoyed that part of my stay. Except that the hotel has this crazy policy about (1) single pool towel per guest. You have to sign for it, get a bracelet, the whole thing is in convenient and more Cancun all inclusive $79 a night hotel then 5 star resort. I mean at almost $400 a night on average here. You expect a certain level of service.The chaise lounges have comfy blue cushions on them. But they are all dirty, old, mildewy . and stained. You need (1) towel to cover them and then (1) towel for yourself. There are no bar attendants that come to you. You have to go to bar yourself and get your orders in. Drinks are expensive and taste terrible. Spa was ok. I had a massage with a male therapist. He was good. But they cheated me out of 5 min of my service. He finished earlier. This is not honest and not right. I was upset. But they did not seem to care. The girl at the desk did give me a 5% off for my inconvenience. But an apology would of been better then 5% off. The spa has a relaxation area with bottles of water and tea. But there is no sugar for the tea, no honey, and nothing to stir the tea with. When I asked or honey or sugar. I was told they had none ???Breakfast at Alfredo's is cheap at only $22. When you consider the variety and quality of the food. Its a good deal and the selection is fantastic. I did the buffet every morning and highly recommend it. But the service from the wait staff was mediocre at best. They where slow and no responsive to guest needs.At check out. I had an early flight. I tried to check out the night before. I was told at 12AM that I could not do that because system was in audit to do it in the morning, I tried at 5AM to check out. Again was told that they would charge all to my Credit Card on file. They could not take my cash because they where in Audit. I waited until 5:30AM and almost missed my flight. I had to leave there without being able to pay in cash and they charged my Credit Card. This is not fair as I intended to pay in cash. If this where like any other Intercontinental in the US. This would of never happened. Hotel is in a great location and right on the ocean. If you get a good deal on hotwire or priceline then I guess its ok. But DO NOT pay the rates on intecontinental.com. You will be sorry !!!

<Author>Nico1974
<Content>2.5 stars Masqerading as a 4 Not a 4 star in my book, but of course this is always subjective to the travelers expectations and perhaps mine were just too high. I recently stayed at Intercontinental San Juan Resort and was thoroughly disappointed. We were not told when you book the room that they will charge a hold on your credit card of $100.00 per night for incidential fee for each day that you stay. The pool chair cushions had numerous stains  bird feces. The streets needed repairs, there were abandon buildings in the area, your local homeless people  only one authentic Puerto Rician restaurant in the area. Overall, the hotel and staff was nice and the room was just okay..nothing spectacular. The beach, due to storms and inclimate weather conditions had massive seaweed and ocean debris and look extremely unpleasing to swim in. Pretty scenery, but way too much seaweed. I did not appreciate the hotel adding a 15% gratuity to every purchase that was made to my bill without my consent and or initial knowledge. The pool consistently had leaves from the overhead trees in it  were not cleaned out to my knowledge hourly. The pool area did not have any music  there was minimal night life in the existing area. The communication between staff members was appalling  non existent. The cab rides/fares fluxuated $2-4 per every ride to same destinations. the cabbies are supposed to work in zones, but we discovered that some drivers are dishonest to tourists because they don't think they know any better. I found this part to be very frustrating. On the hotel premises you are not allowed to bring outside food to their pool area only out to the public beach are you able to eat outside food. They want you to eat and drink from their restaurants on site. the water in our room had turned luke warm for about an hour and the water pressure in the shower was terrible. All the food is very pricey. Everyday we had to call the front desk to have them send up towels and washclothes. I am extremely disappointed and dissatisfied with my hotel stay and will not be a Hotwire consumer due to this negative hotel experience.  
<Date>Sep 9, 2008

<Author>Maedog
<Content>Great stay!! When we went to check-in, the very nice desk clerk upgraded my husband  I to an ocean view room due to low occupancy (low season in P.R.). The room itself was lovely and very clean (the view was gorgeous!). Every staff member we encountered was very helpful and polite. Several restaurants are located within the Intercontinental but we did not try them due to lack of time. The small bar downstairs is adequate for drinks  the casino is nice if you like to gamble. The bar food is laughably overpriced and if you are remotely adventurous, hoof it to the Taco Bell for some late night food (about 2 blocks down on Isla Verde Avenue). There are also two Walgreens on Isla Verde Avenue, so you can easily pick up water etc. on your trip. If you drive, the parking lot is across the street for $16 dollars a day. Make sure you ask the desk clerk for the paper pass to put in your car.

<Author>CrazySammi
<Content>It was great! My fiancee and I spent our first vacation in a city view room at the Intercontinental. I have no serious complaints! The first night I got there, I didn't really like the area, as there are a FEW abandoned businesses around. By the second night, the area had intoxicated me! It's so charming, clean (you could go barefoot) and everyone is so pleasant. ***Hotel PROS  CONS***I can't even think of any serious complaints. The restaurants were pricey? But the food was delish. We booked trips through the hotel, they cleaned our room as long as we left the sign on the door, the AC was comfortable, there was a mini-fridge, cofeemaker...Ok, yeah the TV sucked but we weren't really on vacation to watch TV! Balcony was small, but we weren/t on vacation to stay on our balcony either.***Beach PROS CONS***PROS:-not a ton of annoying noisy kids around, but there are more at the pool-water is turquoise(but not crystal clear)-water is calm-parasailing and jet skis activities availableCONS:-some may be annoyed by the airplanes (I only noticed them 2 or 3x during our 4 day stay, and we spent hoursssssss on the beach[and I am sensitive to noise)Restaurants we went to:Mi Casita: is right across the street and the food was DELICOUS, even though the service was a little slow. A meal there will run you about $30-$50Platos: A little more pricey. They serve a Paella that can feed at least SIX grown men for $45. I think it's a recurrign theme for relaxed Islands like PR- the service was a little slow.Lupis: DISGUSTING! The meal came out to just over $50, yet made Taco Bell look like a freaken' gourmet restaurant. Def. a tourist trap.For daytime fun: We booked a day catamaran trip through our hotel for $88? per person. Pros: (for day trip)-Our first stop was at Icacos, an AMAZING deserted island whose waters were crystal clear. Seriously, you could see like every grain of sand on the ocean floor-Yummy food-Energetic staffCons: -Catamaran shelter leaked when it started raining-we didnt' spend nearly enough time at Icacos, but spent more time on Culebra (?) whose waters had more interesting fish but murkier water-Catamaran bathroom was nasty, no airfreshner, and sinks with no running water.The area had a Walgreens which was 4 minutes away. Whatever we ran out of or needed, was a 4 minute walk away at Walgreens If you want to save money, get some $3 coolers from there and get some water and cold cuts. You can get the same souveniers they sell in the souvenir shops for less than half the price.Next time we may rent a car so we can explore a bit more, but there are so many amazing things to do in that area.

<Author>Sarah475
<Content>We had a good trip .. We stayed at the Intercontinental for 5 nights and we really did not have any problems. I know there are some awful reviews on here, but we had a mostly good experience. Hotel: We were given a room when we arrived and there was no waiting. It was next to the elevator and we asked to be moved, which we were immediately and the receptionist was really nice about it. We were moved to a bigger room with a couch and table, large fridge and comfy bed. It was clean! And the maid service was great - we always had clean towels. We also had no problems with the elevators being slow, never once did we have to wait long for one. One morning there was some banging when something was being fixed, but it didnt start until 9.30 am and wasn't a problem. Your not going to PR to hang out in your room! Ours faced the street which was also quite nice, you get a view of the city. Restaurants: The food at the hotel is great - yes it is a bit pricey but if you're looking for a budget holiday you should stay elsewhere. All the restaurants in the hotel were very good, as was the poolside bar and grill. Drinks are the same price as any hotel on a beach ($10 - 12) - and they tasted good! There is the strip of shops across the road, but the food was so so. Theres a subway and several fast food places. Mi casita and Gelo were ok for breakfast, but a warning, you end up smelling of the grill if you go to these places, it is very strong, so dont wear your best outfits there. The coffee ar Mi casita was probably the worst cup I have ever had - just to warn you. PR coffee is amazing but try it elsewhere. We also tried outback steakhouse down the road and it was below par, not up to the usual standards. Ruth Chris's in the hotel is very very good, my favorite. Alfredos is also good - the breakfast buffet was very nice ($22 each). Beach and Pool: This is what you go to San Juan for!! The beach was beautiful and clean - as was the pool. Lovely blue water. A fantastic place to relax. There are always loads of chairs to choose from, never full. And plenty of unbrellas. If they start packing up the beach at 5.30 pm you can just move over to the pool, its 5 feet away. You get wrist bands too and security seemed very good. You can hire an umbrella on the beach for $5 and a guy sets it up for you. The sun is very strong so wear sunblock! There's a walgreens up the street with everything you need and we got drinks and snacks here too. We had 5 minutes of rain for the whole week - weather was fantastic. Surounding area: The area around the hotels is a bit sad and run down. It is NOT a resort outside the hotel, so if you are looking for that, I suggest you stay elsewhere. Old San Juan is lovely, really worth the trip and we ate at Barrachina which was wonderful. The sangria and pina coladas were so so good. There are lots of cute stores and beautiful buldings. Cab costs $21 to get there. It was very hot in San Juan, so we went later in the day and it was better. Many stores close at 5.30pm but the restaurants are open much later. This hotel is near the airport - so you see and hear some planes. It did not bother us at all and was not loud. Again if this bothers you - stay on another part of the island. Cab from the airport is $14.Casinos: This is not vegas, nor should it be. There are slots and tables, plenty in each hotel if you want to gamble a bit. The machines are on the older side, but it was fun. The hotel next door - El san Juan has a larger casino, but I thought that hotel was tacky and somewhat creepy. The lobby has lots of bars and there is a starbucks there if you need one. All in all we had a great vacation - but make sure you have the right expectations. This is a place to relax, get a suntan and lay on the beach. If you're looking for a glitzy activity packed vacation you'll probably be a bit disappointed here. But we loved relaxing and found this hotel to be pretty good. I would go back, but perhaps would try another part of the island. The Intercontinental is the best hotel in this area from what we saw - so I would recommend it. It may not be as good as some other intercontinentals but it gets a B+ from me. I have definitely had some bad hotel experiences in the past, but lucky for us, this was not bad at all.  
<Date>Aug 23, 2008

<Author>Tulips2765
<Content>Excellent Resort Just got back from a 7day 6 night vacation with my husband and teenage daughter. The hotel met and exceeded my expectations. All the employees we encountered were polite and very helpful. We arrived Sunday night and received lots of tips from Jesus who works 3 to 11pm. We found the room to be nice and clean. The bed was wonderful. We stayed on the 15th floor after receiving an upgrade and had a spectacular ocean/pool view. The room was cleaned everyday. We took the advice of previous travelers and didn't eat at the hotel restaurants. We ate breakfast across the street at MiCasitas, good food and even better prices. We found the area surrounding the hotel to be nice and safe to walk all hours day or night. We walked to several restaurants for dinner, Metropol being our favorite. There are taxi's located outside the hotel for your convenience. We took a cab to Old San Juan, it was wonderful and culturally rich. We went to Old Morro (The Fort) then we had Mollorcas and Puerto Rican coffee at La Bombanero (recommended by Rachel Ray). It was delicious. The cab ride roundtrip was $42.00. We went to the rainforest and the views were breathtaking, it is a nice hike, so wear comfortable shoes. The waterfall inside is beautiful. We ate at a road side Kisok, the rice and beans were delicious. On the tour, we were provided with lots of information about the Island and its history. Great tour, provided through the hotel. We also took a trip to Plaza Las Americas, the big mall there, very nice, there are upscale and regular stores throughtout. It is very large.We found getting around by taxi very efficient and they are readily available. All in all, we had a wonderful time and would go back in a heart beat.

<Author>GAPCHPANTHER
<Content>Do Not Stay at The InterContinental San Juan - Not worth the money..... I recently stayed at Intercontinental San Juan Resort and was thoroughly disappointed. I am familiar with the hotel brand and expected alot more from the hotel. I arrived at 5pm on 08/02/08. My room was not ready. My room was not available until after 8pm. My reservation was for a Laguna View and was made back on May 3. I received a regular room with no explanation. Upon entering the room, I noticed the bathroom was filthy. The bath tub was dirty and the bath mats were dirty as well. The refrigerator was molded and stained. The comforter was stained. I dropped a pen beside the bed and night table. When I leaned down to pick it up, there were old cookies in the floor that apparently had never been cleaned up. I was thoroughly disgusted. I didn't even unpack. I immediately went downstairs and asked for a manager. The front desk told me there was no manager available. I explained to her the situation and told her if that was best your hotel could offer at your prices I would rather find another hotel. She just stood there looking at me like I was crazy. She then told me I would have to pay for a night stay and a 100.00 penalty even though I received none of what I paid for. We stayed and our stay continued to get worse. Housekeeping left one towel an one washcloth for two people. We asked for extra towels for the next day. When they cleaned they took the extra towels we requested. The towels left were stained. While we were on the beach a worker comes over to us and tells us they start collecting the beach chairs at 5:30. The sun is still up and if you are paying $200 plus a night you should be able to stay until sunset at least. I will never stay there again.I previously stayed at the Howard Johnson and Embassy Suite much better rates, cleaner, and better staff.

<Author>tropicsnme
<Content>Better than I dreamed it could be! Just spent 5 days at this beautiful hotel with my family. The entire experience was relaxing, pampering and very classy.Every employee we encountered was polite and helpful; restaurants are amazing, pool and beach are pristine; spa services were spectacular. Had great weather days and an excursion to sail and snorkel was awesome. The negative reviews I had read before the trip must have come from people who weren't prepared to act and spend like a four diamond guest at a four diamond hotel--you get what you pay for and everything was worth it. Sure, you can save some money eating across the street at the fast food joints; but while on vacation, why not experience the new? The bus ride to Senor Frogs was dicey but spend the money on the cab--you'll get there faster and with less stress. There is never a wait for pool/beach chairs, restaurants, taxis. The drinks are a little pricey and weak but if you stick to the 32 ouncers, (like the voodoo!) you get your money's worth. Restaurants have an amazing wine/specialty drink menu.Take the leap and make this your next vacation spot--you'll have a great time.  
<Date>Aug 10, 2008

<Author>nytraveler17
<Content>Great Place to Stay I have stayed in this hotel twice, both for 4-5 day getaways. It's super convenient to the airport (5 minutes away) and San Juan is easy to get to from the east coast. Perfect for a quick beach trip. This hotel, in my opinion is an excellent choice for just such a vacation.Staff is friendly, helpful, and responsive. We had a very good experience in all of our interactions with them.The facility is very well maintained with the feel of an upscale beach resort. Casino is decent sized and has a good variety of tables and machines. It's not Vegas of course but it will fit the bill if you are looking to gamble. I was generally able to find a spot at a $5 blackjack table. The rooms are spacious and well decorated. However, I concur with the other reviewers that the walls can be kind of thin, hopefully you get good neighbors. The bed was comfortable and our room was cleaned well daily, no problems with maid service.Hotel restaurants are good, Ruth's Chris makes a mouth watering steak and the breakfast buffet, while not cheap, was well done. The beach is great, spacious and uncrowded. We loved it! The pool here is top notch, plenty of space and chairs both shady and sunny. The bar also makes good drinks (although really pricey). The hotel has efficient and plentiful security. The neighborhood of Isla Verde is fine to walk around in both the days and evenings. There isn't a ton of stuff around though. If you are looking for a neighborhood with more restaurants and nightlife you might be better off going to the Condado area of San Juan. Overall, I would return and recommend this as a quality place to stay in San Juan.

<Author>brownsugamd
<Content>Absolutely Enjoyed It!!! My boyfriend and I have been planning our wonderful romantic get a way about 4 months in advance, after much reviews from tripadvisor, travelocity and everything else i could find we finally decided to travel to San Juan. It was a quick flight for both of us and we knew we wanted to stay somewhere fun and yet romantic at the same time. We choose to stay in Isla Verde and Im glad we did. All the beaches in P.R. are public and this particular beach, is lined with a strip of hotels. Upon arrival to intercontinental we were greeted by HELPFUL, sweet and really nice bell hops and service guys. We arrived early before check in which is 4 pm. They took our bags, allowed us to check in, and use their facilities while we waited for our room to get ready. We strolled the hotel, which is beautiful. It has an amazing pool and jacuzzi, a spa, 24 gym, and the beach is right in the backyard. There are many restaurants to eat at.Now at Intercontinental, im sure you can book the cheapest room and have the same experience. We purchased a laguna room and we face the front of the city towards san juan. You can see the city lights and sky at night from our balcony. This time of year seems to be tropical rainy season, which we had for the first 2-3 days but it doesnt last long, usually at night, and even if it kinda ruin your plans for the day, your room and the hotel is a great place to stay. We didnt eat much here at the hotel because we know it is expensive, but this ave is a strip full of hotels and shopping area. Right across the street there is a little center. There is ponderosa food (which is kinda like a buffet salad bar, finger food type place), lins chinese which is excellent, and this puerto rican home cooked style place called Mi Casita, which my bf and I particular loved, the food is great and the price is reaaaallllyyy cheap. We had breakfast 1 morning, and it was only $12 for the both of us, they give you really good food and the right portion. They are open from 7am-10pm, most places here close @ 11pm so make sure you eat according to time. There is also wendy's, burger king, a little supermarket, a walgreens a few blocks down, (make a right when you exit the hotel in front entrance).For night life, we went from hotel to hotel. Intercontinental is classy and sophisticated, but if you need a dj, bar, lounges and music, head to El San Juan Hotel, which is left from intercontinental. They have a huge hotel lobby which is fun and exciting, the dj plays music and there is also a house band for a more local experience. There is also lounges and alot of bars, dress to impress at these places.To the right of intercontinental, at the water club approx 2-3 blocks down, then a sharp right.. there is a restaurant called Tangerine/ Liquid. And a roof top sushi bar on the 17th foor, open roof that overlooks the ocean. Prices are ok. There is also local shops, bars, grills and other places on this avenue. For a Local experience, head to old san juan. We took the bus, it was just like a NYC bus. 0.75 cents to the last stop takes you to the bus terminal downtown. Be prepared to walk. We walked the tourist area where the cruise ships dock and also made our way to the historic sites, by the forts which was $3.00 per person to enter, definitely worth it because it was fun and you get a great view of San Juan.El Yunque Rainforest is a must. There is a half day trip from 9:30am-3pm. Its $57.00 a person through the hotel. The tour guide picks you up, gives you a tour while driving, a cave trip, history of P.R., rainforest info, and waterfall treats. This rainforest is about a 1.5 hr trip. Alot of walking, defintiely a cardiovascular workout, uphill and downhill through the forest, very beautiful and romantic .. a must see.. we stopped for lunch at a local place right by the rainforest for what i thought was some of the best P.R. food ever, definitely try the beans and rice with fried chicken and sweet plaintains, ($1.00 items -$6.00) other packages include 3 trips, the rainforest, beach and a nite rafting trip, supposedly the water illuminates in the nite while you boat near the forest. Food on the Hotel: we ate by the beach, at Splash , mostly wraps, finger foods, salads.. good food. drinks and food from $12. other than that, we didnt do much, the casino is not as big as some other hotels but if you dont like to gamble much like me, its ok.You can hotel hop, and no one I.D.'s you , you can enjoy the facilities everywhere. overall this was a great experience and i hope if others are like me, i hope this helped. I thought the service was great, the customer service was excellent, we never had a problem and if we did they were more than happy to help us, very friendly and CLEAN.. our rooms were cleaned everyday with new towels and linens. coffee maker, ice bucket, fridge, safe, iron, alarm clock (ipod home) and cable t.v. in room. official website and pics are accurate.. a beautiful experience!! and complimentary wireless internet from every room which i am submitting this review since we are leaving tomorrow :)we didnt rent a car but if you feel you need too, the hotel has an avis hook up in the lobby where you can get , if you need to or change your mind 24hr rental for about $40 .

<Author>shoutlouder
<Content>Great long weekend at the Intercontinental! Spent a long weekend in July at the Intercontinental San Juan and had a wonderful time. It is in the Isla Verde area which is the right location if you're looking for a relaxing beach vacation with easy access to activities and other parts of San Juan.The hotel grounds are beautiful with a large pool area. Never had much trouble finding chairs because there are so many to go around. Security is superb here. You need wristbands (a different one each day) to even enter the pool area. Your name is looked up on a list, and if the pool attendants find any discrepancies - they call the front desk to verify. This was very impressive. The beach area, footsteps away from the pool, is gorgeous and not terribly crowded. There is no problem finding a nice spot to lay out, and beach chairs and umbrellas are always available. Walk down the beach towards the El San Juan to take part in fun water activities like jet skiing and parasailing.A main point to be noted is the staff at the Intercontinental is exceptionally friendly and helpful! Every request is met with a smile and a cheerful my pleasure. My only complaint is with the maid service. Yes our room was made up every day, but not completely. The coffee maker was never cleaned out, sugar packets never refilled, and we were never left with more than one new fresh towel unless we requested more. Still, this was the only annoyance we really had with the staff and the hotel in general and would definitely return if we visit PR again!  
<Date>Aug 1, 2008

<Author>NortonBNorton
<Content>Just so-so I used trip advisor review as a major part of my decision to stay at the Intercontinental, as well as a friends recommendation. We had stayed at the Ritz previously. I booked an ocean view rm and the price at the time of my stay was approx 400+ dollars plus the daily resort fee. We arrived around 1 pm and did have to wait for the normal check in time. Our room was gorgeous and had a great view. However, the walls were literally paper thin. Every day I would go up to the room around noon and there were children in the room directly next to us, they were singing and jumping on the beds, throwing objects against the wall and so on. This would go on until early evening, I never saw them, or an adult. I found that very strange. The beach was very nice but you had to reserve and pay for an umbrella. The pool area was nice, just small. The weather was very hot and very bright, no complaints. I think the one thing that really really surprised me was the cost of food there. Make no mistake, it might as well be Hawaii or the caribbean. Lunch at the beach restaurant for two daily was over $50 and we are talking pizza or salads. I was very disappointed in the housekeeping, very hit or miss. Some days I had to call after 4pm as they had not been there and we really needed at least more towels so we could get ready for dinner. We ate at Ruth Chris as well as the Palm and the food was very good but very very expensive. The hotel Italian restaurant was very good, very very expensive. I would guess each meal was close to $200 for two. The elevators were very hit and miss as well and as I read reviews today, I wonder why that problem cannot be fixed.some days only one elevator and it is a long wait. So I guess I would end my review by saying this hotel never lived up to my expectations, perhaps I had set them too high?The casino was very sad, very few machines and it seems there are no rules as to dress and behavior. I saw many many people eating food they had obviously brought from home -it just did not add to a resort atmosphere. Did gamble at the El San Juan, just lovely and what a beautiful lobby and bar area.  
<Date>Jul 31, 2008
<Rating>2	2	2	4	3	2	2	3

<Author>MomOf2Atlanta
<Content>Intercontinental Staff Is Awesome! IBar staff Rocks! Wonderful Time! What an amazing vacation!! Puerto Rico is wonderful! The people were very friendly and happy. They really seemed to be proud of their home. Living in such a beautiful place , I can understand why. The Intercontinental is a beautiful hotel. It's not far from the airport, so you can start your vacation immediately and stay until the last possible minute. The beach was gorgeous. The staff at the hotel were all extremely helpful and friendly. The staff at the IBar were especially great. David, one of the bartenders, is terrific! I was on a girls trip with my friend (no husbands or kids) and the staff really made us feel welcomed and at ease. The excursion to the Rainforest was wonderful. Make sure to ask for Hector's tour. He was very knowledgeable and fun too. The snorkeling trip to Culebra was awesome too. The concierge booked everything for us. It was a wonderful, worry free vacation. I will be back as soon as I can. I enjoyed every minute of it!Marsha -Atlanta, GA

<Author>downunder1975
<Content>Superior service We had a great time at this hotel. The wonderful experience started from the first minute we pulled up in the taxi. We were met with some of the friendliest and most helpful staff we have experienced in all our travels. Everyone we interacted with (front desk, conceirge, door staff, bell staff, pool people, waiters, etc.) treated us extremely well and really made the experience. Even Socorro at the Avis counter in the hotel was extremely helpful!Our Club Intercontinental room was right by the pool, gym and spa. We apprecited the additional privacy and ability to walk right out to the pool area and the beach. The furnishings were a tasteful Caribbean motif (no over the top sea foam green and flamingo pink) with a lot of tropical wood. The onlyissues were that the sliding glass door was hard to open and close, the walls were a little on the thin side if you have really loud talkers (we have those neighbors for one day) and the ceiling in the bathroom was a little low. We used the gym. It was one of the nicest hotel gyms we have ever used. Everything was new.We did have our last lunch at the hotel's Japanese offering, Momoyama. The Pepper Tuna appetizer was amazing. The rest of the sushi was good, but nothing spectular. The staff was, again, extremely friendly.We loved this hotel and will definitely stay there the next time we are in San Juan.

<Author>colaivar
<Content>Honeymoon Location I stayed at the Intercontinental last week for my honeymoon from 7/14 to 7/20. The hotel was very nice with many amenities to keep you busy. With so much to do in Puerto Rico we did not completely use all the features they provided. Please note: things are pretty pricey at the Intercontinental but there are very affordable places to eat right across the street such as Mi Casita (Puerto Rican food), Burger King, Ponderosa.We were so facintated with other places along the island such as El Morro in Old San Juan, Ponce, and even took a day trip to Culebra Island to see one of the most stunning beaches I've ever seen in Flamenco Beach. It would be a waste to come all the way to Puerto Rico and not see everything it has to offer.Overall the hotel was very nice and accommodating. I would definitly be back next year to celebrate my one year anniversary.

<Author>andytevez
<Content>Excellent trip for little kids The wife and I just returned from a late June one week stay. Kids are 3 and 5. Pool is great for kids that age and pool very nice, clean and accessible. No seaweed anywhere and I'm assuming that when it does accumulate it's after a storm and the hotel would clean it up promptly. Service was great except for the concierge and we had no problems with housekeeping. And yes we got the free upgrade but I think that was possible because there were available rooms and it was low season - I wouldn't count on it at different times of the year.We booked the trip through Costco - all very smooth and the breakfast special they get you is great. If you have kids go to El Morro in Old San Juan on a cloudy day and fly kites for a day - easiest kite flying conditions you'll ever have due to the wind -- and you can buy kites there for $3-$4. Also, the hotel based Avis lady gave me a great tip on where to eat near Luquillo Beach -- try the Kiosko #2 La Parilla if you like seafood ! That beach is about 45 minutes away and is beautiful to be sure but extremely hot hot hot and zero wave action.The hotel and facilities were great and I'd recommend the place to somebody with little kids but to help you manage your expectations I've listed some negatives below.Negatives:1) the 3 elevators servicing 16 floors were unreliable and kind of a pain but most of the guests took it well so it was a running joke.2) the concierge(s) were useless and actually gave bad information. For example, I told them that I'd be taking the kids to Old San Juan and asked them if it would be easy to find some simple food for them there -- like a pizza. They said there were no such choices and instead directed me to an Italian sit down restaurant and a Caribean themed restaurant. When I went anyway and went to the center of town - the Plaza de Armas - I found myself surrounded by familiar kids places - mcdonalds, wendy's, burger king, etc. This would lead me to conclude that the concierges get compensated for directing people to specific places. They also gave me misinformation about the trip to Culebra Island. The concierge you see in hotel website video must have retired or something.3) if you read reviews about the local, nearby restaurants be forewarned. The Mi Casita restaurant is close and may be good but it's always packed for dinner so don't expect to just walk over. Also, the Fast Food places near the hotel are the slowest I've ever experienced - the Burger King was stunning in it's tortoise pace, and we left after waiting for 15 minutes in a line that didn't move. The Wendy's was slightly faster. The workers were nice enough but totally inefficient. So dinners are a problem unless you drive elsewhere.Avoid:Rain forest excursion - It's 1 hour there, 1 hour back and then 90 minutes in a bus through the forest with a little 20 minutes walk. Total waste of time and I wish I had driven there myself and walked around on my own. I guess if you can't walk or are drunk from a cruise the excursion might make sense but otherwise it's a waste.  
<Date>Jul 15, 2008

<Author>blueridgeVirginia
<Content>All in All a Great Time We stayed at the Intercontinental from 7/8 through 7/12. I had a package that included the breakfast buffet and a tour of the rain forest. I was travelling with my husband, two young kids and my father - so clearly it was mixed company. However, all of us had a great time there. The overall experience was sublime. So here are my thoughts:1) Hotel Beach and pool: The Pool is fabulous ..it has a swim up bar, jacuzzi, and several waterfalls. The water is as deep as as 61/2 feet and as shallow as 3. I would just sit under the waterfall and get a water massage. There were plenty of seats/cabanas at the pool. The beach too is nice. There was a bit ofseaweed but nothing out of control. You can rent an umbrella for the beach but we just found a palm tree and moved our seats under it. The waves can be a bit rough at times so those with small children should be careful but my 9 and 7 year had way too much fun.2) Food: We had our very first meal there at Mi Casita across the street. Very friendly and reasonably priced. I did try the mofongo. The filling was fabulous but the mofongo itself is a quite bland (not the reataurants fault ..just the way it is). I found the food to be pricey in PR overall not too many mid priced choices. We did eat at Ruth's Chris in the hotel one day which was wonderful. As for my other favorite place it was Tantra in OSJ. We ate at Barrachina in Isla Verde as it came so highly recommended by everyone. Maybe we did not order the right things or the one in OSJ is better..but this was my only really bad food experience. It just was not that special compared to what you were paying. I had ordered a Nacho Platter and it was the worst I have had and I really cant imagine messing that up. As I mentioned we did the breakfast buffet. It was great and the all the wait staff is so nice.3) Transportation: We rented a car one day ..to go to the Bio bay. The driving wasn't too bad you just have to be a bit more vigilant and the road signage is not the greatest. But we dont have any horror stories to report there. We rented the car from the Avis right in the hotel and it was easy to be able to pick up and return the car right there. We also used the bus one day. Not bad, takes you through some bad areas but you are not going there so who cares. The bus is clean and air conditioned and only cost 75 cents to OSJ. One thing no one told us is they take exact change only..no bills allowed. 4) Sites we visited: El Yunque, fascinating but it was my least favorite. Bio Bay (vieques) we used East Wind Cats. Loved that though the time in the water was too short. El Morro, loved that too its an amazing structure a must see. OSJ is wonderful ..the most charming architecture and cute shops.My only issue at the hotel was that we originally did not get a room with a king bed though our reservation stated that. However the hotel upgraded us to an ocean view room with a king bed.Everyone in the hotel and PR was so nice, I was sad to leave.  
<Date>Jul 14, 2008

<Author>noahbrain
<Content>Not bad I chose this hotel for my girlfriend and I because it was close to the airport and close to San Juan. I made a good choice. I rented a car at the airport for $20 per day and drove to the hotel. We jumped in the ocean asap and was surprised that it was better than the reviews I had read. The beach was not outstanding, but it was warm and not crowded. The pool was nice, but smaller than I expected. The room was nice, eventhough we had a supersaver deal and they put us on a lower floor.The food was expensive, so the car came in handy to search out nice restauants. We drove to San Juan almost every night. San Juan has alot to offer, it was not a disappointment. All in all this was not a world class hotel, but it met my expectations. I would probably go back , given the opportunity.
