<Author>PRPrincess_8
<Content>Watch out for the Incidential Fees $100 per Day! No Warning I went on a family vacation, the hotel was nice, employees were nice, housekeeping came everyday, beach was beautiful, pool was pretty. Casino was small but when you can get a waitress they will gvie you free drinks and a hot sandwich! I had a city room over looking the main entrance. Comfortable beds, large towels, shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, shower cap, shoe shine cloth, soap. Iron, hair dryer, fridgem coffee machine. In room safe, cable TV.Only thing missing was a microwave.However, you are not told when you book the room that they will charge a hold on your credit card $100.00 incidential fee for each day that you stay. I had 2 rooms so that was $800.00! they put on hold. I tried to argue with them stating that they were tying up $$ that I was planing on using during my stay. I told them that I had booked it directly from Intercontential and there was no mention of this fee only the 22% tax and resort fee on top of your room fee. They went on to explain that that's what all the hotels do and there was nothing that they could do because when they put through you credit card it automatically adds the $100 a day. Needless to say my credit card was short a couple of hundred so it was not approved and I had to give them another credit card or cash for the difference or they could not give me the room! As I was checking out 4 young ladies were checking in and to their dismay they were being told about the $100/day inc. fee, they too had to scrabble for the extra cash or else they could not get the room. I will be calling the hotel's main office to put in a formal complaint regarding this practice. It should be disclosed so that customers know that they will need extra money to be floating in a hold until your trip is over.We had 2 blackouts while we were there, one that was pre- scheduled by the power company between 10 am -2pm. And another one unanounced at about 8 am and lasted an hour. I was disappointed with the area in general. I am of Puerto Rican descent and it pains me to see such an unkept area. The streets needed repairs, there were abandon buildings in the area, your local homeless people, only one authentic puerto rician restaurant in the area. No Puerto Rican bakeries, or Pastellio /Alcapuria places in the area. With all the five star hotels in the areas you would think that they would invest in the surrounding community so that more people would come back not only for their hotel but for the culture itself. Tip: When you get to the aiport look for the tourism kisko, they wear orange shirts and they will make you a ticket for a cab to take you to the hotel they give you a fair price from the airport. However you have to watch some of the cab drivers, some just charge you $1 per checked luggage and some will charge you for every piece of luggage or carry on baggage. Same about of bags, I paid $4.00 extra coming and $8.00 going. Overall, the hotel was nice, staff was nice, the beach was awesome- clear water, some waves (watch small children-waves are sometime rough), it was warm, no fish just some sand dollars, no shells in the water most days. Go early to get a free beach chair, once they are gone they rent chairs for $4.00 a day, but they take them back at 6 pm. , so be prepared to sit on the sand if you want to stay pas 6 pm. Pool has plenty of chairs and cabanas, water fall is cute, goes up to 6 '6. Several sections to hang out in. Use lots of sunscreen, sun doesn't feel that hot but you will get burned fast!Go to Mi Casita for Puerto Rican food, range $8.00-$24 for dinner. Go to Walgreens for water, soda, snacks, coffee, slurppies. Pueblo supermarket is behind Embassy Suite hotel about a 8 minute walk. Fast food, Church's Chicken is pretty good, there's a Pizza Hut that is good and clean. Burger King, Wendy's, KFC is also there. The mini mart across the street is not well stock but for an emergency they'll do. This is still mi Isla Bonita, they just need to spruce it up a bit. with the help of the surrounding hotels.  
<Date>Jul 8, 2008

<Author>ohiomichigangal
<Content>Classy, Well Maintained, and Great Service My husband and I visited in mid-June for our honeymoon. I chose the Intercontinental over several hotels in the same area, and we are so glad we did! We were upgraded to an ocean view room upon arrival. The ocean view is SPECTACULAR! You can see the neat, tropical pool area too. We were offered early check-in, pretty much as soon as we arrived from the airport. The room was the perfect size for a couple, chicly decorated, and although they did miss a day or two of cleaning it, housekeeping responded promptly to all of our requests.Pluses: Beautiful hotel, very clean, wonderful service from bell boys to housekeeping to concierge, several on-site restaurants and bars, great TVs in rooms, near a couple cute places like Lupis down the street, and fun/large pool areaMinuses: Sub-par food at all the restaurants including room service food, WAY OVERPRICED food and drink (just don't plan to eat and drink within the hotel unless you like $15 made-from-frozen hamburgers and $10 vodka-cranberries), not the most glamorous or convenient location (cost us $22 minimum to take a cab anywhere we wanted to go - there just isn't much to do in this part of San Juan)Overall we had a romantic, lovely time, felt like we got a relatively good deal (paid $2300 total for the two of us for 4 nights/5 days - included airfare, hotel, food/drink while there, cab rides, and a kayaking trip), and would return!

<Author>texasscouser
<Content>Very Impressed Rooms very nice we booked 2 laguna views but for $40 more a night per room we were upgraded to 10th and 11th floor ocean views. The featherbed pillow tops were so comfy that we ordered 2 when we got home. The free wireless internet is very fast I was getting download speeds of 220 kbs. The free in room safe was huge big enough for a laptop. and an empty fridge was very useful. The first day we stocked up with lots of beer softdrinks and liquor from the supermarket across the road. The casino has waitresses providing free alcoholic drinks and sandwiches which are gorgeous we loved their pina coladas. We play video poker machines and we were a bit dissapointed that the machines here only pay out 5 credits for 2 pair this can make a huge difference to play time as vegas machines pay out 10 credits for 2 pair this together with the wait times for the elevators were the only negatives for this hotel. We had to push both up and down on the elevators and go along for the ride just to get on else you could be standing there for many minutes. The ocean was the nicest I have ever been in very warm and clean and with a very welcome constant breeze. We ate once in the breakfast buffet it was very nice but about $5 overpriced. Also we ate once in Alfredos italian. the prices for the food are not to bad but the wine list is very overpriced the cheapest was $40. For 4 with wine was $230. We went to mi Casita for breakfast very reasonable but extremely slow. It took 10 minutes to bring a menu 20 minutes for coffee and 30 minutes for the food to arrive. We also ate at Lupis, Metropol and the Ranch all excellent. If you go at the end of june you may see this guy in the photo walking the beach he comes every year and entertains the ladies. The cab fare is $15.50 from the airport for 4 with 4 bags and $21 to old san juan try to get dropped off at the castillo san felipe del morro as the walk through old san juan is then mostly down hill. The liquor laws seem very loose here as they served my 16 year old daughter without question. Also the duty free in the airport allows purchases to the US. All in All an excellent vacation which I give 8 out of 10

<Author>lilypookie
<Content>Nice beach and pool, poor housekeeping Negatives:-Stayed at San Juan Isla Verde arrived around 1p, not accommodated w/ early check in until 4p by that time kids were cranky and tired. -House keeping horrible, dirty comforter was set aside to be changed instead they used the same comforter, flipped it around. Did not come daily, had to call to get room made. -Bathroom is small. -Cafe by pool and Italian place included tip charges even for take out. -Business center charges a fee for internet services. Positives:-Hotel decorated nicely...most of staff very friendly-kids love the pool and beach, beach entrance closes early. -taxi convenient located outside the hotel--mini mall w/ food restaurants across the street (starbucks next hotel over), brand name pharmacy walking distance-provides towels and beach chairs for beach-mini Refrigerator, iHome radio, made in Paris hair shampoo/cond, comfortable bed-small casino open 12n-4am....can use casino comp towards food and room-Restaurants in hotel: Cafe by pool - good freshly made pizza, Jap restaurant - great habachi, Ruth Chris...do not recommend Italian restaurant-rent a car availableTaxi cost (not including tips)...beats paying for gas and looking for parking:-To and from hotel: $10.5-11.00 each way-To and from Plaza las Americas mall: $18 each way (supposedly biggest in carribean - typical american malls)-To and from Old San Juan: $19 each way (lots of souvenir shops, stores are small and do not accommodate strollers, food costly esp authentic puerto rican food).

<Author>kanedaddy
<Content>Great Honeymoon Experience My wife and I stayed at the Intercontinental for our honeymoon. We were there for 4 nights. Upon arrival we were greeted by some very friendly doormen who helped us with our bags and also immediately fixed a mixup with our parking. The valet service costs more than just parking your car yourself, so I wanted them to bring back my car so I could park it myself in the parking lot across the street. They were very understanding and quick about it. When we checked in, I asked what type of room we had since we booked it through priceline and they didn't give us any room information. They informed me that we were in a city-view room and that it could be upgraded for an additional cost. I told the lady at the counter it was our honeymoon and they upgraded us to an ocean view room at no additional cost. The woman at the front desk also informed us that the power was out and some things were running on generator power but that didn't include lights and AC in the rooms. During this time, the elevators were working intermittently which was a bit annoying. Luckily the power was back on in about an hour.The staff at the hotel was very responsive and very friendly. If there was anything we needed, they either had it or found a way to get it. At one point the memory card in my wife's digital camera broke and got stuck in the camera. We called the desk and asked if they had tweezers or something we could use to remove the damaged card. Within minutes, they sent an engineer to our room with a pair of pliers and he carefully removed the card without damaging the camera.The room we had wasn't very big and the bathroom was very small. Nothing very fancy about it. But the view of the ocean outside our little balcony was fantastic. At times we just left the sliding doors open so we could listen to the ocean. We also had a pretty good view of the pool area which is very nice. We spent quite a bit of time in the pool and at the wet bar. We met another couple our age from Philadelphia and actually went out to dinner with them that night at a place recommended to us by one of the doormen.The bartenders at the hotel were great. The bartender we had at the pool was very friendly. She was happy to take our picture and her service was stellar. The bartender at the bar in the lobby was very nice as well.The hotel had a good security staff as well. They stressed the importance of only letting hotel guests onto the premises which made me feel better about my things not being stolen. When I told one of the security staff that no one had checked to see if I was a guest the day before, he said that it was unacceptable and he would correct the problem.This was our first trip to Puerto Rico and it was very memorable. Our honeymoon was everything we hoped it would be. I will definitely stay at the Intercontinental if/when I return to Puerto Rico.  
<Date>Jun 4, 2008

<Author>Well_Traveled_01
<Content>B- Hotel Overall, the room was just okay..nothing spectacular. Upon arrival the bathroom was disgusting. We called down and they sent someone up right away to clean it so they get an A for responsiveness. The workout room was slightly below average and several of the machines were broken.The pool was great and they had two different venues to dine at. Beware of the concierge staff...I would only deal with Nestor the others were not helpful or as knowledgeable.I would recommend booking excursions in advance since they fill up quickly. I can highly recommend www.acampapr.com. They are wonderful! DO NOT USE Adventuras! They are unreliable and have bad business practices. I have traveled all over the world and I have never been more appalled then with this tour operator. We asked around with the locals an apparently many others have had the same experience.Besides Acampa picks you up and drops you off at your hotel, provides lunch, and ensures that a portion of the money they receive goes back into the local community whereas Adventuras does none of the above! You have to find your own way to a local mtg place, bring your own food and we've been told by the locals that they do not reinvest in the community. To top it off their staff is rude and there is no customer service. (If you are American beware if you call and converse with someone who only speaks spanish. They use that as an excuse to say that there must have been a misunderstanding.)

<Author>vacationerBoston
<Content>Nice hotel with many amenities We stayed here for 5 nights to celebrate our 5th wedding anniversary. We were upgraded from a city view to a garden view room, which was on the 6th floor so you could see the ocean too. The room was a good size with a flat screen TV, separate couch/sitting area, fridge , plenty of counter space in the bathroom, and a small balcony. The bed was really comfortable. The AC unit like most everywhere I've stayed kicked on an off all night. There was no noise by the pool at night (I had been concerned about this) and very quiet in the halls, no noise from other rooms.Check in-our room wasn't ready until after 3, which was a pain b/c we got there at 10:30, not the hotel's fault by any stretch and they did offer us the hospitality suite if we wanted to change.One recommendation I would have would be for the hotel to invest in a couple of inexpensive chairs to fit on the balconies, it would really increase the experience to be able sit outside with coffee in the AM, or 'apre beach' to watch the sunset. The hotel surprised us with a bottle of champagne and chocolate covered strawberries with a lovely note from Irene, the guest relations manager whom I corresponded with prior to our visit. That was a really nice touch.The beach was great. I think the umbrellas should just be included in the cost of the room. For us they were a must as we are not used to the hot hot sun. Sometimes they would run out of towels if you went down late afternoon. But no rush to get chairs etc. The pool area was beautiful, we didn't use the pools though, as we like the beach better. The beach could get windy sometimes to the point of being sandblasted. The water was beautifully warm, and no seaweed. The beach was clean and it was great to have the little cafe/bar right there, though expensive!! Sticker shock even though I was warned. It gives one pause to ordering a bunch of frozen drinks all day! Nice mellow bar with friendly staff. We only ate at the cafe (an OK pizza), and Al Fredo for an appetizer of prosciutto and melon. Breakfast was really only the expensive buffet, we sat at the bar for a couple of coffees that ran $10.If you get off campus we ate at Metropol twice, great down home Cuban/Puerto Rican food. Mi Casita for breakfast once, OK, but not great service from our waitress who insisted on giving us American coffee when we wanted it Puerto Rican style. We also ate Mexican at Lupi's, it was OK.Taxi's as others have said expensive, $25 w/tip to Old San Juan. Did not use the spa. Gambled a bit, small casino, but you can get a $5 blackjack table and not as intimidating as some of the larger casinos if you're not a big gambler.I guess if I'm not sounding overly enthused it is because I discovered I really like smaller hotels. We also didn't rent a car, so while everything you really need is right at the hotel, it can cost a small fortune. For a family vacation I don't see how it could be affordable if you only stayed on campus. The area outside the hotel is urban. We walked around a bit to check out some of the other hotels. The Walgreens only had two aisles open, the supermarket seemed like it was ready to close down too. The mall is definitely not a mall, just a few stores-not that we were looking for a mall, but in case someone is! Overall I found it a perfectly acceptable nice place to stay, nice lobby area, gorgeous pools, beach, restaurants, spa, casino, bar. A pretty mellow 'scene', unlike the El San Juan which was very glitzy. But I would stay in a different area next time. Oh and the planes nearby were no problem.  
<Date>May 30, 2008

<Author>Krgl420
<Content>This was great I initially booked my vacation to stay at the El San Juan, and after reading the horrible reviews, I decided to switch over to the Intercontinental. I was so relieved I did that. My friend and I got there at around 10am, we were checked in, and we hung out by the pool for about an hour and a half. They called me on my cell and we got a city view room on the top floor wiht a balcony, and the view really isn't as bad as it sounds. The room was extremely spacious, with enough closet space and a generous bathroom, big enough for two girls to get ready for the night and not be in each other's way. There were plenty of clean towels always on hand, the cleaning people were great and cleaned our room every day. My only complaint is that the water pressure wasn't that great, but maybe I'm just used to my shower at home. The room was basic but modern, and the beds are really comfortable, maybe a little too soft for me, but thats just my opinion.There is a Walgreens down the block, we stocked up on waters and chips to snack on at night, and there is plenty of space in the room's refridgerator for big bottles of water and stuff. It was perfect, actually.The pool area was very clean and very beautiful. We stayed on the beach every day though because it's just my preference. I liked the breeze on the beach and I rented an umbrella for 10 a day (which is worth every penny). The sun is extremely brutal in PR and both my friend and I who never burned got red, so make sure to wear sunscreen!The little cafe on the beach of the hotel was good, it was nothing to really write home about, but the prices were definitely very reasonable, and they make great drinks! The pina coladas and their Jungle Fever drink were always by myside. They have a waitress walking around the beach to bring you drinks and what not. Coming from the NYC area, these drinks are definitely reasonably priced.As for food, to me, nothing was terribly overpriced. The first night we went to the El San Juan to the Palm restaurant. That to me, was just overpriced Italian food, even though it was really good, it's just like home cooking to me so the prices were a little high. The second night we went to Ruth's Chris steakhouse in the hotel - PHENOMENAL!!! The steaks are pricey (but typical for steakhouses in the NorhtEast), but my friend and I saw a special they were having - $99 for two people, and we each got a salad, choice of meat (we chose the petite filets and they were to die for!! Like butter!) a side dish and dessert. Dessert wasn't so great, but then again, we were soooooo stuffed with our meal Id on't think our stomachs could have fit the dessert anyway.The last night we went to the hibachi restaurant in the hotel. Not my favorite place, but I was definitely pleasantly surprised at how tasty the food was. Plus we met this great couple that was on their honeymoon. She is a native of PR and told us about some places to go out for drinks and whatnot.We did go into Old San Juan one day. I love Old San Juan, way better than San Juan, and we heard that the night life out there is great, we just never made it out at night. The cab fare is $20 each way, but def worth it considering all the traffic and the congestion, that driving there yourself would not be fun. We went to the restaurant where they invented the Pina Colada, Barrachina or something like that. It's around the corner fromt he Burberry outlet, and it was AMAZING. so were the Pina coladas! I would def go back there.We didn't get to really experience the true nightlife as we were there during the week, and we were told by all the locals that nothing really got going until Thursday. We went over to the bar at the El San Juan, and I felt out of place, like I was too young to be there (I'm 26). Also, the drinks weren't made that great, and the staff at the El San Juan weren't as attentive or friendly, although I do believe that the pool area at the El San Juan was a little nicer and more modern, with more modern music playing. But as far as the rooms and the rest of the service, I can't say.You should def check out the Water Club. It's a 8-10 minute walk from the hotel, and it has a really cool rooftop lounge. Its def worth checking out.The concierge was very helpful and they have a list of excursions to take if you feel the need. We didn't, but looking back, I wish we had. We did go jetskiing, which was really fun. They're stationed on the beach right outside the El San Juan. 30 minutes was $70, which is a lot, but it was sooo fun. Some people complained about the seaweed - some days the water was chopier than others, but the seaweed tends to gather right on the shore, if you walk into the water a little further its completely gone and very clean. Overall my experience at the Intercontinental was great. I def would go back to PR, just not to San Juan.  
<Date>May 30, 2008

<Author>vstylin215
<Content>Good times at Intercontinental I was a bit apprehensive about this hotel after going through many of the reviews here. Many have complained about the service, and I must say, we only had but amazing service when we went. There were 4 families that stayed in that hotel for a wedding and non of us had any issues with the hotel. Service was impeccable. FRONT DESK: here is where I thought I would run into issues. However, they proved me wrong and were more than helpful with checking in and any other questions I had for them. In fact, I had originally booked just a city-view room and they were kind enough to upgrade me and my parents-in-law to a beautiful and immensely big ocean view room. If you have any questions about restaurants and such, the concierge is very knowledgable and capable of guiding anyone to the right direction.ROOMS: the ocean-view room was amazing. HUGE. We had a king size bed that was beyond comfortable, a love seat, a one-seater, coffee table, and an office table. Needless to say, this room had plenty of space. The closet fit all of our clothes comfortably and there is a small space outside the bathroom for a vanity area where there is great lighting for prepping to go out and applying makeup. The bathroom is also quite spacious and has one of the most powerful showers I have ever experienced in my life. Showering at this hotel was fast and amazing. It was a massage and a shower in one! Lastly, everything was clean! A great plus for a germaphobe like myself.POOL: pretty large and very clean. Never any straws or any nasty things floating. There were many zones ranging from 3 feet to 6 feet. A couple of waterfalls for a nice hydro massage. They start giving the towels poolside at about 8am. This help curbing the habit of people saving the chairs too early. If you go early enough, before 9 froom what I have noticed, they even give you a neckroll along with the towel. They will give you a bracelet when you check these items out and upon returning them, do not forget to ask them to cut those pesky bracelets off.BEACH: We never laid out in the pool and stayed on the beach our entire stay. To us, nothing beats the sound of the ocean and the amazing breeze that puts us both to sleep quicker than we ever anticipate. The beach was clean. Not much seaweed. Out of the 4 days we were there, only once did I see a lot of seaweed. And they were quickly taken away by the staff. For those that love the calm beach, it all depends on the day. Our first day there, it was VERY rough. The waves were huge and intimidating. Each day thereafter, the waves and the ocean slowly calmed down; and our trip ended with very calm waters by the 4th day. I don't know if it is dependent on the weather on some other factor, but there was no consistency as far as how rough or calm the water was that day. There were plenty of beach chairs, so there was no need to get up early and save a chair. They also have umbrellas available for a fee (I think $10) and there is a staff member that will assist you in putting it in. RESTAURANTS: this is one aspect of the hotel I cannot be of any help. Sorry, but I did not eat at any of the restaurants after reading all the reviews about the prices they charge. However, my hubby did eat at Alfredo's, the Italian restaurant, for breakfast and he said the omelet was big and delicious. After I found out the price ($14), delicious should have been the least of what that omelet was! My parents-in-law ordered a pizza for room service and I remember them saying it was not memorable whatsoever. MISCELLANEOUS: The elevators were a bit on the slow side of things. Press LL on elevator if you want to bypass the lobby to go to the pool. The casino was fairly small at this place. Drinks at the bar were mostly around $10 to $14. We ate at the restaurant across the street for breakfast called Mi Casita. Service is beyond slow, but the price is just right. Most of the breakfast items were $5 give or take. I ordered the eggs, homefries, and toast for $4.95. The homefries has a different and addictive flavor that I've never tasted in any homefries before! There is also a convenience store next to Mi Casita. I highly suggest buying bottled water and juices here. I think the hotel charged $8 for the big Fiji water and $3.50 for the small bottles. A six pack of water bottles cost us about $3.50. Save your money and walk across the street and hang right for about a 1/2 a block. They are all there in that little strip mall. Within that strip mall is also a burger king and a ponderosa. In fact, there are so many American food restaurants that I was a bit disappointed of the location. Nonetheless, it is convenient for those who like them. Pamela's had amazing food...expensive, but worth every penny! La Pascaderia Atlantica had the best seafood ever! I'm salivating just thinking about it again. Definetly save room for the tres leches for dessert. Ridiculously delicious! Any of the bakeries around the area always had great bread and sandwiches. There is Reposteria Espana not too far from the hotel. For those needing Starbucks fix, right next door to our hotel is the El San Juan. There, you will find two Starbucks! Also great shopping at this hotel. It's very lively at night. Great band by the bars. Dress to impress if you go at night to party. But definitely a great place to hang out. Huge casino. The Intercontinental looks like a dot next to there's. We went to Old San Juan our last day since we had a 5:45 PM flight out of Puerto Rico. They tell you to be at the airpot 2 hours before departure. If you want a late check-out, the hotel charges about $75. Check out is at 12PM, but they were kind enough to give us till 1PM. Ask for the courtesy room if you don't want the $75 charge. I think they give you 30 minutes to use it. We checked out at 1 and gave our luggage to the bellhop and walked around Old San Juan for a couple hours. Taxi there is about $19 per way and takes between 10-15 minutes. Beautiful buildings and cobble-stone roads. La Bombanera had the best food! Ask for la mallorca (pronounced la mayorca). Goes wonderfully with coffee. Renting a car would be advisable. Taxis are very expensive there. Cost $7 to go down 2 hotels. If I didn't have the long dress on (on our way to the wedding) I would have walked that way! Intercontinental charges $16 for parking (self-park) across the street. Valet parking costs $22 per day. If your going to Old San Juan, parking is horrible! We took a taxi and were glad we did! Always ask for the price before you go in to avoid getting ripped-off! Have fun! Puerto Rico was a blast! email me for any questions.  
<Date>May 21, 2008

5	4(nice):1	99(couple):1	730(massage):1	2280(waterfall):1	10953(hydro):1	

<Author>ChicagoTanJan
<Content>Loved the Pool and Beach This is a wonderful hotel. My only disappointment is in Puerto Rico itself. 1. Hotel location-I was disappointed in the area around this hotel.Lots of American fast food places to eat at and no feel that you were in a different country. Might as well have been in Florida. Fast food joints were great for cheap lunches on the beach. 2.Pool/Beach-Whoever designed this pool did a fantastic job. The large waterfalls drown out any noise from the pool bar, pool restaurant and noisy people. There is a great mix of shade and sun. The towel people will only give you 1 towel each and 1 pillow each. The pillow was great.. They always gave us 4 large towels in the room for 2 people, so we just brought extra towels down with us to the bool/beach to compensate for the 1 towel per person allotment at the pool. The beach is large enough to really spread out and not be on top of others. Chaise lounge chairs were free but the umbrella was $10. You rent them from the pool/towel hut. The umbrellas are a little on the small side. My husband had a hard time getting completely under it. There was always something sticking out. Out of the 6 days we were there the water was calm 2 days, and rough 4 days. By rough I mean you could not relax and carry on a conversation in the water. You had to be very alert or get wiped out by a wave. Eventually, I just when in up to my knees. 3.Food/restaurants- Do yourself a favor and bring a collapsible cooler. Go to Walgreens..buy alot of water and pop. Fill your cooler with ice (provided at the hotel ice machine) and enjoy your cheap drinks on the beach. We also bought beer at the grocery store accross the street ($7 for 6 cans) and had our own cheap happy hour. The first day of arrival my husband and I split a cheeseburger/fries and he had a beer. The bill from the beachside restaurant came to $25 including tip. So needless to say that was the last day we ate hotel/beach food. My husband took the walk accross the street to fast food heaven and bought us Burger King or Taco Bell for lunch. Everytime he came back through the lobby with our lunch food, a Manager advised him he would not be allowed to eat it at the pool. Since we were on the beach this was not an issue. Just very annoying. For dinner we avoided the extremely pricey restaurants at the hotel and opted for Lupis (just past the El San Juan). They had what might be the best steak fajitas I have ever had. ($13,I think) and $3 Medella beers. Also ate 1 night at Outback(at Embassy Suites). At first the prices seem comparable to home until you realize they do not include the salad, like at home. Good meal. Just costs more than home.Hotel room- Got upgraded to an oceanview room. Slept every night with the door open to hear the waves. The room had a ceiling fan, so that kept us cool enough at night even with the door open. The room also had a lighted make-up mirror. The refrigerator is stocked with overpriced hotel beverages but, there is still alot of room to put your own beverages or leftover dinner.Car rental-We rented an intermediate for $30 a day including tax from Dollar rent a car at the Holiday Inn(1 block from Intercontinental). They do close at 5pm so unless you want to pay $16 to park it at the Intercontinental make sure you get going in the morning so that you can return it by 5pm. We drove to El Yunque and were able to hike to the waterfall, stop for lunch and shop Belz outlet mall. The drive to El Yunque takes longer than you think it will. Lots of stop lights made it take 1 1/2 hours. Hotel rate- I booked at Interline Travel.com. This website is for Airline employee discounted rates. We paid $208 per night for a lagoon view room. Their rates are a real deal when you realize the 22% taxes are included. I bought the AmbassadorClub membership ($150) from Intercontinental.com which gives you a one category room upgrade at check in. We would have been upgraded to Pool view but, since they didn't have any available ...we got upgraded to oceanview.Casinos-The El San Juan casino was our favorite. A good amount of 1 cent machines. This casino does get crowded on Wednesday and Thursdays with locals. (They must have some promotion for them because they were allover the penny machines.) We did not like the Intercontinental casino, at all. Not enough penny machines. And the ones they did have wouldn't take your bills or vouchers. They just kept rejecting anything you tried to put in them. The Embassy Suites casino was very small. Hope this helps you enjoy your stay as much as we did.  
<Date>May 19, 2008

<Author>2nvno1
<Content>Nice, but not great! I enjoyed my stay at the hotel. The pool very nice and the beach was ok. The tide was a little ruff. The cafe was small but the food was excellent. Fair prices considering your at a resort. The waitresses and waiters was all friendly and courteous. The Pina Colada's were excellent.......Waleska made the best. The hotel was a little to quite for me and the casino was small and had out dated slot machines. We stayed in a suite which was nice and clean, but small compared to many suites I have seen. There was no tub, which in my opinion is not a suite. All the suites only had a city view with a very small balcony not big enogh for a small table or chair. And with having a city view suite there is not much privacy because you are on the front entrance side of the hotel and there is alot of traffic in and out of the hotel. There are plenty of places outside the resort to get food at a great price. Not sure of the exact name but I believe it's called Misa Casa ( great food /great price) which is in th shopping center across the street from resort. There is also a nice small sushi bar about a block up the street that served excellent sushi and the miso soup was to die for. I visited a few other hotels in the immediate area and found the El San Juan was the place to be to hang out on the weekends. All in all it was a good stay, I will return to Puerto Rico but probably will choose another hotel.  
<Date>May 19, 2008

<Author>ab_wilcox
<Content>Wonderful Hotel I stayed at the InterContinental while on a young mommies ladies trip to San Juan. I read many reviews of Puerto Rico before my trip, with the majority of reviews stating that the service in Puerto Rico is slow, bad, or nonexistent. I must say that I had the opposite experience. Everyone at the InterContinental was friendly, helpful, and happy. This includes the front desk, concierge, bellhop, doorman, bartenders, waitstaff, chambermaids- you name it. We had a wonderful time. I was able to view the lobbies of nearby hotels and by comparison, I much preferred the atmosphere at the InterContinental. It was clean, bright, well decorated, easy to find what you were looking for, and never too crowded to find someone to help you with a request. The pool area was beautiful, right on the beach, had a lovely pool, plenty of seating, plenty of bars and food to choose from, waitstaff that would serve you poolside, plenty of greenery, and great weather to top it all off. I highly recommend this hotel.  
<Date>May 6, 2008

<Author>FloridaRms
<Content>fun, relax and explore This was our first visit to Purto Rico, and for our first stay we couldn't have chosen a more perfect place. The rooms were big, with a balcony and quite comfortable, and always kept clean. The staff were all very friendly but we found the concierge desk at all times to be very outgoing and helpful. One of the tours they recommended was the Catch a Dream Ranch, which was a 90 minute horse back riding experience like we will never forget thru the foothills of the rainforest and a run on the Rio Mar beach with a beautifull view of the El yungque rainforest in the background. We found the restaurant on the beach very nice along with several of the local area restaurants. Cabs are plentiful and the rates are set so regardless of the traffic situation your assured of the cost which we found quite reasonable and more relaxing than trying to rent a car and deal with the local traffic ourselves. Over all we had a great time.  
<Date>May 4, 2008

<Author>slimdim
<Content>Great Time We stayed on the 8th floor Ocean and Poolview and were a little blocked by the trees (for Poolview) ,none the less, it was very nice. The entire staff was attentive and we never had to open the doors when coming into the hotel or leaving. The staff would smile and acknowledge us everytime.Even though we bid through Priceline the front staff still treated us professionally and even upgraded the room to oceanview. Our check in time was very fast without any bumps. When we called for our bags to be brought up they arrived within minutes. I thought it was a joke because of how quick they arrived. The bellperson introduced himself and gave us some tips on our rooms and the area in general.The room was equipped with a refrigerator, flat screen tv, and a very comfortable bed. As others have mentioned, make a visit to the small market across the street or the Walgreen's and stock up on items that will save you from some of the ridiculous prices by the pool. Why not save your money for other things? Definitely give the restaurant down stairs MOMOYAMA. It was excellent and for a couple our total was around $70 tip included, so worth it.I did incur one problem and didn't get help from ANYONE which is why I didn't rate this hotel higher. I attempted to take money out of the ATM located in the hotel casino. The first attempt was for $200 and it said Sorry, we're unable to complete your transaction. So, I tried for $100 and received the same response. Knowing I had money in my account I checked my account online and it shows the withdrawals???? I spoke to the night manager at the casino and he said that the problem with the ATM happens sometimes(the ATM ran out of money) and that I would be credited. They refer me to the bank that owns the ATM and they tell me, We can't help you out cause your not one of our customers.I check my bank account two business days later and the charges are still there. I speak with the front office Manager at the hotel and tell him the above and once again I'm told it's not there ATM so he can't help me. Why would this hotel keep an ATM with this problem????After a call to my bank and putting in a dispute, MY BANK took care of the issue immediately after their dispute division contacted the ATM bank. MY money was credited back to me.Take care of problems that are continuous to customers and this hotel would have received 4.5 rating from me because overall we had a good time.

<Author>NesserG
<Content>Decent stay at the InterContinental 11 of us girls stayed at the InterContinental Hotel for a bachelorette weekend. We all enjoyed our stay except for dealing with one of their employees, Barbara, who works at the Concierge desk. Stay away from her! She was NOT helpful, was extremely RUDE, and had a major attitude problem towards us as a few of the girls tried to check in (their vouchers were left at the Concierge desk as a few of the girls checked in a day or 2 later). We complained to the manager explaining how rude, and unhelpful she was; we are their hotel guests and spending A LOT of money to stay there; there was no need to deal with this kind of service! Jhazil, at the Concierge desk, was extremely helpful and recommended great clubs, restaurants, and bars to go to in Old San Juan (OSJ). Look for her to help you!Overall, our stay at the hotel was good. Small, comfy beds, and clean rooms and bathrooms. We asked for a late check out for 4pm and they gave it to us for free of charge (normally $75 for late afternoon check-out)! The cafe on the beach was great too - order the chicken tortilla wrap; it's delicious! The hotel is close to Walgreens, an ATM, ESJ Hotel, and the Ritz. Too bad it's far away from OSJ, but it's a close drive at least. We can't wait to go back to PR next year!

<Author>hpeter
<Content>Great...once again!! This is my second time staying at the Intercontinental. My family and I stayed there last year. I wrote a positive review about the first time there and things have not changed. We had first planned on staying at the El San Juan this time, but thankfully changed our plans. On our return to the Intercontinental, we saw familiar faces...Bellmen, doormen, front desk, concierge, bar tenders, security, waiters and waitresses and a few managers. They are still friendly, courteous, helpful and pleasant. Ivan the doorman, Andy the bellman, Pablo the front desk manager--all awesome. They remembered us from last year and because of them we will return. The buffet breakfast is delicious and fresh. The rooms are clean and the pool is clean and beautiful. Pool staff are helpful. The airplanes are not a big deal. If the pool bar is a little weak with their drinks, just ask for another one. If you let them know they won't be offended. The only thing I did not like is how certain guests were treated a little more special by management. A lot of brown nosing going on. Its probably the best Hotel in Isla Verde.

<Author>Bluegrove
<Content>Great experience at the InterContinental My husband and I stayed here April 13 - 17 and were very pleased with the service and accomodations. The staff were friendly and accomodating, greeting us often and cheerfully throughout the hotel. We had a beautiful oceanfront room which was both clean and attractive. The mattress was excellent and we even had a small balcony overlooking the pool. We tried the Italian restaurant for dessert and the bar for lunch and drinks. Another night we had a wonderful meal downstairs at Ruth Chris Steakhouse. Even though the food was expensive, it was no more than I would expect at a first class hotel on the ocean. The location is convenient and we were not bothered at all by the airport nearby. I would highly recommend this hotel!

<Author>ellyA
<Content>Nice Overall, but no great value We stayed for an extended weekend as part of a conference/vacation. The pool and grounds were lovely, and the rooms clean and pleasant (if a little small). We were treated well by the staff overall, though some were a little young and inattentive. The pool is gorgeous -- great for kids who enjoy swimming. The beach is lovely as well, and security is quite good. We felt that we could relax and enjoy our time there. We only ate at the restaurant near the beach. The snacks were overpriced and only so-so, though the meals were pretty good and not too expensive. The drinks were expensive and weak, and even the bottled water and sodas were overpriced. Once the conference ended, we felt a bit isolated from shopping -- the shelves at the store across the street were 1/2 empty, and there were only a few fastfood places otherwise. I would recommend going 2 blocks, past the SJ Hotel and Casino, to Gelato Piu for meals and snacks.  
<Date>Apr 16, 2008

<Author>rodiggity79
<Content>Had a Fabulous Time! My girlfriends and I, 8 of us total, had a fabulous stay at the Intercontinental! We initially booked at the El San Juan next door, but because of bad reviews decided to swap hotels and book here. It really turned out for the better. We had 2 of the standard rooms (no ocean view) and the rooms were quite spacious. The best part of this hotel is the pool area and the beach. They are both beautiful. We stayed from Thursday - Sunday and most days didn't get to the pool until 11am or noon. We had no problem finding chairs for all of us and there were plenty of options for shade and sun. We enjoyed the casino area... the dealers were much more friendly than at the El San Juan Hotel and the minimums were also lower at the tables. We did go to to the El San Juan club Brava for one night and had fun, but most of our time was spent at the Intercontinental.There is a small grocery store across the street and a few fast food options. We ate at Mi Casita across the street and the food was good. Overall, a great trip! Would definitely return to this hotel in the future.  
<Date>Apr 10, 2008

<Content>Nice Hotel. Not so great location We paid full price so value wasn't there for us. One night precruise. Beach and pool area were quite beautiful. Service was outstanding. There is one thing you really really need to know. Since I am a priority club member got a beautiful ocean front room. However, El San Juan next door has an outdoor club with full blown Dj playing way into the late night hours. Was ok for the one night precruise. Didn't get to sleep until about 2. Mean while airport is on other side of hotel. I wouldn't want to go through a week there. Ask if it is every night or just on Sat.

<Author>kikiswfnova
<Content>perfect start to our vacation booked one night pre cruise, great deal thru priceline. arrived by noon on saturday (cruise not until 10 pm. sunday). (Taxi was about $25 for two of us (four pieces of luggage) Hotel offered to store luggage while we changed into bathing suits and got two chairs by the pool. (chairs are difficult to find on a busy weekend). we had lunch poolside, very expensive, but we knew that before we decided to eat there). our room was ready by 3, we tossed our things there and headed to the beach. the room was very nice and overlooking the ocean and pool. I was surprized considering our price we paid thru priceline. there is everything in walking distance, walgreens, supermarket, resturants, outback, all the fast food places, a couple of breakfast places across the street. We walked to a wonderful italian rooftop resturant ontop of howard johnsons. the area does get seedy down in that part of town.if you are a priority member they let you stay in your room until 2. which was great for us. once you leave your room either at noon or 2, you can get a hospitality suite for 30 minutes in order to clean up should you want to spend the entire day at the hotel/beach. they give you a wrist band each day for use of the pool/beach and towels, etc. i would highly recommend it. oh and the el san juan is right next door which has an active nightclub. I'd go back.

<Author>murphyIowa
<Content>great stay Stayed at the Intercontinental for 6 nights with 2 teenage kids. I would recommend the hotel. The beach was great, soft sand and a long beach perfect for walks. The pool was also very nice but we spent most of our time on the beach. All of the staff were very nice and helpful. Ate at the beachfront rest almost every day and was good beach/pool food. Also ate at Ruth Chris steak house and was best steak we had ever had. Only rest we did not eat at was the Japanese rest. All were good. We went do El Yunque rainforest on day and hiked the waterfall trail and then went to Luquillo beach, would highly recommend both. Also spent one afternoon in Old San Juan and went to El Morro and walked around downtown, was also a great exp.Stayed on the 14th floor, great ocean view, newly ren room, flat screen, ect., bathroom was a little small but can't have everything.Would stay here again.

<Author>akersjr
<Content>Great spring break getaway for family We found the hotel to be just what the doctor ordered...our trip away from cold Ky. was much needed! The staff was fabulous - from our first moment of getting out of the taxi, until the moment we got back in a taxi to the airport. In fact - at check in, we were upgraded to an ocean view room - when we had booked a garden view room. We were booked for a Triple A room rate, too. I didn't even ask for the upgrade, it was just offered to us. My one thought was - at the time of booking I thought to enter my Priority Membership Card since the Intercontinenal is part of that family of hotels. I'm not in it for the points, but I've heard that sometimes you can get upgraded to a better floor or get some better amenities with just being a member (and membership is free). So...maybe just having that member number on the reservation helped. Who knows. Anyway - the view was GREAT. Pool was FABULOUS. Our 7 year old couldn't get enough! Food at hotel IS expensive. However - if you want to splurge - the Japanese restaurant is good and a hit with kids. The Ruth's Chris steakhouse is also excellent. There is a bakery across the street that has cheap breakfast - like bagels and pancakes. Also , Mi Casita, a Puerto Rican restaurant across the street, is a nice alternative. Not totally cheap - but better priced than the hotel. Go to Walgreens down the street for snacks/groceries. You can put stuff in the in-room fridge for b'fast (we did). There's a subway across the street - and Domino's pizza. Pizza Hut is nearby as is Wendy's. We HIGHLY recommend a tour to the Rain Forest. We booked it through the concierge the day before - and it was well worth it. Again - the hotel was wonderful for our needs. Room was clean, not totally fashionable - but beds were comfy. All other parts of the hotel were beautiful. I felt extremely safe - and felt comfortable with my 7 year old running around the pool. The staff could not have been nicer. We plan to return to Puerto Rico, and if we return to the San Juan - we would definitely stay at the Intercontinental again. Flight note: if you fly Delta - we found out you can change your flight time on the same day for just $50 per ticket if you call within 3 hours of the flight you would like to take (if there is space). We were able to take an earlier flight from home and get an extra half day in the sun. By doing this we didn't have to pay a full ticket change fee or pay new charges on a new ticket.  
<Date>Apr 5, 2008

<Author>rdurbin
<Content>Juice is Not Worth the Squeeze First, If you book through hotwire or one of the like and get a discount rate, you will get a discount room with a discount view. We booked an ocean view and can barely see it. What we can see is the ugly roof of the lobby. Pleasant. The management staff is horrible. Not helpful when you have a problem. We had a problem with the in room movies and when they sent tecs to look at it they could not speak english. We called the manager and asked them to send someone that did. They sent someone else but his english was so limited he could only speak a few words of english. I understand we are in puerto rico but this is supposed to be a world class hotel. The manager got upset when i called him back and said what do you expect, we speak spanish here. Wow, thats insightful. The restaurants are way way way over priced. Ruth Chris' is ok but you can get a better steak at any of the restaurants in Old San Juan. The bar charges 11.00 for a scotch and water. The pool side restaurant charges more for a sandwich. Overall we loved puerto rico but wish we would have stayed elsewhere.

<Author>JM3074
<Content>The Worst Customer Service! We stayed at the Intercontinental for a bachelorette party for the weekend of March 14th. We picked this hotel because of the great reviews. I know everyone experiences are different, so I thought I should share mine. The Intercontinental was overall an okay looking hotel, nothing special. The service on the other hand was terrible. From the moment we got there to check in at the front desk we were given attitude, especially by Barbara (who we always some how had to deal) She seemed bothered by everything and looked at us as if we were asking her for stuff that didn have to do with her job!One of the worst things about the hotel, are the elevators. You could hear everyone who were staying at the hotel complain constantly about how long they took! 15-20 minutes to just go up to your room is unacceptable.. and when they finally did arrive, they would be so packed with guests that you had to squeeze in.. People in the elevator always tried to make room because there was an understanding that no one wanted to wait another 20 minutes for the next elevator! Something to note.. Check out is at 12pm.. and although they don tell you this till after.. they will deactivate your keys at 12pm sharp.. even if you have requested a late check out. So something to be aware of.The Pool area was definitely the highlight of this hotel. There were always chairs available and the pool wait staff was great, thanks especially to Javier  Wilmer!When I go away, even if its for a long weekend.. its because I want to relax and feel calm. Anytime we had to deal with the hotel employees, they were rude, abrupt and unhelpful or just took forever to do anything. I believe they need to be retrained in Customer Service.So.. in my opinion, the Intercontinental Hotel chain tends to mean you are getting a good quality hotel with great service.. Don be fooled by the name?The San Juan Intercontinental is not like any of the other Intercontinental I have ever stayed at. For the price.. I recommend going somewhere else.  
<Date>Mar 18, 2008

<Author>Carib74
<Content>Good Weekend Getaway My wife and I travel to the Caribbean 2-3 times per year and we enjoyed our first stay at the Intercontinental San Juan.We thought the ease of flying domestic with self service check in was a large benefit and the hotel is only 5 minutes from the airport. You can definately hear the planes but they do bother you when you are pool or beach side.We had a club level room which we liked as you have your own personal deck and chairs poolside and the club level provides breakfast and a cocktail time everynight.Everyone was very nice and service was great. We spent most of our time at the beach which was never over crowded and you never had to fight for chairs at the pool.The pool bar was very nice with very good food. Food prices are high compared to most other resorts.We ate at Ruth Chris Steakhouse and Alfredo's at the hotel which were good. We went off-site to Marmalade's which was overpriced, slow service, and small portions. We had a good meal at Pamela's which was oceanside.We would recommend this hotel for couples looking to get some beach and pool time. Kids would like the beach and pool but there are no other kids activities on site.Casino was smaller than average but had everything needed to have some low key gambling fun.Overall we would recommend this resort if you are looking for some quality beach and pool time and really do not want to go far from the resort.  
<Date>Mar 12, 2008

<Author>tmitola
<Content>Beautiful Resort.....Great Beach I did alot of research on mytripadvisor...so I feel strongly about sharing our experience. The Intercontinental is wonderful...on par with a Ritz Carlton. Our room had a beautiful ocean view and new furnishings. Service and staff were excellent. Property grounds are meticulously kept ...pool area is beautiful and lush. The beach is great with just enough surf to keep kids interested. Casino on the property is lackluster...but if you want the glintz of Vegas the El San Juan is right next store. We actually preferred the relaxed, island feel of the Intercontinental though. We used the pool restaurants for lunch...they were very good and resort priced. We had breakfast across the street at Mi casita....very reasonable and good. Breakfast for four is around $30...compared to $22 per person at the hotel. We dined outside the resort for dinner...Barachino's is about a fifteen minute walk...excellent island food VERY friendly staff. We also tried Aijji Modito in Condado despite good reviews the food was OK...we found out after they changed management about a month ago. By far the best Puerto Rican fare was at Raices in Old San Juan....large portions...delicious. Plus, the atmosphere is fun all the staff dresses in traditional island costume. We also dined at The Parrot Club in Old San Juan which was very good...The Dragon Fly ,which is run by the same owner, is asian infused...but is more of a tapis bar than restaurant. Plates are small and to share. Its a good option if you want to eat lighter...island fare can be heavy. Try the duck nachos... In terms of siteseeing, we loved the location of the hotel....being 15 to the airport was great. We went to Old San Juan every night...we rented a car...about a 15 min drive. Parking lots were accessible and a mere $3 for the day. The forts are interesting with beautiful vistas. We went to Baccardi by car...but wouldn't waste your time...you do NOT tour the actual factory anymore...its a short movie and some displays. The Rain Forest is a great trip for kids....loved swimming in the falls. While there we also went to Luquillo Beach which is a beautiful beach, but if your staying in Isle Verde, the hotel beach is nicer with more amenties..so you might want to skip it. We did eat lunch at the kioskis...its their version of road side fast food... alot of fried fritter type food. The people of PR were wonderful and friendly. If you are a staying more than three days definitely rent a car. One word of caution, the drivers in PR are typical city drivers no worse than any New Yorker . But the roadways are not easy to navigate as their road signs are mininal/missing...none of the major atttractions had road signs!!!! The conceirge will give you printed directions..but often they were vague or inaccurate. If you get lost ,and you will, you can call the Conceirge for help. Be sure you have a charged cellphone.We loved the Intercontinenal and would definately return.  
<Date>Feb 17, 2008

<Author>ABIGAIL6
<Content>Great Price, Beach, Pool and Casino The hotel is a short taxi ride from the airport. It is not far from the airport, but that should not be a concern at all. The beach at the hotel is great as is the pool and hot tub. The pool is beautiful and the hot tub is huge. You can get a drink while swimming in the pool. The outside caf is great for lunch. The Japanese restaurant is great for great reasonable sushi. The people in the sushi restaurant are very nice too. The excursions you can book at the concierge are over priced. The exercise room is great if you want to work out. There is an Avis rent a car facility located in the lobby. Rented a car for one day for $50.00. The Avis rent a car lady was very helpful. We used the car rental to go to the rain forest and then drove to a beautiful beach where we went snorkeling.The casino is nice, HINT: go to the casino during the day and afternoon for $5.00 blackjack tables, otherwise you will never get a $5.00 blackjack table. In the evening there are mostly $10.00 and $25.00 tables. Only complaint was the soft bed, but I must admit the fresh air in Puerto Rico exhausted me so I had no trouble sleeping.  
<Date>Feb 16, 2008

<Author>LMMBATAVIA
<Content>Fantastic service Loved the Intercontinental. Traveled with friends and we had a great time. The restaurants and drinks by the pool are expensive, but there are other options. Plenty of great restaurants nearby (Metropol-really good) and a grocery across the street. With refrigerators in the room it was easy to buy and bring back to the hotel. People could not have been nicer. The only problem we had (4 star instead of 5) was that we were told that there was a hospitality suite we could use since our flight was not until 6, but they never told us until we got the key that you only have 30 min. For one person fine but for all of us it was a little rushed. I get it but they should have warned us and we could have split up. Will definitely return to San Juan and would stay at the Intercontinental again.

<Author>luischable
<Content>Excellent Beach Front Hotel This is the third time I have stayed at the Hotel and the second review I have written. Standard of the hotel is great. We were lucky enough to be upgraded to the Club Rooms which are poolside and although they lack a view are well worth it. The rooms are bigger than the Standard Ocean view rooms and come with your own small private terrace. As with all Puerto Rico service is a mixed bag. The bellboys were great and one of the hosts in the Club room could not do enough but her boss looks at guests who use the 'cocktail hour' as if they are doing something wrong. She does not help or even ask if customers are having a nice time. Standard of everything is great but the overall experience is a little dated as the hotel was built a while back. I would go back again for a relaxing stay with easy access to the airport and a great weekend away.  
<Date>Feb 13, 2008

<Author>rtm18
<Content>Great for Business  I have stayed here for business quite often over the past few years (and a few times for pleasure) and finally had to write a review. This place has definitely made some great improvements. While the service has always been excellent, the facilities are now up to par for an Intercontinental. As others have noted, the hotel has gone through some major renovations and is now a top-notch resort.Again, the service here has always been excellent. I feel like I'm walking into Cheers every time I step through the front door (OK, I stay here very often). There are too many names to mention but Lorna Mendez has always taken good care of me! This is a great hotel for business travelers as it is very close to the airport (it is not that loud) and has every amenity a business traveler could want, including a nice business center and fitness center.I have also taken my family here a few times for pleasure and was never disappointed. The last time I took my wife here a few months ago and we had a great time - so great that she wants to come back for her big XXth birthday. I told her she could go anywhere (within reason) but she wanted to come back here. The grounds are fabulous and it is right on a beautiful beach. Yes, food and drink may be a bit pricey but you are at a very nice resort and the food is excellent. If you are on a tight budget there is always Motel 6. I would rather splurge on a single stay here than a couple of stays at a budget motel.There are plenty of reasonable dining options within a short walk or ride. Nearby is Lupis, Mi Casita, Metropol, Outback and a Chili is opening soon. Old San Juan is loaded with fabulous restaurants (Aguaviva ?best ceviche!, Parrot Club, Dragonfly, Tamarind, Tantra) as well as shops, historical sights, etc. There are also some great restaurants between the hotel and Old San Juan. Some of my favorites are Ropa Vieja, Pamela (tables on the beach!), Ajili Mojili, Che, Atlantica, Steak  Co. and Casa Dante to name a few. Also you must try Soleil Beach Club in Pinones, an open-air place right on the water with fabulously fresh seafood.An overall great hotel for business and pleasure and great city!  
<Date>Feb 13, 2008

<Author>KevinOleary
<Content>Great Hotel...very friendly staff! We recently stayed at the Intercontinental for my father in law's 60th birthday party. We asked for an upgrade for the birthday boy and they gave us a Suite for no extra cost. The staff was really friendly, starting with the lady at the front desk and throughout the rest of the property. The rooms were nice and well kept, the beach was the cleanest of all the beach spots around. I liked the Casino at the El San Juan better than the IC but the dealers were friendlier at the IC. In all we had a great time and will def return for another stay. Tip...the El San Juan next door has a really nice nightclub, get there early on a Sat night and they have a cool roof top bar as well.

<Author>LucyCalvin
<Content>A good hotel Most of the reviews we read were right on:Hotel: Only a 5-10 minute cab ride from the airport ($11 fare). The lobby and pool are very nice. The beach is nice, but the water did have some seaweed so if that bothers you might consider a different area/island. Never had a problem getting a lounge chair at the pool or beach. The walls are thin and the doors to each room tend to slam when they close. The sound of the airplanes didn't bother us. We thought the concierge people were friendly and very helpful. The casino is small but still enjoyable.Food: Ma Casita was good, reasonably priced breakfast and dinner food. We were not impressed with the breakfast at Alfredo's (in the hotel), especially at $22 per person. The Japenese restaurant at the hotel was okay. We went into Old San Juan twice (we loved it there; $19 cab fare each way - hint: you can share a cab with other hotel guests who are going into Old San Juan to save a little money) and ate at the Puerto Rico Cafe - a cheesy name but very good authentic Puerto Rican food. We went next door to the El San Juan Hotel for dinner and gambling one night - we ate at The Ranch at the top of the hotel - very good food and great views of San Juan and the water. Local attractions: El San Juan hotel has a Vegas atmosphere whereas the Intercontinental was quiet and relaxed (which we appreciated). We rented a car through the hotel (about $35 for the day) and went to Loquillo Beach one afternoon - much larger beach and calmer water but we recommend going during the week if you can (apparently gets crowded during the weekends). Taco Stand #2 at Loquillo is FANTASTIC - it was recommended to us by our concierge. That morning, we went to El Yunque Rainforest and did some hiking - very good waterfall, scenic views, etc.All in all a very pleasant and relaxing trip. There are definitely nicer places/beaches to visit in the Carribean, so we might not be back to Puerto Rico for some time but we're glad we checked it out.  
<Date>Feb 11, 2008

<Author>jrf_8
<Content>another wonderful stay My husband had I had the pleasure of being the guest of the San Juan Intercontinental from February 3-7, 2008. This was our third stay at this property in the last two years. I am pleased to write that the hotel is continuing to upgrade and take care of their facililties. The rooms have all been redone with lovely colors, new furniture, and flat screen tv's. The gym, while small, has new equipment. The old latice work is down with new ones in its place. The pool area that has been redone for a little over a year is still beautifuls and the landscape has grown in nicely. The staff (many of whom I recognize from the previous stays) are all polite and efficient. I think this is a wonderful hotel, with wonderful employees. It is the perfect place to relax and enjoy a long weekend.

<Author>tappy458
<Content>Fantastic Getaway My husband and I just returned from a four day getaway and found the hotel to be nothing short of fantastic. From the moment our cab arrived at the hotel, the staff was extremely attentive and catered to our every need. We arrived at the hotel at 10 AM and check in was to be at 4pm, but our room was ready the second we arrived. 16th floor, ocean view, the most gorgeous sight of the pool area and behind that, the ocean. Our room was above our expectations..flat screen tv, new clean furniture, updated clean bathroom with a separate vanity area. The king sized bed was extremely comfortable. We went down for lunch at the outside cafe on the beach. We had a very nice meal with a very attentive and polite waitress.my husband had a burger and fries with a coke and I had a chicken quesadilla with an iced tea and the bill came to $30. We found the prices to be reasonable for a resort. After dinner that night we went to the lively lobby bar to have a drink. We then took a walk around the lush landscaped pool area and then down to the boardwalk by the ocean. ( very romantic) For the rest of the evening we went to the casino with many slot machines and various card tables. The casino is beautiful and the waiters/ waitresses were extremely attentive.  The next morning we enjoyed an excellent buffet breakfast on the lower level of the hotel which had everything you could possibly want. (you can order ala carte as well) The waiter was attentive and catered to our every need.  Afterwards we visted Old San Juan. We toured the fort, which was a very interesting step back into the islands history. We then spent the rest of the day walking around town. There were charming old style restaurants and cafe as well as modern places such as Starbucks. There were outlets store for great shopping. The following day we relaxed by the pool and found there to be an ample amount of lounge chairs and cabanas with a good amount in the sun as well as the shade.  Every evening we were there, we went to the casino and walked around the grounds and overall we found this hotel to be one of the nicest we ever stayed at. The staff is polite, helpful and attentive. Whether you are looking for a place to just kick back and relax or to find some fun and excitement, the Intercontinental Hotel is the place to stay.  
<Date>Feb 2, 2008

<Author>Berks1970
<Content>Pricey Hotel - Horrid Guests We chose the San Juan Intercontinental for the last four days of our 10-day trip to Puerto Rico. The rest of the trip was spent at serene, out-of -the-way sort of places in Puerto Rico, so we were thoroughly rested and recharged when we arrived at this hotel. The people at the front desk are very well-trained and polite. We were a tad early and our room wasn't ready, so the bellman took our bags and we went out to the beach-side deck for burgers. When we got to our room an hour later, it was lovely. We had a 12th floor room with an ocean view. Outstanding! My only complaint was thatthe double beds seemed small for two people. There would have been enough room for slightly larger beds, I think. All the other room amenities were very nice.This otherwise lovely property was overrun by rude, arrogant, loud people from a certain East Coast major metropolitan area for the long MLK holiday weekend. They were their usual loud, pushy, obnoxious selves all weekend. Those people were on their Blackberrys and cell phones constantly, everywhere you went, including the pool area, so it was really difficult to relax. I could just feel my blood pressure going up. Several men even smoked cigars by the pool. I was disgusted by this. Who wants to smell that instead of the fresh sea breeze?It was really hard to move to another lounge chair, too, since it was extremely crowded and difficult to find a seat in the first place. Then, when I did find another seat that appeared free, some jerk pushed all my stuff on to the ground while I was swimming. Complaints to the staff elicited little more than shrugs. Later that evening, I went out on my hotel balcony, only to find a man on the balcony below and to the right completely nude and showing himself off to a cheering woman on the patio below. Revolting and low class (more of our countrymen from a certain major East Coast city). The pool is really nice (except they allow smoking anywhere), the beach was nice, too, but the water was full of seaweed. The food and drinks are very high-priced, but I knew this going in, so I sucked it up. I paid $23 for a very tasty quesadilla and Diet Coke. They add the15% tip right into the bill, so just be aware. We had a rental car andknow our way around San Juan pretty well, so we chose to take most of our meals off the property. The valet men were quick and efficient. Noproblems there. The other thing they get you with is one of those stupid resort charges of about $50 per night, so make sure you add that (and about another $50 in taxes) to whatever room rate you find online. Do not befooled!!!This hotel is very close to the airport. This is good and bad. Good because it takes no time at all to get your rental car returned at to the airport, but bad because you can hear jets taking off all day. Notthat big a deal, just something to know before you go. All in all, this was a lovely property with friendly staff, but I doubt we will ever go back. It's perfect for the loud, obnoxious city types requiring every luxury and used to paying exorbitant prices for everything, or for people who want to go to Puerto Rico but are too scared (which is silly) to venture outside of a resort. We'll be looking for something much less crowded, where quiet and solitude are more possible on our next trip.Lastly, we are Priority Club members, but we had no idea that Intercontinental hotels pay Priority Club points at a much lower rate than standard Holidays Inns. We actually received more points for a short stay in a Holiday Inn in Ponce than for our longer, far more expensive stay at the Intercontinental. Frankly, we felt a little ripped off about that.  
<Date>Jan 26, 2008

<Author>Fran000
<Content>great hotel We just came back for a three night stay during the San Sebastian festival. Every hotel room was booked. We originally were booked in the El San Juan Hotel and CAsino through a Jet Blue Package. Jet Blue called us two days before we were ready to leave to say that the hotel overbooked and we had no room. WE were desperate. We spent 5 hours calling every hotel. We lucked out and booked two rooms, oceanfront at the Intercontinental and were very happy with the hotel. The location was great, the rooms were very nice and clean. The casino was good. All the staff were so very friendly and helpful. Even though all the rooms were booked the hotel did not seem crowded. We would definitely recommend this hotel and would return. The only small problem was that there was not much choice for breakfast. There was only one restuarant for breakfast. Also, the hotel is not lively, very quiet with a nice lobby bar and band.

<Author>silverspot
<Content>Gorgeous Property, Had Some Problems My husband and I stayed here because we had such a lovely time at the Intercontinental on Cozumel Island, and we were planning to visit Puerto Rico. We stayed in a special wing of the hotel - I think they call them Club Rooms or something similar. My husband travels for work frequently so we tend to gravitate toward the Intercontinental chain since we know they are reliable. This hotel absolutely had some service problems, but the property itself is absolutely lush, and the pool is gorgeous.We were in Puerto Rico for 5 nights. During our trip, we left for a night and stayed at El Conquistador (about an hour away), and actually wished we had been there the whole time. It was amazing. Our room included access to a special club room that included a concierge, a continental breakfast buffet, and wine and appetizers in the evening. My husband and I were repeatedly struck by the lack of service given by the concierges. The woman in charge (older, distinguished-looking) never remembered us, and constantly asked us which room we were in to confirm we were allowed to be there. The other staff members didn't even glance up when we walked in, even to greet us. It was pretty surprising, considering that this club room was supposed to give us an extra level of service. After a day of receiving little help from the staff in the special club room, we decided to try the regular concierge. We encountered a young 20-something woman with a whole lotta attitude! We asked her for some snorkeling advice, and she was borderline hostile, obviously irritated with her job/life/something. She told us we were in the wrong part of the island and we should have stayed somewhere else! Very funny, considering the concierge is the ambassador to the island to all tourists. We complained to the hotel manager, and they were very kind, sending gifts to our room and calling us to apologize.I can go on and on but I'll stop here. In a nutshell, if you are a business traveler looking for a nice hotel for some pool relaxation - go for it! If you are on vacation, you'll certainly want to look elsewhere. This hotel caters to business folks.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2008

<Author>NicB70
<Content>Fabulous! Chose the Intercontinental for a post-Christmas trip (we got a last-minute air and hotel package via AmericanExpress.com) and were very happy with the hotel--I highly recommend it if you're headed to SJ and it's within your budget. (We probably wouldn't have stayed here if paying full price...but for the price we got online it was phenomenal!)First--the hotel's in a fabulous location. It's a $12 cab ride to the airport, and $19 to Old San Juan. Taxis are readily available. There are a few restaurants across the street (Burger King, Church's Chicken, Subway, and La Casita for Mexican food), as well as a small grocery store. There's a Walgreen's within about a ten minute walk.Check-in was speedy. On arrival, we asked if any oceanview rooms were available and were told it'd be an extra $80/night (when we'd checked online before leaving home, it'd been higher.) We paid for the upgrade and were VERY happy with the room...14th floor with a great view of the pool, ocean, etc. The pool and beach are very clean, and we had no trouble finding lounge chairs. The hotel provides you with nice fluffy towels just as you're entering the pool area, which is very convenient. In our room, the beds were only mediocre, but everything else was so good it wasn't a big deal. There was even better-than-expected toiletries and the water pressure in the shower was great.The hotel was clean and the staff very attentive. We had to wait a couple times for the concierge, but she was helpful and informative about day trips, restaurants, etc. They have a computer next to the concierge desk that allows hotel guests to search for restaurants, activities, etc. all over Puerto Rico. It was very handy...even lets you see restaurant menus. We booked an all-day excursion via the concierge desk that took us to El Yunque, Luquillo Beach, and on a nighttime kayak ride to the bioluminescent bay in Fajardo. It was pricey, but well worth every penny. (The kayak ride in particular was phenomenal!) I was worried the kids (ages 6 and 9) wouldn't be able to go all day, and that the kayak might be too much, but they did fine and would do it all again. The tour guide the hotel uses, Joey, was fabulous and pointed out all kinds of things to the kids (even found them a coqui!) and made food suggestions to keep them happy. I also splurged and got a massage at the spa at the Intercontinental--VERY good massage, though not cheap! If you want to save $$, do NOT order at the pool bar. Drinks are very, very pricey. We didn't eat in the hotel restaurants other than at the outdoor cafe. A pizza there is $14. It looks like it's for one, but it's probably enough for two people (we had a LOT left over...could have saved $$$.) The food was very good, however, so no regrets! If you can book the Intercontinental the way we did (on a last minute deal) and save $$$, do it! The service was phenomenal, as was the hotel's location.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2008
