<Author>Skydog1030
<Content>Wish we were back at the San Juan IC right now ! ! We recently came back from our second visit to the SJIC. What a great place. We stayed there from January 6--9th, 2007 to celebrate our anniversary. Our first visit was in January 2001. I can only agree wholeheartedly with the positive reviews this hotel has received. Our experiences both on this trip and in 2001 were first rate. Let me start by saying that I am VERY particular and I pay attention to detail. In fact , I think of myself as an unpaid AAA hotel critic, with lots of experience but no salary. We booked an ocean view room at $350 per night, including breakfast. Not cheap, but all of the top places in San Juan that I checked also seemed very expensive. They also charge the very annoying add-on esort fee?(as do many other hotels.) which can cause some sticker shock when checking out. Nevertheless, we decided to splurgend are very glad we did.The hotel staff learned we were celebrating our anniversary and boy did they roll out the red carpet. I couldn believe their generosity and thoughtfulness. They upgraded us to a huge suite in the club areaust beautiful and extremely comfortable. And not only did they give us complimentary fruit and chocolate covered strawberries, they also sent us bottle of champagne that was listed at $100 on the room service menu. Wow--did we feel like VIPs.Just for future reference, I walked around the hotel and checked out the standard rooms. The rooms were clean and in good shape, and the hallways were also in good condition. The rooms are average comfortable size, though the bathrooms are somewhat small, and each room has a small balcony. The balconies are really nice to have instead of the typical sealed up room. You can open your door in the morning and let in the balmy Puerto Rican breezes. Wish I was there right now with a cup of Joe.The breakfast buffet was open air, which we prefer in the tropics, with lots of choices including an omelet /egg station.The hotel has a casual restaurant / bar right smack dab on the beach, with some tables actually in the sand. Fabulous location and worth a visit. The food was OK, but pricy, e.g., chicken burger about $13, but unbeatable atmosphere. There is an Italian restaurant, although it was closed for renovation. We didn try the on-site Ruth Chriss Steak House. We tried the casino, but didn have much luck. The lobby is quite stylish and up-to-date, with lots of activity. The pool area was beautiful, with a cool swim-up bar, poolside restaurant with an outdoor bar-b-q chef on duty, which was a great idea. Apparently the entire pool area had just been renovated. When we were there we had no problems finding a place to sit or swim as some prior reviews mentioned. The multiple pool areas and hot tub are big and beautifully landscaped. One of the best restaurants we ate at on the trip was the Metropole, which is a very popular local institution. It just a five minute walk from the hotel. The place gets quite crowded but worth the wait. They serve terrific (and very inexpensive) Cuban/Puerto Rican food. Turn left out of the hotel, cross the street and the restaurant is just past the cockfighting stadium (we didn stop in there.)The hotel concierge, Jossell, couldn have been more helpful. (In fact, the service at the hotel was terrific from everyone we encountered.) Jossell recommended a kayak outing to the bioluminescent bay (only at night), which was a great experience, even though we had never been kayaking before. I think the best time to go, if your timing is right, is on a moonless night. There really is a so much to see and do in San Juan and Puerto Rico, we hope to stay longer on our next trip.  
<Date>Feb 11, 2007

<Author>KMG410
<Content>Good experience at the Intercontinental The basics: Very clean, large room, but nothing out of the ordinary. Very accomodating staff, booked our snorkeling and bioluminescent bay kayaking trip (highly recommended!) with no problems. Ruth's Chris steakhouse is in the hotel, which was great - when we arrived, they said they had no record of our reservation, which was made by the hotel, but quickly sat us anyways even though they were quite busy. We stayed here in mid-August, which was VERY quiet, definitely the beginning of the off-season. The hotel is located on the beach next to a strip of hotels, including the El San Juan (great casino). Across the street is Wendy's, Pizza Hut and a bakery, which is good for a cheap breakfast but be prepared to wait a long time for your bagel - they are very slow. Also check out the Palm restaurant at the El San Juan. The only drawback is if you are into the outdoorsy kind of activities, stay in Fajardo instead. We went on two trips and both of them involved 1+ hour trips to Fajardo by car. Overall, a good experience, there are so many fun things to do in Puerto Rico to keep busy!  
<Date>Jan 29, 2007

<Author>Voyager45
<Content>An excellent choice with a great pool area and beach My partner and I stayed at the Intercontinental this month and at its competitor, the Marriott, a year ago. Both were fine choices, but we liked the Intercontinental better. The great draws are the excellent beach and the beautiful pool area, which is attractively landscaped. Although there was some canned music in the pool area, it wasn't obtrusive and there were areas where one could escape it entirely. The layout was exceptionally attractive for a big hotel. Even on a sunny high season weekend, there were plenty of chairs. The restaurant near the pool is very pleasant. If you're willing to lunch either early or late, you can usually get a table with a delightful beach view. The beach itself is much more appealing than the one near the Marriott, which we rarely used. Our room was quite comfortable. It was definitely worthwhile to pay a bit extra for the ocean view as the view is truly spectacular. The balcony was nice to have, but quite cramped. In this respect, the Marriott was better. Also, the Marriott's furnishings seemed a bit more up to date.  Our only irritating experience at the Intercontinental occurred at 3 a.m. on our first night when a fire alarm forced the evacuation of the entire building. Of course, the false alarm that prompted this wasn't the hotel's fault. But one might have welcomed at least a word or small gesture acknowledging our inconvenience -- perhaps a free cup of strong coffee the next morning to help us wake up. Nothing was forthcoming. But overall, the service was quite efficient. The concierge staff were exceptionally helpful and pleasant. After we asked housekeeping to perform a minor chore, a manager called to make sure that this was done satisfactorily.  On the negative side, the Isla Verde area where the hotel is located is mainly high-rise condos and has less neighborhood atmosphere than Condado, where the Marriott is located. Condado seemed to be better supplied with appealing little restaurants than Isla Verde. But we had a delightful dinner at the Fontana di Roma, incongruously located on the top of the Howard Johnson in Isla Verde.  Overall, we'd definitely take the Intercontinental, but on a snowy New York day, a few days at the Marriott could look fine too.  
<Date>Jan 25, 2007

<Author>bklyn550
<Content>Los Banditos Serves me right for planing a trip spur of the moment. My GF and I decided to take a last minute trip to escape the NYC cold. The El San Juan was booked up and I do not think the Ritz is worth the money due to the fact that San Juan has a foul smelling beach. I am not sure where other reviewers get their opinion of the water here but trust me as I have seen some nice beaches THIS is NOT ONE OF THEM. It is filled with seaweed and smells like bad fish.Our experience began with American Airlines canceling our 6 am flight to San Juan and taking the liberty to rebook us on a 9PM flight. Our travel agent was able to get that taken care of. Once we arrived at the airport we discovered that the flight was severely over booked. terrible turbulence and a great deal of screaming children later we finally arrived at the lovely hotel.After tipping the girl at the front desk we waited only about ten minutes for a room. We were rewarded with one of the highest non smoking ocean view rooms in the place. Lucky us it was on the fourth floor overlooking the main roof of the building. I am sure if the palm trees, the bars, the pool side cafe, the vines, and jungle all fell down there would be a nice ocean view but i Could not see it from my vantage point. One quick trip to the front desk and we were changed to a smoking room on the eighth floor. The hallways smelled of cigars but the room was not at all smoky. My thoughts on the rooms are as follows : The bathroom is too small. The ceiling in the shower is so low that you cant really move around. The door swings open into the space and doe not allow for you to move around in the bathroom. All of the outlets were old and did not even hold onto some plugs. The bed was an old fashioned box spring mattress that had definitely taken a few beatings in its life time. To its is pointed in the direction of the balcony ( so small it should be called a ledge) I think its this was because there is no room to position it other wise. The rooms has a lovely alarm clock CD player that will keep you up at night due to the fact it searches for CD tracks even though the cd is off and nothing is in it. There is a fridge so stock up on water at the supermarket because you may tend to think its free being that the Intercontinental left no price list for items in the fridge. Also there are no prices on the spa menu either. I must say that they do offer a continental breakfast. I think they should call it the Intercontinental Breakfast because they charge for everything so whats the point? I understand that looking at the room service that the going rate for a 1 muffin + I yogurt + two eggs + coffee and juice is now $19 + $ Service fee + 19% gratuity.So these few kinks had me a little annoyed but its was nothing we could not deal with. Having been up since early morning we decided to go by the pool. The pool is lovely the water is a bit cool for some but i loved it. The food pool side is however over priced and not of the quality they should serve given the money the charge. $15 dollar nachos were among my favorite along with the $13 cheese burger that had more chunks of crap in it than anything. They do have a nice BBQ at poolside that has a man with a chef hat doing something. Except when you order your food from the grill menu it comes from inside. The frozen drinks were nice but beware they constantly offer a little extra rum etc which they do charge you for. Also the hotel has taken the liberty of adding their own gratuity onto the bill and then putting a line for additional gratuity. That being said just as i fell asleep poolside i was woken by a lovely woman speaking on here phone about the Barry Manilow Concert she had just attended at a volume not fit for vacation. The worst thing ever done was not making a PR a place where you must pay for roaming. The catch phrase poolside was  Call me its free I am sure this is because everyone wants to hear people chatting it up poolside with their friends back home. There were also a huge number of kids. I love the little ones but there were just so many that they took over the pool. There was hot tub but so many people were in it that I feel it was dirty. Also children were constantly in it even though it specifically says no kids. On the other hand there were a lot of over tanned fat people. When i say fat I am not trying to be mean but the obesity that surrounded this pool made it look like a lake in the Serengeti where hippos would wash.Our first night we had dinner at the Palm which was good if not for the drunken rowdy business people. Take note that from my observation the Intercontinental caters only to business people being that they have a special club for them. They also in my eyes write allot of the reviews here. Hey I would like the place too if my boss was paying. But since I am the boss I think its a huge rip off. The following was so funny I could not bear the get mad that it happened. At 1 am the fire system had a false alarm. Which sent me jumping from my bed like a madman. This alarm system they have is more like an air raid signal. I was convinced we were under attack. It subsided after about a minute. I put my head back down on the lumpy pillow and fell right to sleep. Despite the fact the air conditioner is directly over the bed. Which is nice because cold air does drop down and give you the chills who wouldn't want cold air pumping on their body all night. As i reached my third dream the Air raid signal came on again. This time its was followed with a please evacuate the building warning. Which was lovely and I must say that if you think these hotties look good by the pool (yuck) you should see them in their night things. After walking down the eight flights of stairs and through the back of house we arrived at the pool and were instructed to wait there by a man who then left for a half hour. Finally one of the tourists decided it was safe to go back in the building and we all lined up for the elevator. Since only tow of the three were working for the trip we opted for the stairs. So now that they got false alarm number two out of the way we headed back to go to sleep. I felt that we were owed some type of reimbursement for our troubles. The hotel felt differently. But Assuming it was a false alarm the first time the fire system should have been put on test.That being said we were allowed to sleep in for the rest of the trip. Although since the wooden doors only close when you slam them expect to be woken by people going out to reserve spots by the pool. Also spots on the beach that they hold while they are at the pool or at wendys across the street while they buy themselves some nice treats. Overall the pool is crowded with taken chairs which never materialize any real people. I decided that since Sunday was our last day we would got to Condado to shop at Cartier Louis V etc. So we asked the concierge to see if everything was open. She assured us it was and we hopped in a cab and took the 5 minute ride to Condado to discover that everything was closed. So we took and round trip ride that cost $30 and produced nothing.The Casino is like a nightmare. I have seem better gaming in the back of bars here in NYC. The machines are mostly broken. Or maybe they shut them down if they pay out? Not sure but beware the El San Juan is just a minute away and their Casino is nice. Perhaps they will set up a shell game or three card monty in the lobby because thats the level of gaming to expect from this hotel.Overall I cant say anything bad about the people that work there. The bellmen and the staff are really sweet people working for a living. The hotel chain is horrible. They do nothing for their guests. I love the option of paying for turn down service as well every other thing real hotels do as a courtesy for their guests. Being the people who work there recommend other hotels I guess its fair to saw we have been duped by the intercontinental. Next time I will stay in Fajardo or the El San Juan. I feel truly sorry for all those who were not informed the pool was closed but it seems par for the course from this hotel chain.

<Author>chuckiepool
<Content>this is the best part of san juan the rest of the city I am not too crazy about especially after just been to aruba. we stayed at the club floor which is the lobby level. one benefit is that you avoid waiting for elevator that some people complained about. the balcony faces the garden and pool and very restricted view of the sea, it is bigger than the regular balcony, it can fit in a round table. the garden and pool are beautiful and plenty of lounge chairs. the chairs on the beach are free. the club floor has a nice club room with free continental breakfast and free cocktail hour from 5-7 with all you can drink and snacks. We ventured to OSJ one day, took the bus in front of the hotel all the way to the end, saw part of the city on the way ( taxi would go on freeway). at the pier, there are two free trolley buses you can take. you can get off any time and reboard and see most of OSJ with minimal effort . we had a nice lunch at Il perugino In OSJ.fontana di roma in howard johnson has good food and frienly family style dining. Pikoya in the museum is high end, the food is very good. Atlantica has the best fried calamali but the other items were not so good. we were not impressed with miro and BLT. the pool restaurant at the hotel is excellent for lunch, we ate hot dog and hamburger there three times. Although the hotel is excellent, we don't like SJ that much to warrant a return visit.

<Author>trip4bizandfun
<Content>Terrible Service I guess I was expecting the service at this hotel to match the amenities. I was wrong. The property itself was quite nice, well-located and well-maintained. It's on a nice stretch of very pretty beach. But the service certainly left a lot to be desired and made our stay less than enjoyable. Enough so that I would recommend staying elsewhere (perhaps the El San Juan next door?). We stayed in the Club wing - the section for the Intercontinental's Ambassadors members. The woman in charge of this section should not work with customers; she was actually MEAN to guests - many of those in our party compared notes on the ways she insulted or mistreated us. Her behavior colored all the rest of our experiences at the property. As a result, we found that none of the staff were particularly friendly or warm. Perhaps if she had been nicer, we might not have noticed the lack of graciousness in general, since we didn't have any particularly bad experiences - but we NEVER encountered even one staff member who went out of their way for any of us. (With the exception of the women in the hair salon - they were very nice.) Another recommendation: bring an extra beach towel - there's absolutely NO way they're going to give you a second towel to use at the pool.

<Author>latinjosh
<Content>Awesome Place, good deal and great employees Upon arrival to Puerto Rico's International Airport we could see IC San Juan from the plane, it simply looked amaizing. Upon arrival the Bellman simply was polite, made us feel welcome. And upon enterring the Main Lobby, that is were our experience really started. Brenda, agent who assisted was just charming, thou we had to wait for the room as we arrived early. The Concierge's definetely are the best I have ever dealt with, they are simply GREAT. Jossell is quite the star performer, never, ever says no, if you want it, he will see it happens, what a positive attitude. They were able to plan in a blink of an eye all of our dinner reservations as they took their time to really get to know you, they even asked me if there was any dietiry and/or special need they needed to know before suggesting any Restaurants, now that is professionalism! He gave us options in price ranges, upscale, moderately priced and even a few hidden gems. He offerred options for tours and even adivised of of those tour attractions that we could perhaps do on our own so with Jossell's honesty we saved money as well. Rooms are comfortable, we had a lovely pool view that we could see the ocean partly, next time I'll splurge and pay the extra for an ocean view. Had a minor mishap with the coffee maker, dialed the Concierge and within 5 minutes a new one was delivered and the Concierge, Nestor called back to verify that everything was ok!! The Hotel if a WiFi property and it works fantastic. Maids are incredible, I asked for early turn down and they were right on the ball. Food is great at the beach area but, a little expensive thou. The only draw back, no pool entertainment at all. For a Caribbean Property that I expected latin music tobe play along the beach and as a Resort I expected caribbean games such as doing the limbo but, that never happenned. Upon check out bell captain was requested and was up in the room within a reasonable waiting period. Check out was done by the Concierge, Jossell who really made it difficult for us to depart as he is so professional and corteous and he offerred to even print our boarding passes! I don't know about the other reviews printed here that speak so poorly about IC San Juan but, INTERCONTINENTAL SAN JUAN ROCKS!Thanks for an incredible vacation!Josh

<Author>gunner27
<Content>Loved It! We just returned from a stay at the Intercontinental and we LOVED it! When we got there (before check in) we were upgraded to an oceanfront room on the 14th floor and we were so excited. The room was very clean (no smell). The noise from the airport wasn't an issue. The hotel staff was very friendly. The bell captains out front work their butts off and are very helpful. I thought it was worth every penny and I don't usually splurge on hotel rooms. My only complaint would be the elevators were a little slow and the bartendars didn't go out of their way to engage in conversion ,but nothing that would keep me away, they weren't rude by any means. I would definitely return. It is pricey, but so are alot of the hotels. The pool are is amazing! There are many fast food places within walking distance. Isla Verde beach is very nice. Everyone in the hotel speaks english and that was my experience throughout the island. I'd definitely return!

<Author>shawsh23
<Content>Rip-Off My fiance and i went over the summer. When I called to make a reservation I was told that the Garden/Executive Suite were worth the extra money b/c they have private gardens. Since the price was not much more and it included continental bkfast, I agreed. When we were taken to our room, we were overwhelmed by the smell of mold. Unfortunately all of the garden rooms except maybe for one or two do not get much sunlight. The room and the hallway smelled like a moldy basement. When we complained we were moved to an ocean view room, which they tried to charge us more for. They claimed that since we booked so far in advance the rates had gone up. We negotiated to stay at the same price we were paying for the Executive Suite. SO basically we got ripped off. And then to top it off there is a resort fee which I believe was $30 a day, this was not mentioned at anytime prior to our trip.The ocean view room had a nice view, but it was outdated and the patios are so small you cant really sit comfortably on the patio.The pool although looks nice, is overcrowded and to small for the number of people it accomodates. the place is filled with children, and the Jacuzzi was luke warm and also had a foul smell to it (it too is in the shade most of the day. The concierge was no help either. We asked for a reccomendation for a restaurant in Old San Juan. When we arrived we were diappointed to find that we were the only people in the restaurant and the restaurant also smelled like mildew.Needless to say, we were disappointed. I do not reccomend this hotel. If you cant afford to stay at the Ritz (neither could we), try the El san hotel, which is in the same price range as the intercontinental.

<Author>NewYorkShutterbug
<Content>Could have been great Having stayed at this hotel several years ago, I was disappointed at how it has been allowed to deteriorate. Our room smelled of mold, the paint in the bathroom was peeling and the door was cracked and warped. The hot tub by the pool was a dirty green during the first two days of our stay, and it was only after repeated complaints that the water was drained and changed. There was a limit of one beach towel per person until several complaints were made by guests, which resulted in two towels being given. It was also galling to have to pay extra to rent a beach umbrella. One would have expected a four star hotel to provide one as a part of the service.The food was expensive and mediocre and my daughter became ill from eating the quesadillas at the beachfront bar.On the other hand, the oceanview was a dream and the friendliness of the staff was wonderful.However, the cost and the four star rating certainly did not add up to the reality of the hotel.

<Author>Travelling_Wiz
<Content>We liked the Intercontinental We enjoyed the Intercontinental. Unlike the prior reviewer, we arrived very early (off of a cruise ship) and they got us into a room within an hour (about 12:30). The room was nice and well appointed. We did not have a view - but honestly didn't expect one since I had booked my companies contract rate - which is extremely reasonable. The new pool is lovely. We had fabulous service at the Terraz restaurant (outside by the pool) for both lunch and breakfast - but it is pricey! The breakfast buffet ends up at about $25 with tax and tip. It is good though! We had dinner at Ruth Chris which was very good but expensive - but it is expensive everywhere. On balance, we had a nice, restful visit to San Juan and enjoyed our stay at the Intercontinental.

<Author>TheThreeOfUs
<Content>Has Potential, But Needs MUCH Improvement This hotel needs some work. A lot of work, actually. It's obvious they are trying to do just that, but in the meantime, the rooms are very, very outdated. The furnishings and amenities are way behind what we've come to expect in a hotel at $400/night. The doors, trim, air conditioning vents, balcony railing and plumbing fixtures are all in really awful, outdated condition. They should have been updated 10 years ago -- they are *well* beyond their prime. If you are accustomed to seeing flat panel TV's, contemporary furniture and duvets on the beds, this is definitely not the hotel for you.On the plus side, the beds are comfortable, the rooms are spacious and nicely arranged (other than the bathroom, which is the smallest hotel bathroom I've seen in years.) The beach access is fantastic and the beach itself is very nice. The view from the oceanview rooms is not going to be beat. There are a few restaurants (ie: other hotel restaurants) within walking distance, which is a nice plus, and the restaurants in the hotel (with the exception of the downstairs breakfast restaurant) are nice.The worst part of this hotel is that they had our email address since the day I made the reservation several months ago and we were never notified about the pool renovations. That is really an unacceptable oversight. (And I am probably being generous in calling this an 'oversight.') I cannot even begin to imagine the disappointment this would have created had my stay there been a family vacation! Until the pool is complete, I would be not recommend this hotel, unless you do not mind staying in an outdated room at a resort with no pool. Even when the pool is complete, I would personally not stay here again unless the entire hotel were fully renovated. We debated between this hotel and the Ritz-Carlton, and there is no question that next time, that will be our choice.  
<Date>Nov 10, 2006

<Content>Wowed at the Intercontinental San Juan We stayed at the IC San Juan November 2-4, 2006 as part of a NY-based Management Society group convention of @200. We selected the IC for the 2006 Annual Convention based on our great experience back in 1998. Our group was absolutely wowed by the conference and banquet services during the convention.Staff throughout, were helpful, professional and friendly. Services were efficient and seamless.The property is undergoing renovations which will position this hotel uniquely, among competing properties. We stayed at Club level rooms. Renovations in this area are right up there with those of European hotels, and certainly with the rest on the mainland and locally with like-accommodations. While they are not promoting their beds and pillows, they are more than heavenly! They have not spared any detail with respect to the convenience, ambiance, beauty and comfort of Club-level rooms. We were impressed by the measures of the Security staff that provided a sense of comfort and safety with their discreet and elegant presence. We look forward to seeing the completion of pool renovations that can already be assessed as being Big League.A Wowed Customer.

<Author>GoHerd
<Content>OK for Holiday Way below Intercontinental Quality The hotel is OK at best. It does have a couple of high points but is in need of much work. Here is my breakdown after spending a week at the hotel.Rooms:The rooms are in pretty run down condition. They are old and outdated and not very clean. Probably the worst part of the entire hotel is the rooms. They need a lot of work. All rooms ending in 05 such as 1405 are very small because of the stairwell. Stay away from these rooms. The city view side is not bad it does face the airport a couple of blocks away but the windows are fairly well insulated. You do have a distant view of the bay. Casino:The casino is very run down compared to the neighboring hotels the Ritz, El San Juan and Courtyard. We did not win any money at the IC but did well at all the other casinos. It is very smoky, full of rowdy locals and many of the machines do not work. Beach: The beach is nice for a fairly poputated stretch ot sand. Water and sand are both clean. Warm water in November probably around 80 degrees. There are reefs right off the beach here but not recommended to snorkel due to motor boats and jet skis. The beach is a big plus. Chairs from the IC and umbrellas are free.Pool: Was closed and has been closed for a couple of months they keep backing up the reopening date from early OCt to late to mid of November. The current condition is probably reflective of a December opening. It looks like it is nice but not open. Many checking in were very upset and we witnesses many confrontations with management because they were not disclosing this if you already had reservations. It is in very small print on their website.Surroundings:It is San Juan. Probably not the safest of cities. But we felt safe walking at night in the immediate 10 blocks of the hotel. There were a lot of police patroling the streets. You just have to be smart you do not want to be walking around by your self or with all your money on you. But it appeared Carolina where the hotel is was a better area of Puerto Rico. Hope this helps. We would go back to San Juan however we would look for new accomodations next.  
<Date>Nov 5, 2006

<Author>SDSTraveller
<Content>Nice Hotel, Relaxing Environment but still Overpriced Our three day visit started Oct. 22. The Intercontinental San Juan Spa and Resort is probably one of the nicer hotels along the Isla Verde beach front. However, compared to hotel spa and resorts found on the mainland particularly in Las Vegas it would only rank as average. The pool was being remodeled therefore it was unavailable to guests. This didn't present a problem for me because I enjoyed the beach and ocean which had easy access from the hotel. We reserved a city view room but we told we had been upgraded to a deluxe city view. The difference was simply that the deluxe city view was on a higher floor (5 and above) instead of (2 - 4). Our view was actually very nice. We could see the airplanes as they landed and when there were no planes you actually had a distance (very distance) ocean view. The hotel is only 10 minutes from the airport but the noise of the planes didn't bother us. Others have written that the walls of the hotel rooms are thin, that is correct. The noise didn't really bother me as much as it bothered by roommate. One thing that annoyed us both was the television speaker in the bathroom. It was loud and intrusive. We actually had the maintenance staff cut it off. Instructions should have been left for the guests so we could have cut it off ourselves.The Intercontinental was nice but I think very much overpriced. San Juan for tourists probably has seen better days. I think passing through San Juan before going on a cruise is fine but as a final destination youe better off going to St. Thomas or Aruba.  
<Date>Oct 30, 2006

<Author>DJACKS
<Content>Great hotel! I found a great deal for this trip to PR through Liberty Travel. My husband and I stayed at the Intercontinental from 10/11 - 10/15. We arrived in San Juan at 11am on Wednesday and the hotel allowed us to check in that early. We were booked for a city view room but were upgraded to a ocean view on the 16th floor. We also had complimentary breakfast each morning which was great. The food will definitely fill you up for the whole day. We were still disappointed about the pool being closed. I called before my arrival to see when it would be open and was told it would be open by 10/15. When I got there they said the end of the month. You can use the pool at the Holiday Inn as an accomodation, however, the one day we planned on using it, the hotel was having an event and we couldn't go. The hotel staff is VERY PLEASANT. They address you by name every time you call and if you need anything, they are there in a minute and even call to make sure everything was taken care of afterwards. Outside the hotel, the people were no where near as friendly, and I wasn't impressed with the rest of San Juan. But if you want to go somewhere to relax on a nice beach, this is the place. Too bad the pool was closed. The pictures looked beautiful.

<Author>1Member
<Content>Just returned from long weekend Just returned from a long girl's weekend at the Intercontinental. We had orginally booked the El San Juan but after reading all the terrible reviews, we changed. We were checked into our rooms with no problems even though it was only noon (the people who work here are extremely nice). The room was fine (we were on the city side). Nicely sized, clean and the beds were pretty comfortable. The bathroom is very small but there's a seperate area with a mirror and outlets that's very useful. Like some other reviews mentioned, the walls are very thin, you can hear everything in the hallways, but it was never an issue while we were there. The pool area is very nice, a little wear and tear here and there but they keep the area very clean. We never had any problems getting chairs together and there is a lot of shade for those who don't want to be in the sun all day. From what I understand, they're starting a pool rennovation on September 5th. We didn't spend much time on the beach but the area in front of the hotel had the softest sand I've ever felt and the waves were nice and calm. By the pool there is the pool bar (the rum punch is really good) and a restaurant between the pool and beach that's good for lunch. A word to the wise- the drinks are kind of pricey. It cost $46 a pop for the four of us to get drinks so it starts to add up. But if you're inclined, you can walk across the street to the market and buy a whole bottle of rum for $12. We ate at the sushi restaurant the first night and it was so-so. The other nights we went to the Parrot Club in OSJ (always a favorite) and then to the Palm at the El San Juan next door, also very good. Overall, if you want to be near Old San Juan and the El San Juan for the casino, clubs, etc but don't want to pay Ritz prices, this hotel is a good choice.  
<Date>Sep 5, 2006
<Rating>3	4	3	3	3	4	4	-1

<Author>Linda820
<Content>Would Return to the InterContinental San Juan Resort In A Minute! I stayed at the InterContinental in San Juan Puerto Rico from August 21 - 26, 2006. The reviews I read on Trip Advisor prior to going are very accurate. I cannot say enough about this Hotel and about Puerto Rico. This was my first trip to Puerto Rico, accompanied by my kids, 19  17 and my mom. The most extraordinary thing about this hotel, as others have raved, is the service. I have stayed in many five star hotels and the service at this hotel exceeded all of them. The reason this hotel probably gets the four star rating is because the rooms could definitely use a little updating. Instead of two full size mattresses, they should splurge and get queens. This is one of my two complaints from this trip (I will share the second complaint later)! Our check-in was very quick and being the hotel is five minutes from the airport, our flight landed at 1 pm and we were in our room by 1:45pm. We had a problem with our in-room safe and within 2 minutes someone came to fix it. We also did not have enough towels and within 2 minutes of calling the front desk, the towels were delivered clean  hot right out of the dryer. The front desk even called one minute after receiving the towels to make sure that they arrived. Every single employee in this hotel was friendly and helpful. A room with a view of the ocean is a must!!! The extra money spent for this was worth it. We were overlooking the ocean and the pool - definitely heaven on earth!We ate at Momoyama/Japanese, which was okay. However, Pasaggio/Italian should not be missed. We ate the breakfast buffet at La Terrazza, which was pricey and just okay. The restaurant by the beach - Meditteranian was one of our favorites for lunch with a view to die for and excellent salads. The pool area was beautiful and clean. My second complaint about this hotel was definitely the prices of the drinks. It cost $8.00 for a beer by the pool, which was the same as a mixed drink. I think this was the most I ever paid for a beer. It is recommended to go across the street to the supermarket and purchase snacks and your beer there, where you will pay $8.00 for a six pack. Some of the local places to make note of was Platos for local food, which was excellent (a few blocks from the El San Juan hotel) and Piu Bello for coffee and ice cream (also a few blocks from the El San Juan - make a left out of the InterContinental). The bakery across the street that others have raved about in the reviews has great food, but unfortunately we had terrible service - it is probably best to order your food at the counter. We went to Mi Casita Restaurant - next to the bakery for breakfast one morning and the service and food were horrible - everything was ice cold. Being New Yorkers - I guess we are not used to the slow, very laid back service. STAY AWAY FROM THE PONDEROSA STEAKHOUSE FOR BREAKFAST - we found out the hard way. On our trip we visited the El Yunque Rainforest , which was great. We spent an afternoon in Old San Juan, which was fantastic - great shopping, however, the stores close too early - around 6 pm. We ate in a great restaurant in Old San Juan - Barrachina, which claims to be the home of the original Pina Colada - and they were the greatest! This trip was really enjoyable and I would go back to Puerto Rico and stay in the InterContinental again - I could not have asked for better!  
<Date>Sep 4, 2006

<Author>Shkrel
<Content>Intercontinental was Outstanding! Our family just returned from PR last night. It was our first trip there and we had a fantastic time. We are already talking about returning!The Intercontinental was wonderful. The staff was very helpful and pleasant. The pool- fantastic! There were more than enough chairs and umbrellas- it never seemed crowded the whole time we were there. Although the hotel is on a public beach, it felt more like a private beach. No complaints!As far as the room is concerned- it was clean and comfortable. There is a lock box in the room, but even if we left anything out-we didn't have to worry about it. I booked a city view room and my entire family loved it! We usually have ocean view rooms but I thought it would be nice to have something to look at at night. We were not disappointed- we loved the view. You could see mountains in the background, as well as the city. My 11 year old loved watching the airplanes coming in too!For food, there were plenty of choices- but it could get pricey so be prepared! There is a very good Italian restaurant in the hotel, but the service was a little slow the night we were there. We also tried the steak house at the hotel- very pricey but delicious. (Hint: if you have kids that are pickey eaters, do not bring them here!)We had most of our meals out at the pool bar or at the beach side restaurant. We enjoyed both of them!Talk to the concierge about arranging a snorkeling trip out of Farjardo- it was to die for! Rosie (the concierge) first suggested snorkeling to us. We had never been snorkeling before and were a little hesitant, but this experience absolutely made our trip!! You will love it. We were provided very comfortable transportation to and from the marina (which is about 45 minutes away). Lunch and drinks were included on the boat- I believe it was through East Wind Tours. Our tour guide on the boat, Arturo, was very entertaining.We also went to the rainforest and I wouldn't take that trip again. It was beautiful, but very uncomfortable traveling in a 15 passenger van. I believe it was through CB Coach. We were packed like sardines into the van, and at times the tour guide shut off the air conditioning when we were going up! It was an uncomfortable ride to say the least! Our tour guide, Debbie, was very informative but she seemed more interested in giving us her shpiel than in answering any of our questions that might throw her off track from her speech!If you plan on going to the Intercontinental, join the Priority Club. I believe we paid $150 to join, but received a free night stay along with other ammenities after joining. We also were upgraded to the top floor at no extra cost. We definitely plan on returning- it was that good!  
<Date>Aug 10, 2006

<Author>kiplill
<Content>we didn't want to leave We would recomend this resort to anyone looking for a relaxing and enjoyable time. While it is true that the food and drinks in the resort are more expensive than most, the service and attention to detail from the staff could not be beat. Great accomodations...clean and well maintained with much ambiance. Beautiful pool and direct access to the beach with water sports. Complimentary beach chairs and towels are provided by staff. We were provided with a complimentary upgrade before we even asked!! We were also offered a late check out with use of full facilites and a hospitality room to change prior to our late departure flight in the early evening. We recommend the beachside and swim up bars.....gotta try the Voodoo Juice....it wil be a bucket of fun. For breakfast, we would recommend eating at Mi Casita across the street. It is great food at reasonable prices. Lupi's Sports Bar and Grill...just down the street is another good place for a relaxing, casual dinner. There is also a supermarket within easy walking distance to buy your bottled water, sodas and snacks, because it was extremely expensive in the resort...i.e $3.00 for a small bottle of water. Expect to give a $300 deposit on a credit card upon registration for incidental room charges....which works out great for the bars as you don't need to carry cash. Overall, we had a wonderful time and cannot wait to go back!!

<Author>my3ds
<Content>Great Stay! We just returned from staying at the Intercontinental. This was our first trip to PR and this is one of the best trips ever! The hotel was beautiful and the staff, no matter where, were very accommodating! We met so many nice people from all over the U.S. We were complimentary upgraded to an oceanfront room on the 15th floor so the view was breathtaking! The bed faces the window so waking up to the view each morning was more than I could ask for! Yes, the Intercontinental is a little expensive -for drinks mainly but we went to the store and bought our own and kept it in the room. Dinners were great - we ate at the Momoyama and the cost was no more than what we pay back home to go to dinner. We went across the street to the little strip mall to have breakfast which was very good also. One day we ate breakfast at the Ponderosa which was surprisingly good too!We took the Old San Juan tour and the Bacardi tour and they were both fun - not enough time in Old San Juan but we went back the next night and it was just wonderful!! Outside vendors, music and dancing in the streets, outdoor cafes, etc. We did not take the bus to town since we didn't want to be on it for over an hour for a 15 min. ride by taxi - there were four of us so we split the cost - it was much more convenient. This is a fabulous place - I can't wait to return!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Intercontential Hotel good  My expectations were not what I was expecting. I was upgraded because of my club membership. Unfortunately, My room was located on the city side. I felt like I was not away from home since I come from the city. At night I could hear the planes go by for landing. The A.C. was making noise too. The next day, I asked to change my room to the beach side. Of course they wanted more money. I refuse to pay. I told them I cannot sleep at night and I was not spending another night there. I finaly asked to speak to the Mgr. I was given another room with a pool view. I was downgraded to one room but the room was sunny and had a nice view and I felt like I was on vacation. I inspected the room first before I decided to accept. The pool was big and nice.The ocean is the Atlantic ocean, so it isn't beautiful and clear like the Carribean. The beach is big compare to other beaches in P.R. The hotel is old but clean. The staff are alright. The resturants are good but expensive. If you venture out get ready for the hassles of waiting .

<Author>alerick
<Content>Great Location and a great beach Stayed: June 29-July 5 2006. The goods are:  The hotel is located right next to the San Juan Hotel and you can just walk over and enjoy the Club Brava(mix) and lounge (Spanish Band) that they have. Has one of the best pools of all of the Hotels in Isla Verde.Great rooms extremely nice beach (they have servers on the beach). Jet Skis, Banana Boat, etc. Avail.Bads:Expensive drinks and food (avg. drink $10) **You must try their frozen drinks MargartitaPool closes at 10pm, Pool Bar at 6pm (However, there is another pool bar open)Thin walls (Try to get the room at the end of the hallway)Recommendations:Try not asking the locals for directions; they are not good with directions (you will see)stick to the police officers/taxis/visitor center. Do not take the Bus to Old San Juan. You will hear that it is better. However, is time sonsuming and can get crowed. It took us 45 min. to catch it and a whole hour and 10 min to get there. The same thing happen coming back. Do not be afraid to rent a car and wonder out with a map. There is a supermarket down the street that stays open 24 hrs (not the one directly across from the hotel) and buy water bottles some snacks and a bottle of your favorite liquor. This will save you a lot of $$MUST GO TO PINONES. Is a long strip about a 10 min drive E from Hotel. They have a lot of fish and food and music. Some suvernier shops too. (cheap)**try Pinonos,bacalaito, alcapurriasThere is a Walgreen within walking distance where you can get Cash Back (avoid ATM fees) By the way, they are call ATH (A Toda Hora) not ATM  
<Date>Jul 8, 2006

<Author>crisn11
<Content>So So Resort My husband and I just got back from a 5 day 4 night stay at the Intercontinental San Juan. I must say, that the concierge Jossell Velasquez was so warm and welcoming as well as efficient at his job. He made all of our dinner reservations and suggested many things to do. As a matter of fact they upgraded our room to ocean view free of charge. The entire staff was professional and exceeded our expectations, but thats about it. Aside from the staff we would have to say that our room even with the ocean view was small and just like many others have posted before the walls are paper thin. We could hear everything from the hallway. The japanese restaurant Momoyama and Ruth's Chris were both outstanding. Overall we had a great time because we ventured out to Old San Juan and to the Ritz Carlton which is superior in everyway. If you are going to be in the San Juan area a dinner at Prime 787 at the Ritz is a must. Very expensive but worth every penny. Hope this was helpful didn't mean to drag on. Oh pool at the Intercontinenatal was ok, we much preferred the beach where the sand was soft and so was the water.

<Author>omegaspring95
<Content>Here right now! We're in PR as we speak and I just had to post! Don't believe the negative reviews! It's great at the IC. Hotel provides more than adequate accommadations in a GREAT location. We are active. . .Walked the entire beach daily, went into the RITZ (beautiful but snobby), El San Juan (live salsa at night, great for people watching-- have to see lobby, right next door), The Water Club (roof top bar, sushi, great!) and more. Driving is aggressive but not bad. Got a car yesterday and did the rainforest, Laquillo and Old San Juan. WHEW! Great new Italian restaurant (Sofia, owned by Parrot Club guy, Marco at bar A+!!) Had so much fun, we'r keeping the car today too! Online getting more info form foruns to decide where to go next! Friendly people here. A retired woman just struck up conversation with us yesterday in Old San Juan. She told us about the history of the buildings, La Princesa (the old prison) and the military buildings! It was great. Mind the pigeons~ You have to explore this great island! Book the IC! You won't be disappointed!

<Author>tpersis777
<Content>Perfect Vacation My boyfriend and I stayed at the Intercontinental from June 26th to 30th. We had a GREAT time. Everyone says the Intercontinental is pricey, but we got a really good package deal with a garden/pool view, and none of these hidden fees people keep talking about . We ended up on the 6th floor and you could still see the ocean.Definitely get an oceanview room if you stay, like everyone says. We had a hospitality room when we arrived on the city side. No comparison. Also when we left we received a hospitality room on the 16th floor ocean view...WOW! I see why its the higher the better. You could see the whole beach and beyond from this room. It was just gorgeous. I saw nothing wrong with the lobby, I thought the hotel was very nice and clean, and the grounds were beautiful. The pool was really nice (and clean) too, although we are beach people and never went in! Food is what everyone says, expensive at the hotel (but good!), and so many ways to work around this. We went to Mi Casita for many inexpensive meals and thought it was great. Metropol (for cuban) is also just a short walk away. The location of this hotel was excellent. On one of the days we rented a car and drove ourselves to Old San Juan, defintely worth the short trip to this beautiful city. Then we drove to Fajardo and did the kayak bio bay tour. Also DEFINTITELY worth it, a once in a lifetime experience.Overall I would highly recommend this hotel and a trip to Puerto RIco. The staff of the hotel and the people of Puerto Rico in general were all very nice and helpful. The only complaint we have is that the hotel's beach had quite a bit of debris on it. Straws from drinks and people just not picking up after themselves (so we would!). The beachside drink service was nice if you want to splurge for it, and so is the beach chair service, but perhaps they should have someone cleaning up the beach periodically as well.Any other questions feel free to email me,thanks,Tracy  
<Date>Jul 5, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great stay We recently stayed at the InterContinental for 5 days. Our experience was great, and as a result we enjoyed San Juan more than we expected. People comment about the lobby- who cares? The beach was great as was the pool. The staff will issue you a wristband and deliver your chair to the beach. You feel secure at the hotel and pool, and there is an in room safe for your valuables. I would not recommend eating at the hotel- why go to Ruth Chris when you are in Puerto Rico? Buy your breakfast and lunch stuff at the store right across the street and use the in-room fridge. I would consider buying your alcohol there too- the drinks at the hotel are pricey and not that good. Save your money and go to the excellent restaurants in the evening (Pikayo, Lemongrass, or some good ones on OSJ like Parrot Club).The room was not fancy but very comfortable. Clean, quiet at night and unlike many hotels in San Juan half the rooms face the ocean. Get one with an ocean view. Service was excellent, fast check in and great follow up with any requests. There were plenty of taxis and a very helpful valet staff. Far superior to the other similar prices hotels in San Juan.

<Author>Loripie21
<Content>Perfect location! Great Hotel! My husband and I stayed here Jun 22- 25 and had a great time. The hotel was extremely clean and the staff very polite. The pool area was very nice and there were lots of chairs in either sunny spots or shade spots. The Isle Verde Beach was great for walking and people watching and always had lots going on i.e. jet skis, banana boats, etc. We ate dinner at Ruth's Chris Steakhouse and were blown away by the quality of the food and the service- both spectacular (worth the price). We also walked over one night to the Hotel El San Juan to see what everyone was talking about and were stunned. The hotel lobby is one of the most beautiful i had ever seen- take the advice stay at the Intercontinental but go have a drink at the Hotel El San Juan. The only complaint i have is the resort prices. A beer at the pool at the IC was, with tip, $9.00 USD WOW- we live in St. John in the USVI and that is the biggest resort price rip off we have ever seen. A small martini at the Hotel ESJ was $12.00 USD- YIKES! Luckily there is a store across the street and at the IC they will allow you to bring drinks, snacks, whatever and use the minifridge in the room. Also -after having lunch by the pool one day and paying $83.00 USD for chicken wings, a hamburger, a small pepperoni pizza, 2 beers, and 2 pina coladas we decided to walk across the street where you will also find an assortment of fast food and local restaurants for much much cheaper and that will also taste good!!! I give the hotel and the location and A. We will for sure be coming back!  
<Date>Jun 26, 2006

<Author>mia1972
<Content>Adequate hotel on the beach My husband and I went to Puerto Rico for 5 days. We stayed at 3 different hotels during our stay, and the IC was the last hotel for one night. The location is good because it is right on Isla Verde Beach as it is hard to park a car in this part of town just to use the beach. The water here is very clean and blue-green, not clear as it is on other islands in the Caribbean. It is very calm unlike the wild waves in Pinones, where most of the locals go to swim or in Rio Grande. The only good thing about the hotel is the beach. Otherwise, it is just ok. The lobby is small and not as grand as you would expect it to be. It feels cramped with its low ceilings. The hotel, El San Juan, next door has a lobby and shopping gallery, which makes it feel 5 times bigger than the IC. On Friday evening the IC was very dead compared to El San Juan as it has no disco and just a tame jazz band playing near the bar. The room itself looks very outdated and has very unappealing decor. Not tropical or even modern at all. Could have been any room at a 4 star hotel in Ohio. We did eat at one of the restaurants, Chris Ruth Steakhouse, which always has excellent service and steaks. This is the 2nd trip we have made to Puerto Rico and the 2nd time we ate there, and it has always been exemplary and each time we see Latino celebrities. This being our second trip, we decided instead of spending 5 days straight at Isla Verde like we did the first time that we would hotel hop. It is a great idea to rent a car and drive from place to place instead of being stuck at Isla Verde and taxiing into San Juan. There is not much to do or see if you walk around Isla Verde. There are no chic shops or boutiques as you would expect. We also stayed 2 days at the Westin Rio Mar resort near El Yunque Rain Forest, which was an excellent resort that has what you expect for a 4 to 5 star hotel, not like the IC.  
<Date>Jun 19, 2006

<Author>jen196767
<Content>Great hotel with great service My husband and I went to the Intercontinental for our 10 year anniversary. We loved the hotel! We were on the 14th floor with an ocean view room. Room was spacious and extremely clean. The first night they brought us champagne, fruit, and chocolate covered strawberries (free of charge), since it was our anniversary. Pool area is beautiful, surrounded by palm trees and waterfalls, with a swim up bar (the rum runners are excellent). They had a large, outdoor jacuzzi tub. Bottled water is complimentary, and they do not limit the amount you can have. Food is a little pricey, but that is par for the course for an upscale hotel. We had lunch outside and thought the food was very good. The breakfast buffet is excellent, worth the $19.95-great selection of foods. The service is unbelievable-we did not open the lobby door once-there was always someone there to open the door and greet us!!!!! The concierge, Nestor, was so helpful. I recommend taking an excursion to Las Calebras and Flamenco Beach (supposedly one of the most beautiful beaches in the world). We did not have dinners at the hotel, we preferred to sample the local cuisine. We ate at Parrot Club in Old San Juan, Ajili Mojili in the Condado area, and Barrachina's (down the street from the hotel). All three restaurants were very good. Cab fares got a little pricey ($20 one way to Old San Juan and $14 one way to the Condado area). Although we did not hear rave reviews about the El San Juan, we were told to go inside and see the lobby. I have to say, the hotel lobby was beautiful! Our trip to the Intercontinental was a memorable one!!!  
<Date>Jun 12, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Don't go there! My husband and I, along with our 14 month old son went to Puerto Rico and stayed at the Intercontinental over the Memorial Day weekend. It was not the best trip wee taken though wee traveled to the Olympics this winter in Italy and with a far younger baby to Mexico and other parts of the US. So here are a few reasons why we would probably not recommend traveling to Puerto Rico.The Intercontinental Hotel itself is very nice. It has a beautiful lobby with marble floors, and dark wood accents. But the walls are EXTREMELY thin. The hotel was hosting various proms, Jr. proms and weddings during our stay and had many teenage guests. They get into their rooms at 3:00 or 4:00 am and have the parties continue in their rooms and all the while it seemed like someone had just stepped into our very own room. I could clearly hear their conversations, the steps they took across their room, and even what they were watching on TV. These events woke us up 3 out of the 5 nights we stayed. Also, the hotel is located in a tourist area with various other hotels, however once you walk across the street you feel like you are stepping into an impoverished urban area with drunk men and scantily clad women on the street.The food throughout Puerto Rico was very hit and miss. Yes, the hotel has three restaurants (none that we visited) but the day we did venture to get something to eat in their poolside restaurant we had an $85 tab for a very plain green salad and a sandwich. Far too expensive for what we actually received. I was much more satisfied when I walked across the street to get some far tastier Puerto Rican food for about $8 a dish. I recommend the Asopao de Pollo (Chicken Gumbo). My baby and husband really enjoyed that. All in all I think we received the best food and service on our second night there when we went to the shopping center across the street for some (of all things) Chinese food.We went sightseeing as part of the hotel tours to the Bacardi Rum Distillery (you get two free drinks and a very well put together tour of the distillery and Bacardi history), Camuy caves (interesting), the Arecibo Observatory, and to old San Juan. We also visited the Fort of San Cristobal and the El Moro Fort, on an alternate day when we decided to go back to Old San Juan on our own. Taxi fair to iejo San Juan?was about $20 each way. One of our tour guides advised us to request a receipt from the taxis as a method of keeping them honest.We had several incidents that really tested our patience while on this trip. On one occasion I asked the hotel concierge to direct me to a restaurant where I could see the sunset but she thought I wanted to have dinner on the actual beach. After going back and forth with her about what I wanted she directed me to a restaurant down the street from the hotel that was nowhere near the beach and was completely empty when we showed up. We ended up walking to a restaurant that sat on the pier which had the worst food and service wee ever received. It also seemed like I was at Spring Break central with loud reggaeton music and all the young people getting ready to start their partying. Not a place for families with young children.  
<Date>Jun 8, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Puerto Rico Before my trip I read several on-line reviews and like always, I was sceptical. We arrived in at the Intercontinental Saturday May 13th approx 2:30 P.M. , after a nice smooth filght. Check in was quick and staff very courtious. We left our luggage with them and went on our way, straight to the beach side grill. The food was good, but very expensive, $12.00 for a hot dog/fries and a hamburger was the same--just add $2.00 for a slice of cheese. The view is beautiful tropical folliage, white powdery sand, and aqua ocean on one side and a lush tropical landscaped grounds with pool/pool bar. Of course you always have to have that pina colada floating or sitting at the pool bar-I just love that whole idea! But again very expensive, $20.00 for two. Only and hour has pasted and we're going up to the room. The room is pretty large, well cleaned and maintained with a king size bed, stocked mini bar, dresser, and tv. Inbetween the main room and the bath room is a nice vanity area to put on make up. Then the bathroom, very clean, nice marble tile , full tub/shower (excelllent water pressure), a hair dryer, iron/board, and even a scale (not that I got on it) I'm on vacation. Our room over looked the front of the resort, that was kinda cool to watch the planes come in and see what was around the area. The bed was comfortable, we didn't mind the sounds out the planes taking off and the sound was muffeled with the sliding doors closed. We're used to noise at night living close to railroad tracks here at home. I only mention this because several reviews stated the the noise was unbarable at times--we didn't find that to be the case. For our 1st breakfast we just went down stairs --again, the food was good, but pricy ($44.00 for 2). Now that we know how expensive it is we went off the property for our meals. You are surrounded by all kinds or fast food (churches chicken, pizza hut, wendy's, taco bell, taco maker), etc. we found the Pondarosa to have a good breakfast--there is even an OutBack restaurant around the corner (definately somethng for everyone). We didn't take any tours, but rented a car (off property cheaper) and explored on our own. Map of island is easy to navigate, exits maked, highways are kinda rough. We went to the rain forest and spent the day (breath-taking) hard hiking if your not fit. Drove around to several beaches, I loved them all and none were over crowded. Took a ride to the caves--that was too cool, it's amazing to be so deep into the ground and stand inside this huge, cool, dark dome with enough light to see what's around, giant stalagtites and stalagmites protruding from the ground and ceiling of the cave. We saw some bats flying around one section and one right infront of me hanging upside down with one wing open . That is the coolest picture I took. We also went to the center of the island and visited with some of my husbands family--the ride was beautiful with water falls that you see after taking a hair pin turn traveling up the mountain. We're not much for night life so all we really did is go out for dinner and stop on the way back to the casino. I liked the one in the El San Juan better than the others and that was only because of the appearance--the others weren't very elabrate for being a casino, well not what I'm used to anyway. We left every night with a little more than what we spent, but then again we're not big gamlers. I would definately stay at the Intercontinental again---When you look at it from the front you would never know that there was a tropical paradise waiting for you on the other side! The island people were very friendly and the weather was fantastic.  
<Date>Jun 1, 2006

<Author>ajs0522
<Content>Nice Hotel, Questionable Guests My husband and I stayed at the San Juan Intercontinental over Memorial Day weekend. I was worried about a difficult check-in, tiny rooms, thin walls, etc. I was pleased that everything in those areas turned out ok. Though our room was not ready upon arrival, it was not a problem because we were given a hospitality room to change. I was not feeling well from the flight, so they allowed us extra time in the room. The room was adequate in size... and was very very clean. We were on the 16th (top) floor, and the view was lovely. I didn't hear our neighbors, but did hear doors in the hall closing- not a big deal at all. In general, the accomodations were nice. Not spectacular, but certainly nice enough.The pool was lovely... but overcrowded with loud guests. We stayed on the beach most of the time, and heard boom boxes playing loudly. I think many of the island people vacation there for a night or two over the Memorial Day weekend. I felt as if it were more a spring break atmosphere... not what you'd expect for $300+ a night, and in May. Tuesday after Memorial Day was the best day. The beach was also nice. Definitely a people watching beach! Ocean water was nice as well. Not crystal clear, but still clean and warm.The conceirge was great- though they recommend you take the bus to Old San Juan for 75 cents as opposed to a taxi- $19 one way. DO NOT take the bus if you want to feel secure and comfortable. Very shady characters. My husband and I could not understand why the concierge would recommend doing so.All in all a nice place- not a great weekend in terms of the occupants there, but we enjoyed ourselves at the Intercontinental anyway.  
<Date>May 31, 2006

<Author>Jules1212
<Content>A Perfect Vacation The hotel's staff is so incredible. They treat you like royalty. My husband and I celebrated our 10 year ann and stayed there in May 2006. We were upgraded to an ocean view room, the view was fabulous. The room was nicely decorated, everything worked fine. It was nice to have a safe in the room. There's also a small fridge, and a market across the street. Two great breakfast places were across the street, by the market, Mi Casita, and the bakery. Mi Casita has $2.50 bfast special everyday. Subway and some other fast food restaurants are also across the street. The hotel food is way overpriced. Breakfast was like $14 min. We didn't eat at the hotel except for Ruth's Chris Steakhouse, which, of course, was the best steak ever. There's also a casino in the hotel, nickel slots are were it's at! I had a few good nights in Biddyville, as my husband called it. (There were lots of older women playing the nickel slots)The guy in the gift shop even went to another hotel to get my size in a shirt I wanted. Free towels and bottled water at the pool everyday. The pool needs a review all on its own. That was the most fabulous pool I have been to, and I've been to a lot. Rock formations, water falls, bridge, swim up bar, it is sooo nice! I do not recommend renting a car, unless you have terrific navagational skills. The streets seem very difficult to navigate. The taxi was well worth it. The bus was less expensive by far, but took like half an hour to wait on, then twice as long to get there as a taxi. This website helped me choose our vacation, so I hope my review has helped you. I highly recommend the Intercontinental Hotel and Casino in San Juan. We cannot wait to go back.  
<Date>May 29, 2006

<Author>back115
<Content>Loved this hotel The Inetercontinental Hotel and Casino in SanJuan , Puerto Rico was better than expected. It is a 4 star hotel in the Isle Verde section of San Juan. The cleanliness of the room,and friendliness of the staff was beyond our expectations. Whether we needed concierge assistance, or a question answered at the front desk, our needs were met promptly. The food and drinks at the hotel were expensive, but not more so than the El SanJuan next door. We had an oceanview room with a magnificent view, and our room was spacious enough to accomodate the 3 people in our party. I would definitely stay at this hotel if I returned to San Juan, and would recommend it to anyone planning an upcoming trip to the area.

<Author>isletraveler
<Content>Nice Hotel This was a nice hotel. It was clean, the rooms were nice, the grounds kept very well, and service from all staff (from bellman to housekeeping) was top notch. The food at the Splash Bar (pool bar) and at the Mediterranian Cafe (beach front) was so-so. The breakfast in the mornings at the hotel restaurant was very good, and the Japanese restaurant was excellent. Isla Verde seemed to be a very nice area of Puerto Rico. My husband had stayed prior to my arrival for a meeting at the Westin Resort...probalby 40-45 minutes away from Isla Verde. He said he liked this better. This was maybe a 5min cab ride to the airport, and about 15min cab ride to Old San Juan. Old San Juan was interesting, but it's really hot and most of the shops sell the same things. Go to see the history and have lunch...go back to your hotel for nightlife. Right next door to the Intercontinental is the El San Juan. Go to their rooftop restaurants (one Mexican food, one Ranch Style)...the views are great and the atmosphere is good. They also have a club, but we didn't stay long enough to really get the feel for it. I'm sure if you're in the mood for dancing and a 'clubby' atmosphere it would be just fine! All in all, I'd recommend the Intercontinental over other hotels we saw.  
<Date>May 9, 2006

<Author>CeCeArlington
<Content>Great service but get your wallet ready.... My husband and I just returned from our 3 night, 4 day trip to San Juan Puerto Rico. I am starting a new job next week so I was really excited about getting in a (much deserved) vacation. I searched and searched for the perfect spot to go and wound up booking at the Intercontinental Resort and Casino. We had never been to PR so we had no idea what to expect. We arrived and took a quick $15 cab ride from the airport to the hotel, $15 for a 5 minute cab ride seemed excessive but what the heck...we were in Puerto Rico! We checked in and found our Garden View room overlooked the roof of the restuarant but beyond that was a beautiful blue ocean so I got over it. We headed down to lunch and found that the cheapest thing on the menu was a veggie wrap for $10. This was about the time we realized this was not going to be a cheap trip. I will spare you the play by play but the moral of this story is that Puerto Rico (the Intercontinental specifically) is very expensive. The Intercontinental is a nice hotel...I say nice, not great, and far from fabulous compared to several other Intercontinental's that I have stayed at in the past. It is far away from any other restaurants or shopping so if you want to get a meal outside of the hotel, get ready to pay AT LEAST $40 roundtrip to get anywhere else, same goes for shopping. The casino was okay, but very small and very smokey. The pool is very nice...this is where I spent the majority of my stay. The spa is nice but the doors to the rooms are very thin. Throughout my 55 minute massage I heard a little kid who had been dropped off in the reception area crying for her mother while she recieved a massage in the room next to me. I will close with the fact that the hotel was nice and the service was great but I would not reccomend this to anyone who plans to explore anything outside of the hotel. My reccomendation is to stay in the Old San Juan area. It is chock full of restuarants, bars, and shops (The Parrot Club is a must!). I was told that this was the ghetto area but quite honestly the whole of San Juan that I saw resembles the ghetto and Old Town was the most fun. P.S. If you are thinking of booking a trip to PR within the next month or two, talk to the tourism commission. The PR gov't is having a bit of a economic setback at the moment and all public employees (schools, hospitals, gov't agencies, etc.) are unemployeed due to the current elected party. We heard several different versions from those who felt one way or the other about the govenor in office but nonetheless there was a lot of unrest and demostrating going on while we were there.  
<Date>May 3, 2006

<Author>ATLTravelsALot
<Content>Disgusting service - No comparison to other Intercontinental's This hotel is in no way up to par with other Intercontinental's in Latin America/worldwide. Service in EVERY respect is terrible, from the housekeeping that does not show up until 5:00 PM despite repeated requests for service to the absolute zero service in the casino. I was playing $25 blackjack tables for HOURS and not one drink order. Finally complained to management and even the blackjack dealer was literally screaming for a waiter to take orders wihtout success. The bathroom is tiny, the shampoo/amenities sorely lacking and the bed is worn out. Nasty hot tub with brown water and absolute dirty bed linens/bedspread shows this property in desperate need of repair. For $300 a night, stay elsewhere. Never again will I stay here. Nasty nasty nasty is all I can say about this hotel. Oh, the Ruth's Chris restaurant/service is excellent, but stay elsewhere and go there to eat. The Intercontinental is nothing more than a rundown Holiday Inn. I agree with the previous post...this place is dangerous for familie and children as well. The bathroom at the beach was used by non-guests and very dirty. I had my towel actually stolen at the beach when I went to the room for 30 mins. to check email! Not safe and dirty in general!

<Author>Empanada
<Content>Nice place, thin walls The location for this hotel is good--close to the airport on a beautiful beach (but the taxis rip you off charging you $10.50 for a five minute ride!). The room was spacious and the beds are very comfortable. Our room had a beach view that was beautiful and the hotel provides complimentary plush beach towels, chairs, and umbrellas. But be prepared to listen to your neighbors because the walls are extra thin. We could hear people coming in and out of their rooms all night long. The rooms were very clean and we didn't have any problems checking in. The hotel is close to other hotels and shops, so dining was easy. The neighboring El San Juan Hotel has an amazing salsa club with live music on many nights. We stayed away from the casino because we're not gamblers and we've been to Vegas. We'd recommend skipping breakfast in the hotels and walking across the street to the mini-mall that has breakfast places (e.g., a bakery) for less than $5 per person. There's also a great homestyle Puerto Rican (Criollo) restaurant across the street-their asopao de pollo (chicken soup) was delicious and inexpensive. We'd recommend skipping the hotel restaurants unless you'd like to really pay a lot for a nice meal.Be forewarned, this hotel is not near Old San Juan--if you plan to go to Old San Juan, it's a pretty costly taxi ride ($20 one way). But we took the public bus instead (75 cents per person) and it gave us a great tour of the city and it stops right in Old San Juan at the bus terminal. The bus was clean and operated very efficiently but take exact change. Just ask the concierge about travel in and around Old San Juan-he was very helpful.Note: We did not pay for our stay at the hotel (business trip with extended stay for vacation). But we felt the price of the hotel was reasonable considering the convenience of its location to the beach, restaurants, casinos, and nearby hotels. If you're planning on catching more culture and nightlife in Old San Juan, we'd recommend staying in Old San Juan. The Intercontinental is good for a relaxing time on the beach.  
<Date>Apr 22, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Very Nice Hotel Just got back from a weeklong trip staying at the Intercon Hotel in Isla Verde area. We had a decent sized room (king bed, sofa) facing the ocean. It does make a big difference when you get that view and open your sliding door for a nice breeze off the ocean. The higher your floor the better the view. People have complained about the walls being very thin and hearing everybody else but honestly it depends who is staying next to you. It's pretty much luck of the draw. Tell the front desk if your neighbors are too loud. They'll handle it for you. The hotel is very very close to the airport so that's good but also bad in some respects. Only an $11 cab ride (5 min) away but you can hear the boom of the planes arriving and departing close by. Bewteen 11 pm and 7 am the airport has very minimal activity. The pool area is very spacious with plenty of comfy chairs to claim. The staff is very attentive and accommodating to help you enjoy your stay there. There are two bars/restaurants at the pool area, one closer to the beach and one has a swim up bar. The Splash swim up bar makes their drinks better than the Ciao restaurant. Definitely important when your paying $8 per drink plus tipping. Food at both places is your typical bar food. Pricier because of the convenience of eating right there at the poolside/beachsisde. You can walk right across the street to a few places for cheaper breakfast/lunch food (i.e. Subway). The beach outside the hotel is decent but the ocean water surprisingly has lots of seaweed. They have water activities such as jet skiing, parasailing, banana boat. Isla Verde beach area allows you to take nice walks up and down the coast. The hotel offers you chairs and umbrellas for the beach as a guest, free of charge, just throw a few $ tip to the guys busting their butts hauling them out for you. They have a decent gym overlooking the ocean close to the beach. It's included in your stay. The hotel has a few different restaurants- sushi, steak, italian, breakfast buffet. Did all of them except for the italian. Enjoyed all of them, little pricier but that's expected for hotel standards. The casino is pretty good, open every day from 10am-4am. Guy sells cigars in front of it during the evening. Little bar in the lobby area with salsa playing music in the evenings. If you plan on hanging in the lobby area during the evening bring a sweatshirt, it's cold in there! People actually hang out in there because it's nice. The concierge desk was very helpful to us in planning dinners and various other activities. Highly recommend Nestor or Joselle. All in all it was a very nice place and the weather in PR was great, obviously the reason people go to the island for vacationing. Would stay there again if we visited PR again. El San Juan hotel next door is pretty sweet with a cool lobby/ bar area but it's also much more expensive.  
<Date>Apr 22, 2006
