<Author>snoopy1128
<Content>Paradise Found ! My husband and I just returned from a 6 day stay during Easter week at the Intercontinental. It was one of the best vacations of our lives. We were treated like royalty by the entire staff the whole time we were there. We were upgraded for free to an ocean view on the 10th floor. What a view from the balcony!!! The beach is beautiful. The lounge chairs and small tables are free and they will place them anyplace on the beach that you like. Umbrellas cost $10 to rent, but to save money we put our chairs under the palm trees when we wanted shade. There is a small shopping mall across the street where you could buy food to picnic on the beach. We bought food from Subway and there is a small bakery there. You could also walk to Burger King and Wendy. You could be lazy and order food on the beach, but it is expensive. We did that one day and it cost us $42. We were lucky because we had a 25% discount on all food and beverages through Liberty Travel Agency. The hotel has beautiful pools with waterfalls, a swim up splash bar and a jacuzzi. The lounges around the pool are very cushiony and comfortable. The concierge is excellent. Through Nestor we booked a tour to El Yunque Rainforest and Luquillo Beach. It was through E  B tours with a man named Jos Antonio(Joey). It was an all day tour. He arrived in his Ford Windstar van with 2 other couples and 1 child. It was a nice small group of 7 people. We left at 9:30 AM and returned at 6PM. We saw all of the important sites in the rainforest and were able to swim in La Mina Falls. He gave us so much interesting information. We arrived at the famous Luquillo Beach at 2:30 and spent the rest of the day there. We had the buffet breakfast every day which was included in our package from Liberty travel. There was a great selection of items and you could get things cooked to order like special omelets, eggs done anyway you like them or waffles, and pancakes. They changed some of the hot items every day. One day there were blintzes, another breakfast burritos, poached eggs with sweet plantains and different kinds of potatoes. We sat outside near the pool area. For dinner we ate at the Ciao Mediterranean caf on the beach, the Ponderosa across the street where we had lobster tails, the 10th floor of the Howard Johnson Hotel (8 blocks away) which has a beautiful Italian restaurant called La Fontana with a view of the harbor and a restaurant at the end of our beach which juts out into the water called the Oceanview or Sonny restaurant. The food was very good and the view of the harbor was beautiful. It was not expensive.I will definitely return to this hotel again. I am only home 2 days and I miss being there already.  
<Date>Apr 21, 2006

<Author>luvtolaf62
<Content>Had an awesome vacation! My boyfriend and I just got back (yesterday) from our 5 night vacation at the Intercontinental. We had a great time with very few complaints about the hotel. I would have to say the only real problem was the thin walls (as previous reviewers have stated). If you're unlucky to have inconsiderate neighbors, you'll hear doors slamming and conversations in the hallway and the rooms next door. At 3:00 AM, this was not an ideal situation. Fortunately, it didn't happen every night. We had a city view on the 11th floor and although the balcony is small with only one chair, we were able to bring the room chair outside and be very comfortable having morning coffee or an evening cocktail. The room itself was clean but nothing special. However, this was just fine since we didn't spend a whole lot of time there. The maid service was excellent. The pool and beach areas couldn't be better. You can rent an umbrella ($10) at the towel stand and there's plenty of plush towels and free water. There are also plenty of waiters on the beach if you'd like to have drinks or food brought to you. The gym was just OK. There were four treadmills, one stairmaster, two recumbent bikes and plenty of weights. The spa area is small but sufficient and everybody is really very nice.If you're looking for some salsa dancing, go next door to the El San Juan. The bands were great!Overall, we had a great vacation and would definitely stay at the Intercontinental again. I would be happy to answer any questions if you'd like to contact me. This was my fourth time to Puerto Rico and last year, I stayed at the Wyndham El San Juan.  
<Date>Apr 12, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great hotel! We stayed at the Intercontinental March 24th, 2006 for 3 days following at sailboat charter in the BVI. It was great to have such a nice hotel to look forward to after roughing it for a week! We loved this place! Everyone was so friendly, rooms clean, pool area great-plenty of chairs, beach location excellent. We had a top floor room facing the ocean and could hear the waves all night when we left our door open! The casino was fun-small, but we're not big gamblers. By the way, they don't adhere to the dress code in the casino that they tell you. (Which was good for us because we didn't have room to pack nice clothes and extra shoes other than sandals on the boat. They do make you wear shoes and shirts in the lobby). There are so many helpful personnel standing around everywhere. The concierge was especially helpful in getting us around San Juan and trying out restaurants. Our ONLY gripe was our room not being ready when we arrived, but we just went down and had a drink at the beach bar, so it wasn't really a big problem. We would love to go back to San Juan, as 3 days was not enough time, and will definately stay here again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice hotel....Here are a few tips My husband and I stayed at the Intercontinental in March and on the whole we were very pleased. The staff was very friendly and helpful. They upgraded our room at no extra charge. The pool was lovely and the beaches sufficient. We really appreciated security ever present and that staff was waiting with towels and water after a morning run. The location is great. Close enough to the ESJ for a night of fun and some great food but far enough away for peace and quiet and minutes from the airport. Our room was lovely. Our two complaints would be the doors are very loud. On Saturday night we heard doors slamming all nigh. Not very restful. Try to request a room at the end of the hall. The shampoo is horrible. Fortunately there was a walgreens right down the street and the problem was solved with a $1.25.If you are not a big breakfast eater, we highly recommend the bakery in the strip mall across the street. Great baked goods, ham egg  cheese sandwiches, and a mean cup of coffee. The owner is very nice and remembers how you like your coffee after one day. Another food tip...walk to the end of the beach (to the right) there is a little dive hotel (not the bar hanging over the edge) at the end. Walk through the motel and you will see an amazing view of the ocean, have a great burger, a cold beer, all for a few bucks. Great find!We loved Puerto Rico. There is as much or as little as you want to do. One last warning!!! Check over your bill before check out. We were charged for things we did not eat and were charged for parking a car we never had. Once pointed out, they corrected it without a fuss. We would recommend this hotel. Clean, friendly staff, and decent amenities.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect quick getaway! A friend and I stayed at the Intercontinental for 3 nights in March and loved it. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful, the rooms were fine (not luxurious, but more than adequate) and the pool and beach were great. Despite there being 2 conferences at the hotel while we were there, it never felt overcrowded. The food was good and the drinks hit the spot. We loved how easy it was to get to from the aiport and took advantage a great little coffee shop across the street and a small grocery store to save $ on breakfast. All in all, my friend and I would both definitely return, either with our families or for another girls' weekend.

<Author>hoskikar
<Content>Intercontinental overpriced! Stayed at the IC on March 16 - 18th. Four ladies and two rooms. Arrived at IC at 5:00pm and one of our rooms wasn't ready until 6:00pm. Was given a complimentary drink at the bar while two of us had to wait for our room to be cleaned.Public areas are very pretty. The rooms are absoultly no more than average. They seem worn. Caulk in the bathroom was old, not well done and yellowish. The beds were fine. The balcony VERY tiny but at least for the most part a beatiful ocean view (it also overlooked lots of roof tops that were not pleasing to look at).If we hadn't paid so much for the room it would be one thing but to pay these prices I expect alot more for the money. Staff was friendly but slow at checkin. Pool was GREAT! Big, clean fun to be at! Beach was very nice. I did appreciate the security they had around the hotel. I would probably not stay here again as I think we could have gotten a better place to stay for the money we spent.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Fantastic staff, beautiful hotel, a great option..... My girlfriend and I recently stayed at the Intercontinental for 5 days and 4 nights. We are 28  29 yrs old and we were looking for something other than a spring break place, but we also didn't want to stay in a 'honeymoon type' resort. The Intercontinental proved to be a great selection. The staff is extremely pleasant  helpful, always greeting you with a smile. The beach is great, with a cool little beach bar/cantina run by the hotel where you can enjoy a cocktail or some lunch while just steps from your beach chair. The pool is also very attractive and is great for a quick swim, but we're more beach people. The lobby bar and restaurants are totally sufficient if not exceptional. However, the El San Juan, known for it's fantastic nightlife( mediocre rooms) is literally right next door. We also had dinner and drinks at the Water Club, Isla Verde's new trendy 'boutique' hotel  it was also within walking distance. We had a very nice oceanview room on the 12th floor with a tremendous view. All in all, we had a great time at the Intercontinital and we would recommend it to any of our friends. I can't say enough about the staff and how nice they were.  
<Date>Mar 14, 2006

<Author>Phantom03
<Content>A truly wonderful experience! We are frequent travelers and have been to several Caribbean destinations. We don't cruise, so our experiences have not been limited to port areas or 1 night stays either. That being said, we are totally enchanted with the island of Puerto Rico! We just returned from our 5 night stay at the Intercontinental Hotel there and couldn't be happier with the service and accomodations received. I know the details below are long winded, feel free to skim, but I'd rather give too much info than too little. We are all unique and what means something to one doesn't always mean the same to others. Bottom line is, Puerto Rico and the Intercontinental are both tops in our book!Location - The hotel is a short $11US taxi ride from the airport. It is very close to the airport, but so are ALL the hotels in the Isle Verde/Carolina section. Airplane noise was noticable out by the pool during peak times, so keep that in mind if you are sensitive to it and maybe look for a hotel away from the airport. Definitely no fault of this hotel and to be honest, we didn't notice any airport noise from inside our room (facing the ocean, not the city).Pool - The pool is in a class by itself! The combination swim up/walk up bar is partially covered to provide shade most of the day for people who want to park there and drink without becoming a lobster. The pool bar has 3 tv's and plenty of name brand alcohol. Everything can be charged to your room, no need to bring cash to the pool area. There is also a small footbridge, several shallow ledges for in-pool suning, and (best of all) a multi-waterfall simulated rock formation with all kinds of places to sit/stand under them. A small section of the pool gets 6'+ deep and is clearly marked by bouy lines. The rest is generally between 3' and 5'+. Hot tub is huge and connected to the pool for easy in/out between the two. Plenty of areas to get shade and sun around the pool. Thick cushioned loungers with lots of tables and umbrellas are usually able to be had with not too much trouble. Towels are easy to get and plentiful as is all the FREE bottled water you can drink. Drink service was almost always at hand and not bothersome if you didn't want it. If you are a pool person, this is your place to be.Beach - Soft, beige sand is perfect for long, barefoot walks. Not too crowded. Surf is just rough enough to be interesting, perfect for the body surfer. Lots of watersports options nearby. Beaches are public but not overrun by pushy vendors (we saw very few at all). Only knock was the above average amount of seaweed in the first 10-15 yards of surf. Most hotels on the beach issue their guests daily ID braclets to get back in.Room - The shower is the best we have ever, and I mean EVER, had! It is what all showers in the world should be designed after! Holds the temperature, gets as hot as you want (or not), easy to operate and the water pressure is like a small fire hose. Did I mention we liked the shower? A small refrigerator is in the room stocked with a couple beers, a couple waters, some soda... any of which will be charged to your room if consumed. The great part about it is there are no sensors inside, so you can move things around and use the ample extra space for your own perishables. The king bed was very comfortable, pillows were just OK, plenty of blankets if you want them. Enough drawer and closet space for 2 people on an average stay. Large desk and sofa in the sitting area. Balcony was too small, but better than none at all. Sliding glass door lets the Caribbean air wash right into the room. A/C works really, really well (too well sometimes) and sound is on the level of white noise. TV gets several popular US  PR channels. Iron  ironing board. In-room safe with self-program code and lots of room inside. Plenty of mirrors and lights around them to see what you're doing. Like most hotels, you can probably hear through the walls if you really try (like say putting your ear up to it), but just sitting in the room we heard nothing on either side of us. One big problem we had was being right outside the elevator and several exuberant guests seemed to think nothing of shouting down halls and slamming doors at all hours. No matter where you are, please remember if you're in the hallway everyone can hear you.Food - Pool  beach bars offered some great lunch type food which ranged from the native (Puerto Rican specialties) to the ordinary (Burgers  Pizza). All were very good with no lingering effects. La Terraza was also very good. Room service at breakfast was prompt, accurate and the food was delcious. We did not try the other restaurants at the hotel since there were so many other options on Isle Verde and Old San Juan. One night we ate at Metropol with mixed results. My pork was way too fatty, but her beef dish was very good. Our best food experience was at Dragonfly in Old San Juan. Simply to die for. Slightly larger than Tapas style portions designed to mix and share. Get the mongolian beef, it's sublime! Parrot Club was great too. El San Juan hotel next door has several restaurants of which we tried two. The Italian one (next to Palms) was excellent. The Mexican one... wasn't. But I digress, back to the hotel.Casino/Lobby Bar - Casino is a decent size, never really too crowded. The one and only $5 min Blackjack table fills up quickly at night with the $10 min table right behind it. Minimums don't change with the time of day. There is a dress code after 6, somewhat enforced. Slots range from 1 cent to $25, most are 5 cents. One Roulette wheel, a couple craps tables (usually only 1 going), a few poker tables and some other misc tables (let it ride, caribbean stud, etc.). Drink service at at the casino was spotty. My advice is have a back up plan for entertainment because the house seemed to have some uncanny streaks of good luck. The lobby bar seemed quite nice to lightly mix and mingle or listen to some music, but to see and be seen the place to go seemed to be next door at El San Juan.Spa - I had a Swedish massage, 55 min for $85 plus gratuity. Nice clean facilities and the staff are very friendly. As for the massage, I've had better and I've had worse. Sorry I can't be of more help than that.Service - Exceptional. Upgraded at check in. Housekeeping did a great job throughout the stay (1 day it could have been a little quicker). The lobby was always full of hotel personnel ready to answer any questions. There was an Instant Service button on the room phone which immediately connected to someone who greated us by name and addressed any issues we had immediately, then followed up to ensure we were satisfied. Tour desk people were extremely helpful and the tour guides we had were simply the best. The service at this hotel was among the best of any we've stayed at in the Caribbean. No surprises at check out either.Misc Stuff - You can do as little or as much as you like at this hotel and in Puerto Rico in general. We took the rainforest tour with Castillo Tours, ask for Conzavos (a.k.a. Papa Lion), the 2nd best tour guide in Puerto Rico (he'll explain why). We also did the Old San Juan  Bacardi Rum tour with Antonio who went above and beyond to help us. We can't wait to return!  
<Date>Mar 13, 2006

<Author>jkap
<Content>Had a fabulous trip and can't wait to go back Spent a week at the Intercontinental in San Juan abd I highly recommend this hotel. It's one of the nicest we've ever stayed at. However, I want to emphasize the benefit of staying on the ocean front side. We stayed on both (ocean and city) and found the experiences to be like night and day! Facing the ocean you feel like you are on a Caribbean island. You have a beautiful view (the higher the better) of the ocean and pool. It's great having the sliding glass doors open and getting the ocean sound and breeze. Across the hall, you feel like you are at an airport hotel. It is loud from the airport and city noises and you don't want the curtains open. The pool was terriffic with waterfalls and a swim up bar. The beach was very nice. The staff was exceptionally pleasant; from the pool attendants to the waiters and especially the front desk staff. The Japanesse restaurant was one of the best we've ever dined at. Much better than the one at the El San Juan. The food at the pool was great, but huge portions. We learned to order 2 meals for 4 people. The restaurant on the beach is nice, but allow plenty of time to wait. They have a small pizza oven and many orders. The Ranch restaurant at the El San Juan was fun for kids and had great atmosphere. Renting a car was easy - right in the hotel. Maria and Hector (Avis desk) were very helpful. Loved the Rain Forest. Had a great Italian meal in Old San Juan at Sophia's. The nice part about staying at the Intercontinental is that you are in they City and can access other restaurants and sight seeing, but you don't have to leave the hotel to experience a great, relaxing vacation!  
<Date>Mar 2, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Staff  The very goods for our experience here last week; concierge, almost all of the staff was very attentive, welcoming, and friendly; pool is very nice, beach is expansive and great for walking; we ate at the less expensive places at the hotel and found the food to be pretty good overall; there are also a couple of local places nearby particularly for breakfast and the next door hotel offers rooftop dining with a great view.The issue with the hotel revolved around the rooms for us; the room was large enough but we had noise issues with rooftop ventilation from outside and random noises throughout the night that sounded like someone dragging their chair across the floor. Also, door and bathroom sink were chipped/dreary. For the rate we paid for the room these things are really not acceptable. When I called the front desk to ask around a different room assignment because of the roof ventilation noise, they said they would send an engineer up to check out the noise but we waited for a while and no one showed up or followed up at all. Seems like they probably get lots of complaints about the rooms and don't take them too seriously.Overall, the positive staff attitude and pool area really made this a very good vacation for us.

<Author>twoplustwo
<Content>Great trip to the InterContinental My family of four (two daughters, ages 9 and 13) just stayed at the InterContinental from Feb. 18-25, and had a wonderful time. Some info/impressions, in no particular order:-- Great pool. Really great pool. Waterfalls, a little footbridge to swim under, beautifully landscaped, great upkeep. --The lounges around the pool go early. I got out there by 8 to secure 3 in the shade. But....--The chaises by the beach (which the staff will set up for you) seem to be available all day. I've heard that you have to get there early-ish for an umbrella, though.--The beach is really nice -- nice for long walks, really good for sand castle building. The water was warmer than the pool! Some seaweed, but there was only one day when it was TOO much seaweed. Soft sand; no water shoes needed.--On the beach, walk to the right (toward the El San Juan) for boating activities. My kids and husband went parasailing (they were each harnessed in with him, so he went up twice) and that was a definite highlight of the week for them. Costs about $60 each. The banana boat ride was more.....um....exciting than we thought it would be, judging from how it looks from the shore. Don't bring your glasses or camera, because you WILL be tossed off the boat at some point. You'll either think that's fun, or not. One of my daughters loved it; the other sobbed. --Unbelievably great, friendly service. Without exception. The concierge service is particularly wonderful, particularly Nestor. --One complaint: The walls of the room are thin. This is no problem unless you have really loud neighbors. There was only one point during the week when we were bothered, when our neighbor started blasting loud rap at 5:30 a.m. I called downstairs, and security came right up and knocked on their door (and knocked and knocked, until they finally turned off the music....but then we could hear what the music was drowning out: Oh baby.....OH BABY BABY! OH OH OH!). --We had a garden/pool view room, which was facing the ocean...in fact, we could see the ocean just fine! All this means is that it's on a lower floor (we were on 6). So I wouldn't pay extra for ocean view, unless you spend lots of time on the balcony. (The balconies are small -- just one chair and a small table.)-- Food: We had two TERRIFIC meals at Ruth Chris's steakhouse, and a really nice meal at Passagio, the italian place. (That has a dress code: no flip flops or shorts.) Nice breakfast each day at the buffet. Dinner one night at the restaurant down on the beach (Ciao Mediterranean--get the pizza!).-- We had dinner one night at Metropol, which is within walking distance, and has nice authentic local food. Fun place. Had dinner one night at Tequila Grill, which is on the 10th floor of El San Juan (rude hostess--that's the only rudeness I encountered all week). Great view, okay Mexican food. There's also a place called The Ranch on that floor. Both casual. --El Morro is a wonderful trip.--Old San Juan: I had a great time wandering around on my own. If you're not going to do a tour, have the cabbie drop you at El Convento hotel, wander up and down that hill (has outlet stores, if you're into that, but also nice historical things: San Juan Cathedral, San Juan Gate one block west (? toward the water)), then walk down to San Francisco or the street directly after that (LaFortenza, or something) and turn left for some nice local shops. Got some very nice stuff at Puerto Rico Arts and Crafts, which is on LaFortenza (or whatever). I ran into a funeral procession, complete with singing and drums, and masked dancers. An amazing sight.--The casino's nothing special, if you're into that. We're not, so didn't matter. Overall, I highly recommend this hotel -- we'd definitely go back.  
<Date>Mar 1, 2006

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great location, great pool, small rooms terrible price! For the 300US plus hidden fees we paid, I didn't think it was worth it! For that price go stay at the Beverly Hilton!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice hotel, for half the price We just returned from 5 nights at the Intercontinental San Juan. I have never felt the need to write anything but a positive review for hotels. Don't get me wrong. This is a nice hotel and the doormen are very friendly. However we have traveled quite a bit in the Carribean and for the price I would not stay at the IC again. The front desk are almost rude as well as some of the other staff. For $200-$300 a night this would be a great hotel but it is definately NOT a four star resort. The rooms are small and noisy and the sad part is that management at the hotel seemed to be bothered when issues were brought up. For $439 a night plus tax and a $48 hotel service charge we expected much more. A lesson learned I guess.

<Author>SusanGreatNeck
<Content>Nice for a short trip After staying at the Wyndham El San Juan Hotel and Casino for over ten years we decided to try the Intercontinental next door. We had an ocean front room with a king size bed. The room itself was narrow and quite smallas was the bathroom. The balcony had room for only one chair and a small table. There were two connecting doors on either side of the room, allowing us to hear every word our neighbors were saying. We spoke with the manager and were told every room was the same size. I found the service to be fantastic everywhere in this hotel. Unfortunately I would not stay here again because of the room size. When paying top dollar for an ocean front room there are other hotels offerring more for the money. Next try will be the Westin, where the rooms appear to be much larger.

<Author>Jannaqq
<Content>Wanted to love the InterContinental, had to settle for the Holiday Inn instead I selected the IC based on a good bit of research, including reviews at TripAdvisor. We made our reservation back in October for our Feb 3 stay....but sadly, did not get a chance to stay there. IC called me 3 days prior to arrival to let me know that they could not honor my reservation because a 'large group' was staying there. While this was never quite explained to me, the IC was kind enough to 1) give me advance notice 2) book us into the their sister hotel (Holiday Inn San Juan) and 3) comp our first night's stay there. So, while I was disappointed with the change (there is no reasonable way to compensate for switching to a 2-star hotel 2 blocks off the beach from a 4-star hotel on the beach), the IC did work with me to make it as right. We had a smooth check-in at the Holiday Inn SJ, a great room, and use of the IC grounds as though we were guests. All detailed in a letter sent to me by the IC's revenue manager (maybe that explains it?).

<Author>rinaldino
<Content>Excellent location, but bad service/price ratio We stayed at the Intercontinental from 01/27/06 until 02/03/06. In short: a very good location but a very low average level of the hotel's guests, no controls and no appropriate interventions from hotel's officers and a very bad service/price ratio. A few examples.At the swimming pool, pool attendants, except those who hand over the towels but don't make anything else (I have unsuccessfully asked to be helped on with the placing of an umbrella ),are nonexistent; still at the pool, where chairs are extremely close each other, one day ny four neighbours had lunch with cans and foods picked up at a nearby supermarket, thus disseminating all around stinks and garbage, but evidently the hotel management allows it; inside there is one bar only, unbelievably noisy due to the music always kept at full volume,but with no alternatives; the waitresses of the bar are very uncultured and one of them didn't know the existence of something called sherry; many of the hotel's guests wear baseball caps and Stetson in the evening even in the bar and the restaurants and have a behaviour which would be very indulgent to define as coarse; the hotel's shop has only a couple of local and of American newspapers, and that's all;etc.Obviously my complaints would be of little importance, if any, should I refer to a third class hotel, but I am talking about an Intercontinental with room rates justifiable only for a high class hotel.In conclusion, the excellent location of the Intercontinental in Portorico, just on the beach and very close to the airport, is surely a positive aspect but absolutely insufficient to compensate all the negative ones ( and I have mentioned only a few of them ).

<Author>ruben900
<Content>Just okay We just spent 2 nights in late January 2006 here. We go to San Juan 2-3 times per year and usually stay at the Marriott Resort in the Condado. We wanted to try the Isla Verde area for something different this trip. So, much of this review will be comparing this resort to the Marriott.First off, if you are new to Puerto Rico, you have to understand that an upscale hotel there will not be as nice as what you'll find in the States. They are made of concrete, so there's more noise. The furnishings are not as nice. Rooms are often musty due to being seaside. The staff is on an island schedule, so you have to be patient.Second, I have to commend the professionalism of the staff at the Intercontinental....better than any other place we've stayed.In a nutshell, this hotel would be good if it were less expensive. It is in many respects very similar to the Marriott Condado, just more pricey. The rooms are similar, but noisier (doors slam more loudly and the airplanes fly much closer to it with the airport nearby). The rooms were like an Omni, a Courtyard or Marriott in the States....not elegant by any stretch.The casino is okay, but no better than Marriott's and not as nice as the El San Juan nearby or El Convento in Old San Juan. The neighborhood is certainly not one where you want to walk after dark. There are grocery stores and fast food places nearby for during the daytime. No boutiques, cafes or nicer souvenir places like in the Condado.The gym is so-so, as most are down there. The pool area can't compare with Marriott's or with others I've seen. The stretch of beach it's on was quite dirty, partly due to wintertime when winds stir up more seaweed. However, it was nice to be able to jog on the beach for 1.5 or 2 miles thru Isla Verde....in front of all the hotels, etc. Fun to people watch there, too.Stay here if you can get a good deal on it, but not if it's more than $200 per night on-season.  
<Date>Jan 30, 2006
<Rating>3	2	3	-1	3	-1	4	-1

<Author>CateW
<Content>We thought this place was just terrific.... We decided on San Juan in general because it was an easy and direct flight out of NYC. We booked a package on Orbitz and the Intercontinental was one of the hotel choices for our short 4 night stay. I admit that I had some reservations based on some of the reviews but ended up being extremely satisfied. We took this short trip prior to a 10 day cruise that we are taking in a month and wanted to get some sun and just relax. Despite what we read about the hotel restaurants, we decided not to leave the hotel complex. We ate at the Japanese restaurant the first night, Ruth's Chris the next and Passagio's one night. Each was wonderful but a little on the pricey side. I've been to Ruth's Chris in NYC and was disappointed, but the repeat in San Juan did not disappoint. The Japanese Restaurant was noisy (as expected for tepanyaki) but the food was excellent and the Passagio's was very cozy and excellent overall. The pool area was beautiful and the water refreshing. If you didn't get to the pool early, and I am talking by 10 a.m. you didn't get a chair. Now let me say that I was down there around 9 each day so we were set, but we were also there. There were many chair hogs - meaning that they put either a book or sun tan lotion on the chair and left for hours. Check-in was a breeze and we arrived at noon and were able to get into our room right away. We were sipping a drink by 12:30. We live in CT now, but lived in the City for 6 years. Many reviews mentioned the planes coming and going and the noise level. If you've lived in the City for any period of time and have police sirenes, fire engines and ambulances screaming by at all hours of the day or night, you won't be phased by the planes at all. Our room was on the 5th floor and was very clean - no complaints at all about the room. The bathroom was also very clean but a tad on the small side. Frankly, we didn't spend all that much time in the room during the day since we were there for the sun and were just really there late in the evening so weren't bothered by this at all. We also ate breakfast at the hotel, wasn't great, wasn't bad but was a little pricey. We don't eat all that much and when we have breakfast, we skip lunch so I can't comment on the lunches. Drinks from both the pool bar and lobby bar were very good and the overall service exceptional. For those who would rather venture out and are on a limited budget, the Outback is nearby as is Pizza Hut and several local restaurants that a number of people that we talked to said were very good. All in all, we had a great time and would definitely go back.  
<Date>Jan 24, 2006

<Content>Management failed us We flew in to San Juan a day early for our Cruise and stayed one night at The Intercontinental. We paid $300 for a city view. Not a very nice view, we looked out on dirty hotels and fast food restaurants. Pool area is nice and beach is nice, but be aware beer is $6 a bottle. Bellman was nice helping us with bags and info. Main problem we had with hotel was that a week after we stayed there, we get off cruise @ 8:30am and flight didn't leave until 5:20pm, we go to airport and try to get flight moved up and we can't and they wouldn't let us check in until after 1pm and there's not even a place to sit at airport, the only place we had to turn was The Intercontinental where we had stayed 1 night the week before, so we take a taxi and asked the management if we could just store our luggage and get an armband to be able to use the pool area and use a towel, and their reply was because they were full they couldn't let us. There was only my wife and myself, and we were talking only a few hrs, people were checking out and for those checking in, that time is 4pm, they turned us away. They could have done the right thing and maybe had a repeat customer but next time we'll go next door to the El San Juan, and we'll get an ocean view. If you're looking for a party you won't find it at The Intercontinental It was dead the Fri. night we were there, but had a blast next door at The El San Juan.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>LOVED IT! We got back from from PR last week and had an awesome time! We stayed at the Intercontinental and hit the beach and local restaurants. We loved having the best of both worlds - we had the beach on one side and the city on the other. The IC has clean rooms, a friendly staff, and a beautiful pool and beach area.The concierge was very helpful in directing us to outside restaurants and sightseeing. The rest of the staff was very accomodating to any other requests we had.The IC is expensive but you get what you pay for. It is next door the the Wydnam Casino which is known for the night life. It is also local to a lot of restaurants. The staff at the IC was great for recommending restaurants in the area. The cuisine at the IC was expensive as to be expected at any resort, but there were so many places to go to eat that were right outside the resort - literally a 2 minute walk.Anyway, my husband said that this is where he wants to go again next year. Although the IC was expensive, I think it was worth it. We had lunch at the resort only because it was convenient to the beach, but we saved $$ on breakfast and dinner by taking a walk off the resort. The IC wasn't overcrowded and the staff was very friendly and the rooms were great. Oh yeah - it's a 5 minute taxi ride from the airport and a 10-minute taxi ride to historic Old San Juan.

<Author>SweetRoadTrip
<Content>Swim Up BAR! POSTIVES-Isla Verde is a great location. The Intercontinental had a great beach and pool area and the staff was very friendly and a SWIM UP BARNEGATIVES--Casino is dumpy, Restaurants expensive. The area- the hotel is right next door to the El San Juan with its gorgeous lobby bar and great scene.Across the street from the Intercontinental is a little strip mall with a tiny supermarket where we picked up bottle water and room necessities. There is also a bunch of fast food places and a small diner which has very good Mofongo (if you are in PR you must try it). Its only a short walk to the Water Club Hotel with its cool roof top bar and great tapas-like restaurant Tangerine.

<Author>commscholar
<Content>Great time at Intercontinental Great hotel, with great service. The beach and pool area are beautiful. Restaurants and bars expensive. However, there's a grocery store and lots of reasonable restaurants literally right accross the street. They sent us a free bottle of wine and chocolate covered strawberries to our room. We still don't know why. My one complaint is that the king bed rooms were really tiny. We were in a two-double bed room the first night, which was spacious and nice, but we wanted a king bed after that. The king room was not that nice and really small. I thought the veiws were nice from the cityview rooms as well as the others. I don't think it's worth paying for the supposedly better view, unless you're getting the top floor oceanview rooms. All balconies are small, only fit one small chair. The staff was so helpful they were really wonderful.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best Hotel in Isla Verde This was our third time staying at the InterContinental. We have stayed twice at the Ritz, twice at the Caribe HIlton and once at the Marriot; however, the InterContinental is our favorite place to stay when we are in San Juan. The grounds are lovely, the rooms are clean and comfortable and the staff is pleasant and accomodating.  The beach in Isla Verde is fantastic and great for taking long walks. You don't get much of a beach when you stay at the Hilton or at the Hotels on the Condado. Eating at the hotels can be expensive, but there are a few places very close by that serve some great food. The Metropol is our favorite - great Cuban food, not like abuela's, but good! Right across the street from the hotel is a stirp mall. There's a small grocery where you can buy bottle water, snacks and drinks (soda, beer, wine, rum...). There's a place to eat there called Mi Casita - be warned - the service is awful, especially at breakfast time! Food can be good. A few doors down, in the very same strip mall is the Golden Bagel Bakery! Coming from the NYC area, I'm very fussy when it comes to bagels, but this place has some great local pastries and good cafe con leche. You can go there for a very excellant and inexpensive breakfast; or better yet take it to go and bring it back to eat on the hotel balcony or on the beach. One place to never go to eat is the Ocean View! We waited over an hour to get our food, then we just walked out, so who knows how long it really would have taken!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Fabulous Anniversary Trip My darling husband and I have been looking forward to our 30th wedding anniversary and celebrating with a special trip just to relax in the sun because the anniversary is on January 10th. After much research and looking at all possibilities I decided on the Intercontinental Hotel in San Juan. Hawaii was too expensive for us this year and we were not interested in a long flight. Darling husband was not into a cruise, it's been a busy year and we both just wanted to veg.The Intercontinental is everything we expected and more. The property is beautiful and kept meticulously clean. The pool area is as wonderful as everyone else has been saying on this site and I lived out there all week. The beach is ok but there were little noseeums biting me out there so I was very happy to enjoy the pool area. Also, the water had a lot of seaweed washing up. Husband was happy as long as his drink was cold! We stayed the entire week on priority club points and they upgraded our room after the first night and the view was amazing. We felt like we were sitting in the top of the palm trees with a view of the ocean.I went shopping in Old San Juan and really enjoyed browsing there. The Coach and Dooney and Burke outlets have great prices. Ruth's Chris was excellent as always and we went twice, Passiagio's was ok - mediocre - we went twice also. The ElSanJuan next door is incredible and we had dinner at The Palm for our anniversary and were treated very special. The club concierge had Champagne and chocolate covered strawberries waiting for us in our room when we arrived as a surprise because it was our anniversary. This hotel has fabulous service, couldn't be nicer or more helpful. We have traveled a lot and stayed at Ritz Carlton and many Marriott Renaissance Hotels but this was probably the best service even than the cruise ships. The staff at this hotel will help you with anything and do it with a smile, they are always asking if everything is ok. We won a few dollars in the casino although it's annoying how long it takes to get paid when you win.My only criticism of this hotel is that they need to upgrade the bed linens and the beds. We slept fine but after the Ritz Carlton and Marriott Renaissance and even Crowne Plaza, I expected the linens to be a little nicer but this is a small complaint, our room was great.We will definitely go again to this property and if you go please give Frances at the Splash Pool Bar a big hello for us!! (great poolside food)  
<Date>Jan 15, 2006

<Content>Intercontinental made my dream come true I always dreamed of taking my family on a dream vacation to the land of my parents birth. <Author>FunSeekinRican
<Content>Great Deal in Isla Verde ! I just returned from a week at the Intercontinental (1/4 - 1/10). I was curious as to what my trip was going to be like since me  my bf were so young (we are 20) but we had a fantastic time! For young people isla verde is a great place to go to relax, chill by the beach and pool, and have fun. The drinking age in PR is 18 and alcohol is in no short supply although it can be expensive through the hotel.The GoodIt's a beautiful hotel with nice green plant life and a nice lobby  outside. immediately getting out of the cab we were greeted and helped by the staff outside and it was like that the whole vacation. The hotel staff was amazing in service and hospitality. They always held the door when we were walking in and out of the hotel and always greeted us and chatted with us when we saw them around the hotel. The pool was very nice and large. It has two small waterfalls and a lil cove in the middle of the two that you can sit in. Theres a swim up bar and a nice sized hot tub that was great to relax in. Security was pretty tight with the pool. You have to get a new colored wrist band everyday to get towels and complimentary water bottles. I guess because we were young we got checked a lot by security to make sure we were guests but it wasnt that bad. They dont want anyone sneaking into the pool. I also got ID'ed a few times at the casino and they are strict with not allowing any kids in there. Theres also shady canopies and umbrellas if ur not a big fan of the sun. there was no short supply of pool chairs. The beach was enjoyable and the hotel provided each guest with chairs brought to the location of your choice. The rooms were medium sized but cozy. At night in the lounge they have singers that sing different spanish music and some people get up and dance making a really nice atmosphere. the food in momoyama was awesome. the hot tub was open till 10pm for a nice late nite dip. There is a game room with a few decent games for the kiddies. The beach was amazing at sunset and at night. The water was warm and the sand was white  nice. Overall the stay was great and the food was good!The BadThe maids were not the best. The pool was beautiful - but FREEZING. everyone had trouble getting in it. I'm usually a big pool person but I couldn't bring myself to go in more than one time. The beach was warmer than the pool. The beach was nice, one of the nicest in the metro area but during christmas time the ocean cleans itself which means loads and loads of sea weed. The beach was covered with sea weed making it really hard to jump in. Once you got past a certain point it wasn't as bad but it was pretty gross. However, it does go away (the sea weed was completely gone on our last day). We asked the staff to recommend better beaches and we got a bunch of great beaches to visit. The one we went to was escambrones (its on the map given at the hotel). It was gorgeous and the water was clear  you could walk out 15 ft and still stand. I'd definitely reccomend it. The airport was also annoying and you heard every airplane that landed but you heard it practically everywhere on isla verde practically. The gift shop in the hotel was very overpriced  the tour desk was very sloppy. I reserved the biobay with castillo tours before I got there and when i confirmed they had no idea what I was talking about. I'd recommend going through Nestor at the concierge. Also the biobay tour we went on was in the van of some guy named Ishmael and it was horrible. I think tours through actual companys are better but i dont know who or why castillo tours put us with this guy. Avoid Ishmael. Last but not least do NOT rely on cabs. The taxi situation is ridiculous there. Its 20 USD one way to go into old san juan. We had no car which made it difficult to go out at times. The better clubs and food was in old san juan but we couldnt enjoy it as much because it was so pricey to get there. There is a bus thats only 75 cents but it took really long and I didn't feel that comfortable. If you speak spanish and dont mind locals the bus might be a good solution. The area around the hotel isnt the greatest but I wouldn't call it seedy. Take the bus and your definition of seedy might change. im from a city so I felt fine walking along the street but I wouldnt stray too far from the hotel.FoodI thought the restaurants in the hotel were over priced so we went out searching for cheaper, local food. We ate a lot at Mi Casita in the shopping center across the street. They have good mofongos if ur into that. the food was good but the service was bad. We also ate at Metropol down the street. they had the best vanilla flan I have tasted in a long time. Once again the service wasnt great but food was very good. Across the street from Metropol is the isla verde mall that has a dennys if you want a cheap breakfast rather than the expensive breakfast in the hotel. There is a Walgreens if you walk in the san juan direction along with Burger King, Wendys, Churchs, Pizza Hut, Dominos, Subway  other little restaurants. In San Juan we loved Barra China. the service  food were great (their pina coladas were amazing). We ate at Ostra Cosa as well but we didnt enjoy it. If you are walking and you see a guy pushing a cart get some coco or another flavor. its only a dollar and they are very yummy. If you ask the hotel staff they will recommend good food for whatever you are looking for. There are definitely ways to eat good food for less if you are on a budget and know what you are doing. Overall for the price i thought Isla verde  the Intercontinental were great. its not a 5 star hotel but then again you arent really paying 5 star prices. if you want that pay a lot more and go to el san juan hotel. We had a great time and cant wait to go back! You will have an amazing time if you go knowing what you are in for. enjoy! Buen Viaje!  
<Date>Jan 11, 2006

<Author>Chantinny
<Content>Perfect We stayed at the Intercontinental from Dec. 15-20. I can't understand the negative reviews. Everyone at the hotel was so friendly and helpful. Our room was on the 10th floor overlooking the beach. It was a perfect location. Yes, there was only 1 chair on the balcony. If we wanted to, we could have taken a chair from the room outside. The room was nicely appointed. It didn't need to be spectacular since the weather was awesome and we were not in the room much. The concierges were most helpful.The buffet was included in our package. It was yummy. We went to the casinos at the El San Juan and the Ritz. We did notice a contrast in the lobbies of the 3. The Intercontinental was nondescript. The El San Juan looked like Havana in the 50's and the Ritz looked quite staid.Some people thought it was seedy walking around San Juan. If you are used to big cities, then you will feel at home. It didn't phase us at all. It was definitely safe. We like to try local food when we travel. We did not eat at any of the hotel chain restaurants. One meal was at The Metropol. It is across from The Ritz. It is Cuban food. It was excellent and not expensive. Someone on this site mentioned to order tres leche for dessert. Yes, it is a must. We also ate at Plato. It is between the El San Juan and The Ritz. We asked the waiter for advice and he told us the most popular dish. I don't remember the name. It was chicken stuffed with plantanos. The food was great, but, the service was quite slow. Our first night we didn't have a rental car and took a cab to a super fish restaurant called Atlantico. They had the best sangria. We ate at Spanglish in Old San Juan. It is good Puerto Rican home cooking. We drove to the Rain Forest. We hiked down to the waterfall at the bottom. It is about a 20-30 minute hike.The return trip is steep. Much to our disappointment, the sun was out. It was still beautiful. People said that Loquillo beach is a must. We went last year and decided to give it another shot on the way home from the rain forest. We don't understand what the hoopla is. It is just an ordinary beach. There are many kiosks selling local food that are supposed to be good. Last year we also went in December and went to a huge craft fair at the Barcardi Factory(I think it is always the 2nd week in December) It had a lot of local artisans and A LOT of people. It was worth the trip if you want to purchase locally made art. Old San Juan is colorful to walk around. There is a visitors center that has maps and info. Of course, there are many outlet stores, too.  
<Date>Jan 7, 2006

<Author>johnpw
<Content>Solid if not spectacular I stayed here with my wife and two children (12  15) Dec 25-31. I was a little concerned about what I would find based on some of the previous reviews, but overall ended up quite satisfied. We had an ocean side deluxe room (#710), which had a great view and was relatively quiet (didn't hear our neighbors plus we made sure to get a room away from the elevators). In terms of the room, this is NOT a 5-star hotel - it's a solid 3.5 in my book, but I came in with this expectation and was not disappointed. Beds were fine, basic amenities fine, bathroom small but functional. If you're looking for a 4 or 5-star type experience, you'd have to look elsewhere (Ritz or El San Juan?). Otherwise, the pool area is really nice, the lobby is good, and the staff are friendly and helpful.We've gone to Florida the last 3 Christmases and got fed up with the spotty weather. So we decided to pay the extra price for better weather and were glad we did. Otherwise, in terms of room, beach and pool, this is not much different from the place we last stayed at in Boca Raton (I can't remember the name!) and the clientele is very similar. The beach is nice but not spectacular, but perhaps I'm a bit of a beach snob, having been to some of the best in the Carribean. For GREAT beaches in Puerto Rico, you have to take a short boat trip to one of the islands (Icacos or Culebra) off the East coast. In fact, I would highly recommend the East Wind catamaran sailing  snorkeling trip, although there aren't many comfortable or shaded seats on board, so be prepared to rough it a little and bring lots of sun protection.I grew up in cities and some rough areas, so had no problems wandering around at night, but the fact of the matter is that - outside the nice resorts - the Isla Verda area (and greater San Juan as far as I could tell) is very run-down and seedy. I knew this coming in and it didn't bother me, but for those of you who like to wander around discovering charming little shops and restaurants, you'll be disappointed! Perhaps Old San Juan is better for this, but my wife came away unimpressed from her half-day trip there (I didn't go).I would consider going back because: 1) the trip in and out is so easy, 2) the hotel, pool  beach are pretty nice, 3) the weather is better than Florida, and 4) some great beaches and snorkeling are an easy day-trip away.  
<Date>Jan 2, 2006

<Author>tmsweet772
<Content>Elegant and Relaxing Things I loved: pool, lobby, nice and attractive staff, beach, atmosphereThings I didn't like: Small gift shop, breakfastIf you are looking for a hotel that has a beautiful lobby, gorgeous pool(s) and breathtaking beach this is the hotel for you. This hotel was a breath of fresh air for my friend and I. There were no screaming children, the staff was very attentive, and the overall atmosphere was laid back. I really liked that there wasn't pool games going on where the pool staff yells at you to participate. The room was nice and accomodating no complaints. Though we did complain a few times about the TV not working. The location wasn't bad. There was a gorcery store down the street, along with a Subway and a few other American fast food places. I wasn't too thrilled with breakfast at the hotel. There was only one restaurant that served it and it wasn't too good.Can't comment of Casino. I don't gamble.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Nice staff, bad room We stayed at the Inter-Continental San Juan Resort for two nights in mid-December 2005.The hotel is located right on the beach (public beach) in Isla Verde near the airport. The gardens at the front and back of the hotel were very nice. The main lobby was also quite nice, with live music in the evenings. Swimming pool in the back is large. The staff was superb, from the front desk to the hotel security to the tour coordinator. Friendly, polite, and efficient.The rooms however are really showing their age and require renovations (someone posted in their review that the hotel was recently renovated... I think that only meant the main lobby... or perhaps renovation has yet to be carried out for the floor we stayed on !?). Sound insulation was very poor. Walking in the hallway, I can hear kids talking in the rooms. When in our room at night, I can clearly hear the TV in the next room. The airplanes were also very loud, but that's what you get for staying close to the airport. We also found two small cockroaches in our room... There aren't a lot to see around the hotel, although there are a few restaurants and a supermarket across the street.If we paid the hotel advertised $200US/night rate, I would've been quite disappointed with our stay. However we got a deal at $100 US/night which made the stay more worthwhile.  
<Date>Dec 22, 2005

<Content>Great Stay! The Intercontinental was a great place to stay in San Juan! Staff was very helpful and friendly! Rooms were nice and had balconies (unlike some other hotels in San Juan). <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Liked it and will probably be back... Traveled here for a week with our 2 year old. We would recommend this resort, with a couple of minor issues.Plusses: This is by far the easiest destination in the Caribbean for travel. Non-stop flight, no customs hassles, hotel 10 minutes from airport. Within an hour of the plane landing we were hanging at the pool. For this reason we will be back again next time.Nice room-- pay up for the ocean view its worth it. Somehow we got booked on the top floor in what seemed to be an upgraded suite. We were glad to have the included breakfast package since there was a variety of good food (especially the omelette  waffle station)  they didn't charge us for our kid's food. The pool and beach are both very nice. Our child loved playing with the other toddlers in the wading area. The surrounding bars and restaurants were convenient when out in the sun. The ocean water was really warm and the waves weren't too huge. If you like to snorkle I'd recommend Caymans or Cozumel instead.The staff was very attentive. I liked having the fast food restaurants nearby...though the few hundred dollars they saved us was spent in the casino. Also contrary to some of the other reviews we found the area around the main street in front of the hotel to be fine, even at night. We live in the city  I'm far more concerned about walking around at night at home!Minuses:Room had thin walls so a few nights we were kept up by loud neighbors TVs and conversations. I'm sure they had the same complaint about our loud child early in the morning. My usual trick, turning up the fan on the thermostat to drown out noise, only works for like 10 minutes then the fan turns off. The pool is not heated and was too cold for our child to go swimming, though it seemed fine for the older kids.El San Juan casino next door was nicer  seemed to have better payouts.All in all we'd come back but I think we'll try the Ritz next time (which seems awful close to the airport...)  
<Date>Dec 10, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good and Bad I stayed with family from NYC from Nov 24th to Dec 2nd. I had read quite few reviews on the property, so I was a lttle bit unsure of what I was going into. The hotel staff, especially Juan from Avis Rent a Car and Nestor the Concierge could not have been more helpful. The overall staff were pleasant and helpful. Most times when leaving and entering the hotel, someone was always quick to hold the door open for you. The pool, beach and ocean were just delightful. There were plenty of chairs and the kids just loved the waterfalls in the pool area. Food in the hotel was OK, if you go for the breakfast package prepaid be sure that you are a big eater in order to get true value. The food at the buffet was fair at best, but you can only do so much with eggs, bagels and cereal. Ruth Chris and the resteraunts in the ESJ were outstanding.Go for the upgrade to the ocean view rooms (10th floor or higher, worth the extra $) Just a spectacular view. Mini fridge in room so stock up at one of the local stores within walking distance (day time hours only) Unsafe at night.When people talk about the surrounding area/streets as being seedy/dumpy they are right on the money. What a shame to have such beautiful beachfront hotels surrounded by such unsavory characters and trash. Let's get Trump or Wynn down here and do it right. The hotels advertise casino gaming. I guess if you've never seen Vegas or AC these pocket casino's might work. The slot machines did not pay at all in the whole time I was there, not that I was looking to hit it big, but at least give you a little tickle once in a while. If your looking to get a free drink when your on the slots, think again, because it just does not happen. I spent about $500 over a few nights on the slots, and was never offered a drink. Another reason to bring in the Donald. Side trips to Old San Juan, Rain Forest and the Caves are a must if you have the time. Don't be fooled into going over to Ponce, nothing there to speak of. Overall if you can get by the crazy drivers, seedy main drag, poverty in most area's and poor excuse for a casino and just enjoy the hotel, sun, pool and beach for what they are (very nice), you will not be sorry for staying at the Intercontinental, the folks seem to try hard at the hotel and are sincere in doing the best they can, but Puerto Rico is what it is. If you want true 4 or 5 style luxury and surroundings go to another Island.  
<Date>Dec 5, 2005

<Author>thegyp62
<Content>NOT a 5 Star Hotel Just returned from the Intercontinental Hotel in San Juan. I chose this hotel partly because of the reviews on this site. Unfortuneatly, my experience at the hotel was not a very good one. My biggest problem with the property was that it is rated 5 stars, and is no way even close. I would rate it 3 stars, at best. When you book a 5 star hotel you have certain expectations. None of my expectations were met.First of all, the Intercontinental is the old Sands Hotel. In places it looks just as dated as the Sands. The rooms have been renovated and were relatively clean but not like other Intercontinental Hotels, they have no style or warmth. We had booked a Jr. Suite. When we arrived we found out at the front desk that all Jr. Suites only face the city,(which really was not a problem) and all of them are located between the elevators. It was nosy all the time, but not unbearble. The room was not at all decorated, it had the necessaities but nothing else. Housekeepping was horrible. Everyday they never left toiletries, so no matter what time we got back to our room we had to call for toiletries. After 6 days, that gets old. They never made the king size bed, they put the bedspread on top of the TV and left it there. When we checked into the room there were no bathrobes, the toliet paper holder was off the wall, so the tissue sat on the floor and the hair blower was broken. I realize this may not seem like a big deal but when you want the service of a 5 star hotel, and pay for it, it is really dissappointing when you do not receive it. Management is a joke. When I went to check out my bill indicated that I had not paid anything and that was incorrect because I had pre-paid. In addition, the nightly rate was 40.00 more per night that I was quotad and paid for. When I questioned the front desk, they told me the 40.00 extra per night was for the third person in my room. I had no idea there was a fee, my reservation was always for three people and they never mentioned it. Plus no one ever did anything for the third person. My husband and I had to make up the sofa bed every night ourselves. As far as the prepayment, he told me according to him there was no prepayment. When I asked him to try and look deeper into the reservation he told me to call my credit card company and check my charges. By the way none of his responses were given in a pleasant way. At this point I wanted to speak to the manager.I called and received someone at the front desk who claimed he was the front desk manager.I wanted the hotel manager. I was told there was no hotel manager on staff this particular night. I know that was a lie because while I was waiting for the elevator approx. 20 minutes prior, I saw the hotel manager with another guest who was furious. I will not go into that problem because I did not witness it. Anyway, I knew the hotel manager was somewhere in the hotel but I decided to respect what this person told me and proceeded to tell him the problems with my bill. He tells me that he needs to look at all the records and he will call me back.....I am still waiting to hear from him and I have been home two days already. In fairness to the hotel, the food was very good, the grounds are well kept and very pretty, and they have a good beach. Service was good and the staff, (most of them) were friendly. The only problem was that they were always nice and pleasant, they just didn't always do what you asked for. I have been to San Juan many times and I think if you really want the service of a 5 star hotel maybe you should consider the Ritz Carlton. I have not stayed there so I cannot say so for certain. However, I can say the Intercontinental is NO way a 5 Star Hotel in San Juan.  
<Date>Nov 29, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Fabulous!!!!!! My husband and I decided to go there to celebrate our anniversary. From the moment we arrived, we were greeted like royalty. The concierge upgraded our room to an ocean view upon learning of the reason for our trip. He was extremely kind and friendly. Our room was nice and clean, and the view was georgeous. Complimentary beaches chairs, towels and tables were provided for us to layout on the beach. Bar service was provided at the beach, which was a nice addition.The food and the pool bar was excellent as well as the staff, who did their upmost to make our stay memorable. The lobby, pool area and surrounding areas was very nice and clean. The casino was nice as well. At night the lobby was a nice play to just take it down, enjoy a drink and music. The location was great in that you were able to walk around and eat and drink at the local spots. A huge 24 hr Walgreens Pharmacy was located down the street, which was nice if you needed any toiletries etc.I highly recommend this hotel for anyone looking to come to Puerto Rico.

<Author>Gracie99uk
<Content>I didn't love it .... My husband and I chose the IC San Juan for a three night stay as part of the honeymoon. I have to start this review off with a brief moan about first impressions of Puerto Rico. We had quite a bit of luggage due to our wedding and being on holiday for nearly four weeks. At the airport we paid for a luggage cart (surely all airports should provide this as a matter of courtesy?!?) only to find out that we were only allowed to wheel it to the other side of security and not outside to ground transportation - fat lot of help the luggage cart turned out to be. Airport staff were also really miserable (with the exception of the slightly mad immigration officer!). Anyway moan over ... my first impressions of the IC weren't overly positive. Whilst the staff were very welcoming and friendly I felt the room was a little small (King Bed Ocean View) and the view of the ocean can only be described as laughable given that the predominant view was of the roof of the restaurant below!!!! Other reviewers are spot on when they say that the balcony is very small - ours had a small table and one chair - not ideal for honeymooners wanting to share a romantic moment! The room was smaller than other hotels we've stayed in although I did like the separate dressing table area just outside the bathroom. Bathroom light fittings were damaged and the bathroom was very small. On the plus side the bed was very comfortable! We set off to explore the rest of the hotel. The pool is nice (the water is cold!) and there are plenty of sun loungers with very comfy cushions. The only negative thing about the pool area, in my opinion, is that it gets quite shady early on in the afternoon so not good for sunbathing. We had lunch at the restaurant at the cafe at the back - standard fare (pizza and burgers) but tasty with good service. The beach is nice and IC guests also have use of sun loungers. Ocean is warmer than the pool but beware my husband was stung by a jelly fish! The staff at the hotel were able to offer assistance with this to ease the stinging!!!We used valet parking whilst we were there and the car was always available when we got outside - valets were friendly and helpful. We ate at Ruth Chris Steakhouse (twice) - delicious!We also visited Old San Juan - there's parking right at the top by El Morro in an underground lot (v.convenient) and the Barcardi Factory. I agree with a previous review that you don't actually learn much about the process of rum making and the guided tours are herded through quite quickly not giving enough time to listen (it's an audio tour) to all the information. My husband enjoyed it as he had his two free drinks as well as mine!!!One evening we wandered over to El San Juan - hotel was busy and there seemed to be a good atmosphere. Not sure I would pay the price to stay here when it's only a five minute stroll from the IC and you can still enjoy all it has to offer.All in all I'm not sure I would hurry back to Puerto Rico even though I did enjoy my stay.  
<Date>Nov 27, 2005

<Author>blossom1022
<Content>Great service and prime location My husband and I (ages 34 and 32) just returned from a 5 night stay at the InterContinental. Wee been on many tropical vacations before (Mexico, Aruba, Jamaica, St. Marten). Our trip to P.R. was a last-minute decision. We were looking to travel to a beach destination during the Thanksgiving week that was a short flight from the N.Y. area airports. We wanted a location that had a beach, nightlife  an area we could explore independently.SUMMARY: Overall we were satisfied with our stay at the IC and I would rate it 3 out of 5 stars. ROOM: We booked and received a city-view room with a king size bed. The room was clean and functional, albeit smaller than I thought for the price and the carpet slightly worn.SERVICE: This is where the IC shines. Every employee we encountered was super friendly, attentive  eager to help.CONCIERGE and FRONT DESK: While friendly, I must note that some of the advice/suggestions given by the concierges were off the mark. For example: 2 of them recommended a trendy restaurant in Old San Juan, AquaViva. We asked for an upscale seafood restaurant. Well AquaViva is really a 2-star restaurant charging 5-star prices in my opinion. We found it to be overpriced, overhyped and overcooked (my dinner that is). The total bill was over $120 for 2, which included 2 drinks, appetizers  dinner for 2 people. Add on about $40 for the cab ride from the hotel and back, and we spent over $140. We don mind spending the $$ but when the place looks like a diner painted blue with seashells as the dcor and we arrive dressed to impress it was disappointing, especially since the food was overcooked and the bill was about the same as we spent at some much higher-end restaurants we dined at during our stay. We did enjoy La Piccola at the El San Juan  Ruth's Chris steakhouse. We chalked it up as a ost in Translation?episode. What we consider upscale may differ from others since we eat out regularly at some great New York City restaurants. For those looking for restaurant suggestions in Old San Juan, I highly recommend simply taking a cab to Fortaleza street (restaurant row) and walking around yourselves and deciding. We saw more appealings choices when we went on our own strolling through Old San Juan.Also, on a number of occasions, we had difficulty speaking with the concierge or someone at the front desk. Either there was no one manned at the desk for extended periods of time, or a few times when I called the concierge desk no one answered the phone. This wasn anything to ruin our trip, but these are issues that keep the IC firmly as a 3-star hotel in my opinion.POOL/BEACH area: Everything was well maintained. Food and service at the restaurants near the pool and beach were great. Also, the hotel does provide free towels  beach chairs. You simply go to the pool hut and provide your room number.ACTIVITIES: We rented a car for a day with AVIS and went to Old San Juan and we also hopped on the ferry to go to the Bacardi Factory. The ferry to the Bacardi Factory was only 50 cents pp and then a quick shuttle ride to the Bacardi Factory. Personally, I would just skip the factory visit, it more like a looong Bacardi commercial. They don really go into depth with the process of rum making. We were just glad that we didn pay the tour package price to go there!!We also visited the bio-bay arranged right at the hotel for $150. This was a surreal experience. Make sure you wear your bathing suit and don wear anything that you don want to get wet. Youe basically paddling your way in water in a kayak at 10 pm in pitch black so be prepared. It not for the faint of heart or for small children in my opinion. THANKSGIVING: The hotel had a special Thanksgiving buffet for about $35pp which included mimosas and dessert. Given the price, we thought it was a good value and the turkey was delicious. We noticed the resort had a lot more guests check in the day before Thanksgiving and we were glad we were leaving the next day to avoid the crowds.Would we go back? Possibly, but I be more likely to consider the El San Juan next door if I find out that theye updated their hotel rooms more. El San Juan had a lot more ambience and was a lot livelier at night. I certainly recommend the IC for families or groups looking for a decent place to stay in San Juan.  
<Date>Nov 26, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good Deal for a Quick Getaway Stayed at Intercontinental 11/13-11/17/2005 and enjoyed our stay. Arrived at 2pm but room not ready..was able to check in by 3pm. Check in is listed at 4pm. Had a city view room, asked for an upgrade but was denied because Hotel was booked. Asked next day, advised room avail if we wanted to pay $40 extra per day. Worth the money for an ocean view/city view not the most appealing. Very close to airport can see  hear planes from hotel room/Some buildings in the city look very run down. There were some really nice rooms that had patios that were steps from the pool and beach. If I ever stay again I would book that. Taxi from airport $9 going to hotel but $11 from hotel which we found strange!!! Quick easy access to  from airport which is a plus for those on a short trip. I was very concerned about the weather since the weather reports showed rain with a dark cloud every day. It was rainy and overcast the entire 1st day so we spent the night enjoying the casino (just played nickel slots which were alot of fun but not very loose)def not VEGAS...lol/won  lost, basically broke even but had lots of fun. Got free drinks at the casino while playing but had to look for a waitress since we were only playing nickels..lol. My husband does not play the slots but was happy watching the game on a HUGE TV located in the casino. We did eat at the Japanese Steak House inside the hotel which was alot of fun , got to meet some other people at our table. Price ok approx $50 for the two of us. Prayed that night for sun and the next three days were sunny (YIPEE!!)..did have periods of quick showers. Jumped in the Jacuzzi during brief showers, nice  hot/bubbly or lounged in nice padded chair under tent or umbrella because rain usually didn't last long. It does get overcast at times so be sure to use sunblock as you can burn very fast . Beach was nice...golden sand not white but was raked every morning. Look closly when walking on beach to observe little clams being washed ashore/little lizards running around grounds of hotel. If you order a drink from the beach it has a surcharge...paid $9+tip for a mudslide from Splash Bar but it was VERY GOOD. Snorkeling/Fishing and other tours can be booked at pool hut. Plenty of clean towels and free bottled water. Snorkeling canceled due to rough water. Had alot of wind. Spent 2 lazy days on beach and at pool. Took local bus A-5 to Old San Juan .25 cents/nice shopsnote: Bus gets very crowded had to stand up during 1/2 the trip on the way back (apprx 50-60 min ride to Old San Juan on bus) If you dont like crowds can take taxi for approx $16 each way(see Conciere before going to San Juan for good info/map) Took ferry (.50 cent pp)from Old San Juan from Pier 2 and then taxi ($3 pp) to take free tour of Bacardi Factory which included 2 free drinks per person. Good deals there on all kinds of Rum. Oh...the breakfast at hotel is expensive unless included in hotel price...we enjoyed Mi Casita restaurant for breakfast. A short walk to the right of the hotel/a very small place but had great coffee. Area also has grocery/liquor store..dominos pizza, ponderosa, burger king. Another shopping area w/a Dennys to the left of the hotel. Overall, Hotel staff was nice...best service was at the beach where staff will place beach chair for you. Security always on duty..felt very safe. One last thing...rooms were small and the balcony is for one person only. Rooms were clean/did not see any bugs or anything like that. If you prefer a more polished luxury hotel with alot of night life then you may want to stay next door at the Wyndam. Intercontinental is an overall good deal for the money. BEST FEATURE: POOL/BEACH  
<Date>Nov 21, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Vacation  My vacation was from Nov 9-15. Note that this review is from a 25 year old (female) and traveled with my friend- same age. I was overall very happy with this hotel. The hotel is a five minute drive from the airport, which was great. This also means you will hear the planes -this did not bother us. We had arrived early, about 2 hrs prior to check in time, but we were given our room right away, no waiting, which was great. The room was nice, we had a city view- this was not a big deal as i didnt plan to spend my vacation in my room. My first impression was that all the staff were extremely helpful and very nice. The beach was clean, warm water- not crystal clear as compared to other islands, but still very nice. The pool was nice although we mostly stayed at the beach. The food / drinks at the hotel were a bit pricey( although good). Head across the street where you can pick up drinks/snacks at the supermarket, and there are plenty of american chains for a cheap breakfast/lunch. Also, Mi Casita is very reasonable although plan to wait for a while- service was a bit slow but food was still good. For dinner we mostly ate away from the hotel because we wanted to try as many local restaurants as possible. I highly recommend Ajili Mojili ( sp?) Food was excellent- definetly the best that I had while in PR. As far as nightlife at the hotel, there is a small bar in the lobby ( nice spot to get a drink and hang out- low key) and there is a casino. The casino in the hotel was ok for my purposes, Im not a big gambler so I really cant comment. Nightclubs- We went to Babylon - at the El san juan ( their lobby on the weekend was packed - in comparison to IC). We also went to senor frogs,Pool Palace and Lazer- there are alot of clubs  bars in the area- depending on what kind of music you like. Concierge  staff in the hotel were helpful in giving us some ideas. As far as the weather, prior to leaving I checked the forecast which said rain every day, I was a little worried, but if it rained, it was for about 10 minutes then it cleared up. We did not lose any days due to the rain. I would definetly recommend taking the tour to El Yunque ( bring an umbrella), tour was great, rainforest  waterfalls were beautiful. Old San Juan has alot of great shopping and plenty of restaurants. You can take the bus for .25 ( but the last bus out of Old San Juan was 9pm- so we always took a taxi). Overall we had a great time in PR and at the Intercontinental. I would definetly recommend this hotel and would return for another stay.  
<Date>Nov 16, 2005
